subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I work with a species called "Bonobo."

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
And I'm happy most of the time,

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
because I think this is the happiest species on the planet.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
It's kind of a well-kept secret.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
This species lives only in the Congo.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:30.958
And they're not in too many zoos, because of their sexual behavior.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
Their sexual behavior is too human-like

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
for most of us to be comfortable with.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:35.958
(Laughter)

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:36.958
But --

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:37.958
(Laughter)

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:42.958
actually, we have a lot to learn from them, because they're a very

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:46.958
egalitarian society and they're a very empathetic society.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:50.958
And sexual behavior is not confined to one aspect of their life

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
that they sort of set aside.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
It permeates their entire life.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
And it's used for communication.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
And it's used for conflict resolution.

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:04.958
And I think perhaps somewhere in our history we sort of,

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
divided our lives up into lots of parts.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:11.958
We divided our world up with lots of categories.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
And so everything sort of has a place that it has to fit.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:18.958
But I don't think that we were that way initially.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:22.958
There are many people who think that the animal world is hard-wired

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:26.958
and that there's something very, very special about man.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:30.958
Maybe it's his ability to have causal thought.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
Maybe it's something special in his brain

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
that allows him to have language.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
Maybe it's something special in his brain

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:43.958
that allows him to make tools or to have mathematics.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:49.958
Well, I don't know. There were Tasmanians who were discovered

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:53.958
around the 1600s and they had no fire.

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
They had no stone tools.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
To our knowledge they had no music.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
So when you compare them to the Bonobo,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
the Bonobo is a little hairier.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:11.958
He doesn't stand quite as upright.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
But there are a lot of similarities.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:19.958
And I think that as we look at culture,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
we kind of come to understand

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
how we got to where we are.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
And I don't really think it's in our biology;

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
I think we've attributed it to our biology,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
but I don't really think it's there.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
So what I want to do now is introduce you

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
to a species called the Bonobo.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
This is Kanzi.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
He's a Bonobo.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
Right now, he's in a forest in Georgia.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:49.958
His mother originally came from a forest in Africa.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
And she came to us when she was just at puberty,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
about six or seven years of age.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
Now this shows a Bonobo on your right,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:02:59.958
and a chimpanzee on your left.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:04.958
Clearly, the chimpanzee has a little bit harder time of walking.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
The Bonobo, although shorter than us and their arms still longer,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:12.958
is more upright, just as we are.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:17.958
This shows the Bonobo compared to an australopithecine like Lucy.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
As you can see, there's not a lot of difference

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
between the way a Bonobo walks

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:26.958
and the way an early australopithecine would have walked.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
As they turn toward us you'll see

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:33.958
that the pelvic area of early australopithecines is a little flatter

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:37.958
and doesn't have to rotate quite so much from side to side.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
So the -- the bipedal gait is a little easier.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
And now we see all four.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Video: Narrator: The wild Bonobo lives in central Africa, in the jungle

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
encircled by the Congo River.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:55.958
Canopied trees as tall as 40 meters, 130 feet,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:59.958
grow densely in the area.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
It was a Japanese scientist

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:06.958
who first undertook serious field studies of the Bonobo,

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
almost three decades ago.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
Bonobos are built slightly smaller than the chimpanzee.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:21.958
Slim-bodied, Bonobos are by nature very gentle creatures.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:27.958
Long and careful studies have reported many new findings on them.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:35.958
One discovery was that wild Bonobos often walk bidpedally.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:46.958
What's more, they are able to walk upright for long distances.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Susan Savage-Rumbaugh (video): Let's go say hello to Austin first and then go to the A frame.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
SS: This is Kanzi and I, in the forest.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
None of the things you will see in this particular video are trained.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
None of them are tricks.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
They all happened to be captured on film spontaneously,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
by NHK of Japan.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
We have eight Bonobos.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
Video: Look at all this stuff that's here for our campfire.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
SS: An entire family at our research centre.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
Video: You going to help get some sticks?

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:29.958
Good.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
We need more sticks, too.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
I have a lighter in my pocket if you need one.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
That's a wasps' nest.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
You can get it out.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
I hope I have a lighter.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
You can use the lighter to start the fire.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
SS: So Kanzi is very interested in fire.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
He doesn't do it yet without a lighter,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:07.958
but I think if he saw someone do it, he might be able to do --

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
make a fire without a lighter.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
He's learning about how to keep a fire going.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
He's learning the uses for a fire,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
just by watching what we do with fire.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
(Laughter)

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
This is a smile on the face of a Bonobo.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
These are happy vocalizations.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
Video: You're happy.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
You're very happy about this part.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:41.958
You've got to put some water on the fire. You see the water?

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
Good job.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
SS: Forgot to zip up the back half of his backpack.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
But he likes to carry things from place to place.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Video: Austin, I hear you saying "Austin."

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
SS: He talks to other Bonobos at the lab, long-distance,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
farther than we can hear.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
This is his sister.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
This is her first time to try to drive a golf cart.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
Video: Goodbye.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
(Laughter)

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
SS: She's got the pedals down, but not the wheel.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
She switches from reverse to forward

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
and she holds onto the wheel, rather than turns it.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
(Laughter)

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Like us, she knows that that individual in the mirror is her.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.958
(Music)

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:45.958
Video: Narrator: By raising Bonobos in a culture that is both Bonobo and human,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
and documenting their development across two decades,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
scientists are exploring how cultural forces

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:53.958
(Laughter)

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
may have operated during human evolution.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
His name is Nyota.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
It means "star" in Swahili.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:09.958
(Music)

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Panbanisha is trying to give Nyota a haircut with a pair of scissors.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.958
In the wild, the parent Bonobo is known to groom its offspring.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.958
Here Panbanisha uses scissors, instead of her hands,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
to groom Nyota.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
Very impressive.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
Subtle maneuvering of the hands is required

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
to perform delicate tasks like this.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:57.958
Nyota tries to imitate Panbanisha by using the scissors himself.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
Realizing that Nyota might get hurt,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Panbanisha, like any human mother,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
carefully tugs to get the scissors back.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
He can now cut through tough animal hide.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
SS: Kanzi's learned to make stone tools.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:30.958
Video: Kanzi now makes his tools,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
just as our ancestors may have made them,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
two-and-a-half million years ago --

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:39.958
by holding the rocks in both hands, to strike one against the other.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
He has learned that by using both hands

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and aiming his glancing blows,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
he can make much larger, sharper flakes.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
Kanzi chooses a flake he thinks is sharp enough.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
The tough hide is difficult to cut, even with a knife.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
The rock that Kanzi is using is extremely hard

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
and ideal for stone tool making, but difficult to handle,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
requiring great skill.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Kanzi's rock is from Gona, Ethiopia

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.958
and is identical to that used by our African ancestors

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
two-and-a-half million years ago.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
These are the rocks Kanzi used

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
and these are the flakes he made.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:29.958
The flat sharp edges are like knife blades.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
Compare them to the tools our ancestors used;

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
they bear a striking resemblance to Kanzi's.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
Panbanisha is longing to go for a walk in the woods.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
She keeps staring out the window.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
SS: This is -- let me show you something we didn't think they would do.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Video: For several days now, Panbanisha has not been outside.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
SS: I normally talk about language.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
Video: Then Panbanisha does something unexpected.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
SS: But since I'm advised not to do what I normally do,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
I haven't told you that these apes have language.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
It's a geometric language.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:16.958
Video: She takes a piece of chalk

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and begins writing something on the floor.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
What is she writing?

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
SS: She's also saying the name of that, with her voice.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
Video: Now she comes up to Dr. Sue and starts writing again.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
SS: These are her symbols on her keyboard.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:37.958
(Music)

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
They speak when she touches them.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Video: Panbanisha is communicating to Dr. Sue where she wants to go.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
"A frame" represents a hut in the woods.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Compare the chalk writing with the lexigram on the keyboard.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:04.958
Panbanisha began writing the lexigrams on the forest floor.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
SS (video): Very nice. Beautiful, Panbanisha.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
SS: At first we didn't really realize what she was doing,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
until we stood back and looked at it and rotated it.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
Video: This lexigram also refers to a place in the woods.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
The curved line is very similar to the lexigram.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:29.958
The next symbol Panbanisha writes represents "collar."

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:33.958
It indicates the collar that Panbanisha must wear when she goes out.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
SS: That's an institutional requirement.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
Video: This symbol is not as clear as the others,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:44.958
but one can see Panbanisha is trying to produce a curved line

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
and several straight lines.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Researchers began to record what Panbanisha said,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
by writing lexigrams on the floor with chalk.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
Panbanisha watched.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Soon she began to write as well.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
The Bonobo's abilities have stunned scientists around the world.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
How did they develop?

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
SS (video): We found that the most important thing

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:13.958
for permitting Bonobos to acquire language is not to teach them.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
It's simply to use language around them,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
because the driving force in language acquisition

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:24.958
is to understand what others, that are important to you, are saying to you.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Once you have that capacity,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
the ability to produce language

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
comes rather naturally and rather freely.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
So we want to create an environment in which Bonobos,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
like all of the individuals with whom they are interacting --

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
we want to create an environment in which they have fun,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
and an environment in which the others

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
are meaningful individuals for them.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
Narrator: This environment brings out unexpected potential

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
in Kanzi and Panbanisha.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Panbanisha is enjoying playing her harmonica,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
until Nyota, now one year old, steals it.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:15.958
Then he peers eagerly into his mother's mouth.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Is he looking for where the sound came from?

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
Dr. Sue thinks it's important to allow such curiosity to flourish.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
This time Panbanisha is playing the electric piano.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
She wasn't forced to learn the piano;

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
she saw a researcher play the instrument and took an interest.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
Researcher: Go ahead. Go ahead. I'm listening.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
Do that real fast part that you did. Yeah, that part.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
Narrator: Kanzi plays the xylophone;

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:29.958
using both hands he enthusiastically accompanies Dr. Sue's singing.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:31.958
Kanzi and Panbanisha

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
are stimulated by this fun-filled environment,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.958
which promotes the emergence of these cultural capabilities.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
(Laughter)

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
Researcher: OK, now get the monsters. Get them.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
Take the cherries too.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
Now watch out, stay away from them now.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
Now you can chase them again. Time to chase them.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
Now you have to stay away. Get away.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
Run away. Run.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:19.958
Now we can chase them again. Go get them.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:22.958
Oh no!

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
Good Kanzi. Very good. Thank you so much.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:37.958
Narrator: None of us, Bonobo or human, can possibly even imagine?

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:50.958
SS: So we have a bi-species environment, we call it a "panhomoculture."

title: The story of life in photographs
transcript: Nature's my muse and it's been my passion. As a photographer for National Geographic, I've portrayed it for many. But five years ago, I went on a personal journey. I wanted to visualize the story of life. It's the hardest thing I've ever attempted, and there have been plenty of times when I felt like backing out. But there were also revelations. And one of those I'd like to share with you today.I went down to a remote lagoon in Australia, hoping to see the Earth the way it was three billion years ago, back before the sky turned blue. There's stromatolites down there — the first living things to capture photosynthesis — and it's the only place they still occur today. Going down there was like entering a time capsule, and I came out with a different sense of myself in time. The oxygen exhaled by those stromatolites is what we all breathe today.Stromatolites are the heroes in my story. I hope it's a story that has some resonance for our time. It's a story about you and me, nature and science. And with that said, I'd like to invite you for a short, brief journey of life through time. Our journey starts in space, where matter condenses into spheres over time ... solidifying into surface, molded by fire. The fire gave way, Earth emerged — but this was an alien planet. The moon was closer; things were different. Heat from within made geysers erupt — that is how the oceans were born. Water froze around the poles and shaped the edges of the Earth. Water is the key to life, but in frozen form, it is a latent force. And when it vanishes, Earth becomes Mars.But this planet is different — it's roiling inside. And where that energy touches water, something new emerges: life. It arises around cracks in the Earth. Mud and minerals become substrate; there are bacteria. Learn to multiply, thickening in places ... Growing living structures under an alien sky ... Stromatolites were the first to exhale oxygen. And they changed the atmosphere. A breath that's fossilized now as iron.Meteorites delivered chemistry, and perhaps membranes, too. Life needs a membrane to contain itself so it can replicate and mutate. These are diatoms, single-celled phytoplankton with skeletons of silicon ... circuit boards of the future. Shallow seas nurtured life early on, and that's where it morphed into more complex forms. It grew as light and oxygen increased. Life hardened and became defensive. It learned to move and began to see. The first eyes grew on trilobites. Vision was refined in horseshoe crabs, among the first to leave the sea. They still do what they've done for ages, their enemies long gone.Scorpions follow prey out of the sea. Slugs became snails. Fish tried amphibian life. Frogs adapted to deserts. Lichens arose as a co-op. Fungi married algae ... clinging to rock, and eating it too ... transforming barren land. True land plants arose, leafless at first. Once they learn how to stay upright, they grew in size and shape. The fundamental forms of ferns followed, to bear spores that foreshadowed seeds. Life flourished in swamps.On land, life turned a corner. Jaws formed first; teeth came later. Leatherbacks and tuataras are echoes from that era. It took time for life to break away from water, and it still beckons all the time. Life turned hard so it could venture inland. And the dragons that arose are still among us today. Jurassic Park still shimmers in part of Madagascar, and the center of Brazil, where plants called "cycads" remain rock hard. Forests arose and nurtured things with wings. One early form left an imprint, like it died only yesterday. And others fly today like echoes of the past. In birds, life gained new mobility. Flamingos covered continents. Migrations got underway.Birds witnessed the emergence of flowering plants. Water lilies were among the first. Plants began to diversify and grew, turning into trees. In Australia, a lily turned into a grass tree, and in Hawaii, a daisy became a silver sword. In Africa, Gondwana molded Proteas. But when that ancient continent broke up, life got lusher. Tropical rainforests arose, sparking new layers of interdependence. Fungi multiplied. Orchids emerged, genitalia shaped to lure insects ... a trick shared by the largest flower on Earth. Co-evolution entwined insects and birds and plants forever. When birds can't fly, they become vulnerable. Kiwis are, and so are these hawks trapped near Antarctica.Extinction can come slowly, but sometimes it arrives fast. An asteroid hits, and the world went down in flames. But there were witnesses, survivors in the dark. When the skies cleared, a new world was born. A world fit for mammals. From tiny shrews [came] tenrecs, accustomed to the dark. New forms became bats. Civets. New predators, hyenas, getting faster and faster still.Grasslands created opportunities. Herd safety came with sharpened senses. Growing big was another answer, but size always comes at a price. Some mammals turned back to water. Walruses adapted with layers of fat. Sea lions got sleek. And cetaceans moved into a world without bounds. There are many ways to be a mammal. A 'roo hops in Oz; a horse runs in Asia; and a wolf evolves stilt legs in Brazil. Primates emerge from jungles, as tarsiers first, becoming lemurs not much later. Learning became reinforced. Bands of apes ventured into the open. And forests dried out once more. Going upright became a lifestyle.So who are we? Brothers of masculine chimps, sisters of feminine bonobos? We are all of them, and more. We're molded by the same life force. The blood veins in our hands echoed a course of water traces on the Earth. And our brains — our celebrated brains — reflect a drainage of a tidal marsh.Life is a force in its own right. It is a new element. And it has altered the Earth. It covers Earth like a skin. And where it doesn't, as in Greenland in winter, Mars is still not very far. But that likelihood fades as long as ice melts again. And where water is liquid, it becomes a womb for cells green with chlorophyll — and that molecular marvel is what's made a difference — it powers everything. The whole animal world today lives on a stockpile of bacterial oxygen that is cycled constantly through plants and algae, and their waste is our breath, and vice versa. This Earth is alive, and it's made its own membrane. We call it "atmosphere." This is the icon of our journey. And you all here today can imagine and will shape where we go next. (Applause) Thank you. Thank you.

title: The shrimp with a kick!
transcript: If you'd like to learn how to play the lobster, we have some here. And that's not a joke, we really do. So come up afterwards and I'll show you how to play a lobster.So, actually, I started working on what's called the mantis shrimp a few years ago because they make sound. This is a recording I made of a mantis shrimp that's found off the coast of California. And while that's an absolutely fascinating sound, it actually turns out to be a very difficult project. And while I was struggling to figure out how and why mantis shrimp, or stomatopods, make sound, I started to think about their appendages. And mantis shrimp are called "mantis shrimp" after the praying mantises, which also have a fast feeding appendage. And I started to think, well, maybe it will be interesting, while listening to their sounds, to figure out how these animals generate very fast feeding strikes. And so today I'll talk about the extreme stomatopod strike, work that I've done in collaboration with Wyatt Korff and Roy Caldwell.So, mantis shrimp come in two varieties: there are spearers and smashers. And this is a spearing mantis shrimp, or stomatopod. And he lives in the sand, and he catches things that go by overhead. So, a quick strike like that. And if we slow it down a bit, this is the mantis shrimp — the same species — recorded at 1,000 frames a second, played back at 15 frames per second. And you can see it's just a really spectacular extension of the limbs, exploding upward to actually just catch a dead piece of shrimp that I had offered it. Now, the other type of mantis shrimp is the smasher stomatopod, and these guys open up snails for a living. And so this guy gets the snail all set up and gives it a good whack.(Laughter)So, I'll play it one more time. He wiggles it in place, tugs it with his nose, and smash. And a few smashes later, the snail is broken open, and he's got a good dinner. So, the smasher raptorial appendage can stab with a point at the end, or it can smash with the heel. And today I'll talk about the smashing type of strike.And so the first question that came to mind was, well, how fast does this limb move? Because it's moving pretty darn fast on that video. And I immediately came upon a problem. Every single high-speed video system in the biology department at Berkeley wasn't fast enough to catch this movement. We simply couldn't capture it on video. And so this had me stymied for quite a long period of time. And then a BBC crew came cruising through the biology department, looking for a story to do about new technologies in biology. And so we struck up a deal. I said, "Well, if you guys rent the high-speed video system that could capture these movements, you guys can film us collecting the data." And believe it or not, they went for it. (Laughter) So we got this incredible video system. It's very new technology — it just came out about a year ago — that allows you to film at extremely high speeds in low light. And low light is a critical issue with filming animals, because if it's too high, you fry them. (Laughter)So this is a mantis shrimp. There are the eyes up here, and there's that raptorial appendage, and there's the heel. And that thing's going to swing around and smash the snail. And the snail's wired to a stick, so he's a little bit easier to set up the shot. And — yeah.(Laughter)I hope there aren't any snail rights activists around here.(Laughter)So this was filmed at 5,000 frames per second, and I'm playing it back at 15. And so this is slowed down 333 times. And as you'll notice, it's still pretty gosh darn fast slowed down 333 times. It's an incredibly powerful movement. The whole limb extends out. The body flexes backwards — just a spectacular movement. And so what we did is, we took a look at these videos, and we measured how fast the limb was moving to get back to that original question. And we were in for our first surprise. So what we calculated was that the limbs were moving at the peak speed ranging from 10 meters per second all the way up to 23 meters per second. And for those of you who prefer miles per hour, that's over 45 miles per hour in water. And this is really darn fast. In fact, it's so fast we were able to add a new point on the extreme animal movement spectrum. And mantis shrimp are officially the fastest measured feeding strike of any animal system. So our first surprise.(Applause)So that was really cool and very unexpected. So, you might be wondering, well, how do they do it? And actually, this work was done in the 1960s by a famous biologist named Malcolm Burrows. And what he showed in mantis shrimp is that they use what's called a "catch mechanism," or "click mechanism." And what this basically consists of is a large muscle that takes a good long time to contract, and a latch that prevents anything from moving. So the muscle contracts, and nothing happens. And once the muscle's contracted completely, everything's stored up — the latch flies upward, and you've got the movement. And that's basically what's called a "power amplification system." It takes a long time for the muscle to contract, and a very short time for the limb to fly out. And so I thought that this was sort of the end of the story. This was how mantis shrimps make these very fast strikes.But then I took a trip to the National Museum of Natural History. And if any of you ever have a chance, backstage of the National Museum of Natural History is one of the world's best collections of preserved mantis shrimp. And what —(Laughter)this is serious business for me.(Laughter)So, this — what I saw, on every single mantis shrimp limb, whether it's a spearer or a smasher, is a beautiful saddle-shaped structure right on the top surface of the limb. And you can see it right here. It just looks like a saddle you'd put on a horse. It's a very beautiful structure. And it's surrounded by membranous areas. And those membranous areas suggested to me that maybe this is some kind of dynamically flexible structure. And this really sort of had me scratching my head for a while. And then we did a series of calculations, and what we were able to show is that these mantis shrimp have to have a spring. There needs to be some kind of spring-loaded mechanism in order to generate the amount of force that we observe, and the speed that we observe, and the output of the system. So we thought, OK, this must be a spring — the saddle could very well be a spring. And we went back to those high-speed videos again, and we could actually visualize the saddle compressing and extending. And I'll just do that one more time. And then if you take a look at the video — it's a little bit hard to see — it's outlined in yellow. The saddle is outlined in yellow. You can actually see it extending over the course of the strike, and actually hyperextending. So, we've had very solid evidence showing that that saddle-shaped structure actually compresses and extends, and does, in fact, function as a spring.The saddle-shaped structure is also known as a "hyperbolic paraboloid surface," or an "anticlastic surface." And this is very well known to engineers and architects, because it's a very strong surface in compression. It has curves in two directions, one curve upward and opposite transverse curve down the other, so any kind of perturbation spreads the forces over the surface of this type of shape. So it's very well known to engineers, not as well known to biologists. It's also known to quite a few people who make jewelry, because it requires very little material to build this type of surface, and it's very strong. So if you're going to build a thin gold structure, it's very nice to have it in a shape that's strong.Now, it's also known to architects. One of the most famous architects is Eduardo Catalano, who popularized this structure. And what's shown here is a saddle-shaped roof that he built that's 87 and a half feet spanwise. It's two and a half inches thick, and supported at two points. And one of the reasons why he designed roofs this way is because it's — he found it fascinating that you could build such a strong structure that's made of so few materials and can be supported by so few points. And all of these are the same principles that apply to the saddle-shaped spring in stomatopods. In biological systems it's important not to have a whole lot of extra material requirements for building it. So, very interesting parallels between the biological and the engineering worlds. And interestingly, this turns out — the stomatopod saddle turns out to be the first described biological hyperbolic paraboloid spring. That's a bit long, but it is sort of interesting.So the next and final question was, well, how much force does a mantis shrimp produce if they're able to break open snails? And so I wired up what's called a load cell. A load cell measures forces, and this is actually a piezoelectronic load cell that has a little crystal in it. And when this crystal is squeezed, the electrical properties change and it — which — in proportion to the forces that go in. So these animals are wonderfully aggressive, and are really hungry all the time. And so all I had to do was actually put a little shrimp paste on the front of the load cell, and they'd smash away at it. And so this is just a regular video of the animal just smashing the heck out of this load cell. And we were able to get some force measurements out. And again, we were in for a surprise.I purchased a 100-pound load cell, thinking, no animal could produce more than 100 pounds at this size of an animal. And what do you know? They immediately overloaded the load cell. So these are actually some old data where I had to find the smallest animals in the lab, and we were able to measure forces of well over 100 pounds generated by an animal about this big. And actually, just last week I got a 300-pound load cell up and running, and I've clocked these animals generating well over 200 pounds of force. And again, I think this will be a world record. I have to do a little bit more background reading, but I think this will be the largest amount of force produced by an animal of a given — per body mass. So, really incredible forces. And again, that brings us back to the importance of that spring in storing up and releasing so much energy in this system. But that was not the end of the story.Now, things — I'm making this sound very easy, this is actually a lot of work. And I got all these force measurements, and then I went and looked at the force output of the system. And this is just very simple — time is on the X-axis and the force is on the Y-axis. And you can see two peaks. And that was what really got me puzzled. The first peak, obviously, is the limb hitting the load cell. But there's a really large second peak half a millisecond later, and I didn't know what that was. So now, you'd expect a second peak for other reasons, but not half a millisecond later. Again, going back to those high-speed videos, there's a pretty good hint of what might be going on. Here's that same orientation that we saw earlier. There's that raptorial appendage — there's the heel, and it's going to swing around and hit the load cell. And what I'd like you to do in this shot is keep your eye on this, on the surface of the load cell, as the limb comes flying through. And I hope what you are able to see is actually a flash of light.Audience: Wow.Sheila Patek: And so if we just take that one frame, what you can actually see there at the end of that yellow arrow is a vapor bubble. And what that is, is cavitation. And cavitation is an extremely potent fluid dynamic phenomenon which occurs when you have areas of water moving at extremely different speeds. And when this happens, it can cause areas of very low pressure, which results in the water literally vaporizing. And when that vapor bubble collapses, it emits sound, light and heat, and it's a very destructive process. And so here it is in the stomatopod. And again, this is a situation where engineers are very familiar with this phenomenon, because it destroys boat propellers. People have been struggling for years to try and design a very fast rotating boat propeller that doesn't cavitate and literally wear away the metal and put holes in it, just like these pictures show.So this is a potent force in fluid systems, and just to sort of take it one step further, I'm going to show you the mantis shrimp approaching the snail. This is taken at 20,000 frames per second, and I have to give full credit to the BBC cameraman, Tim Green, for setting this shot up, because I could never have done this in a million years — one of the benefits of working with professional cameramen. You can see it coming in, and an incredible flash of light, and all this cavitation spreading over the surface of the snail. So really, just an amazing image, slowed down extremely, to extremely slow speeds. And again, we can see it in slightly different form there, with the bubble forming and collapsing between those two surfaces. In fact, you might have even seen some cavitation going up the edge of the limb.So to solve this quandary of the two force peaks: what I think was going on is: that first impact is actually the limb hitting the load cell, and the second impact is actually the collapse of the cavitation bubble. And these animals may very well be making use of not only the force and the energy stored with that specialized spring, but the extremes of the fluid dynamics. And they might actually be making use of fluid dynamics as a second force for breaking the snail. So, really fascinating double whammy, so to speak, from these animals.So, one question I often get after this talk — so I figured I'd answer it now — is, well, what happens to the animal? Because obviously, if it's breaking snails, the poor limb must be disintegrating. And indeed it does. That's the smashing part of the heel on both these images, and it gets worn away. In fact, I've seen them wear away their heel all the way to the flesh. But one of the convenient things about being an arthropod is that you have to molt. And every three months or so these animals molt, and they build a new limb and it's no problem. Very, very convenient solution to that particular problem.So, I'd like to end on sort of a wacky note.(Laughter)Maybe this is all wacky to folks like you, I don't know.(Laughter)So, the saddles — that saddle-shaped spring — has actually been well known to biologists for a long time, not as a spring but as a visual signal. And there's actually a spectacular colored dot in the center of the saddles of many species of stomatopods. And this is quite interesting, to find evolutionary origins of visual signals on what's really, in all species, their spring. And I think one explanation for this could be going back to the molting phenomenon.So these animals go into a molting period where they're unable to strike — their bodies become very soft. And they're literally unable to strike or they will self-destruct. This is for real. And what they do is, up until that time period when they can't strike, they become really obnoxious and awful, and they strike everything in sight; it doesn't matter who or what. And the second they get into that time point when they can't strike any more, they just signal. They wave their legs around. And it's one of the classic examples in animal behavior of bluffing. It's a well-established fact of these animals that they actually bluff. They can't actually strike, but they pretend to. And so I'm very curious about whether those colored dots in the center of the saddles are conveying some kind of information about their ability to strike, or their strike force, and something about the time period in the molting cycle. So sort of an interesting strange fact to find a visual structure right in the middle of their spring.So to conclude, I mostly want to acknowledge my two collaborators, Wyatt Korff and Roy Caldwell, who worked closely with me on this. And also the Miller Institute for Basic Research in Science, which gave me three years of funding to just do science all the time, and for that I'm very grateful. Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
If you'd like to learn how to play the lobster, we have some here.

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
And that's not a joke, we really do.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
So come up afterwards and I'll show you how to play a lobster.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:23.958
So, actually, I started working on what's called the mantis shrimp

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
a few years ago because they make sound.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:28.958
This is a recording I made of a mantis shrimp

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
that's found off the coast of California.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
And while that's an absolutely fascinating sound,

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
it actually turns out to be a very difficult project.

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:52.958
And while I was struggling to figure out how and why mantis shrimp,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:56.958
or stomatopods, make sound, I started to think about their appendages.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
And mantis shrimp are called "mantis shrimp" after the praying mantises,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:03.958
which also have a fast feeding appendage. And I started to think,

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
well, maybe it will be interesting, while listening to their sounds,

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
to figure out how these animals generate very fast feeding strikes.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:13.958
And so today I'll talk about the extreme stomatopod strike,

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
work that I've done in collaboration with Wyatt Korff and Roy Caldwell.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
So, mantis shrimp come in two varieties:

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
there are spearers and smashers.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
And this is a spearing mantis shrimp, or stomatopod.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:29.958
And he lives in the sand, and he catches things that go by overhead.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:34.958
So, a quick strike like that. And if we slow it down a bit,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
this is the mantis shrimp -- the same species --

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
recorded at 1,000 frames a second,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
played back at 15 frames per second.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:46.958
And you can see it's just a really spectacular extension of the limbs,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
exploding upward to actually just catch

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
a dead piece of shrimp that I had offered it.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:56.958
Now, the other type of mantis shrimp is the smasher stomatopod,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
and these guys open up snails for a living.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:04.958
And so this guy gets the snail all set up and gives it a good whack.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:05.958
(Laughter)

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
So, I'll play it one more time.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:11.958
He wiggles it in place, tugs it with his nose, and smash.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:18.958
And a few smashes later, the snail is broken open, and he's got a good dinner.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:22.958
So, the smasher raptorial appendage can stab with a point at the end,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
or it can smash with the heel.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
And today I'll talk about the smashing type of strike.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
And so the first question that came to mind was,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
well, how fast does this limb move?

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
Because it's moving pretty darn fast on that video.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
And I immediately came upon a problem.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
Every single high-speed video system in the biology department

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:45.958
at Berkeley wasn't fast enough to catch this movement.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
We simply couldn't capture it on video.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
And so this had me stymied for quite a long period of time.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
And then a BBC crew came cruising through the biology department,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:58.958
looking for a story to do about new technologies in biology.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
And so we struck up a deal.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
I said, "Well, if you guys rent the high-speed video system

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
that could capture these movements,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
you guys can film us collecting the data."

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
And believe it or not, they went for it. (Laughter)

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:13.958
So we got this incredible video system. It's very new technology --

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
it just came out about a year ago --

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:20.958
that allows you to film at extremely high speeds in low light.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
And low light is a critical issue with filming animals,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
because if it's too high, you fry them. (Laughter)

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:30.958
So this is a mantis shrimp. There are the eyes up here,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
and there's that raptorial appendage, and there's the heel.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
And that thing's going to swing around and smash the snail.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:37.958
And the snail's wired to a stick,

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:41.958
so he's a little bit easier to set up the shot. And -- yeah.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
(Laughter)

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
I hope there aren't any snail rights activists around here.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
(Laughter)

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:53.958
So this was filmed at 5,000 frames per second,

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and I'm playing it back at 15. And so this is slowed down 333 times.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
And as you'll notice, it's still pretty gosh darn fast

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
slowed down 333 times. It's an incredibly powerful movement.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
The whole limb extends out. The body flexes backwards --

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
just a spectacular movement.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
And so what we did is, we took a look at these videos,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
and we measured how fast the limb was moving

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
to get back to that original question.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
And we were in for our first surprise.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
So what we calculated was that the limbs were moving

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
at the peak speed ranging from 10 meters per second

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
all the way up to 23 meters per second.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
And for those of you who prefer miles per hour,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:34.958
that's over 45 miles per hour in water. And this is really darn fast.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
In fact, it's so fast we were able to add a new point

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
on the extreme animal movement spectrum.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
And mantis shrimp are officially the fastest measured feeding strike

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:48.958
of any animal system. So our first surprise.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:49.958
(Applause)

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
So that was really cool and very unexpected.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
So, you might be wondering, well, how do they do it?

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
And actually, this work was done in the 1960s

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
by a famous biologist named Malcolm Burrows.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And what he showed in mantis shrimp is that they use

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
what's called a "catch mechanism," or "click mechanism."

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
And what this basically consists of is a large muscle

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
that takes a good long time to contract,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
and a latch that prevents anything from moving.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
So the muscle contracts, and nothing happens.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
And once the muscle's contracted completely, everything's stored up --

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
the latch flies upward, and you've got the movement.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
And that's basically what's called a "power amplification system."

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
It takes a long time for the muscle to contract,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
and a very short time for the limb to fly out.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
And so I thought that this was sort of the end of the story.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
This was how mantis shrimps make these very fast strikes.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
But then I took a trip to the National Museum of Natural History.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
And if any of you ever have a chance,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
backstage of the National Museum of Natural History

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:50.958
is one of the world's best collections of preserved mantis shrimp. And what --

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:51.958
(Laughter)

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
this is serious business for me.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:54.958
(Laughter)

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:59.958
So, this -- what I saw, on every single mantis shrimp limb,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
whether it's a spearer or a smasher,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
is a beautiful saddle-shaped structure

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:07.958
right on the top surface of the limb. And you can see it right here.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
It just looks like a saddle you'd put on a horse.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
It's a very beautiful structure.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:16.958
And it's surrounded by membranous areas. And those membranous areas

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
suggested to me that maybe this is some kind of dynamically flexible structure.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
And this really sort of had me scratching my head for a while.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And then we did a series of calculations, and what we were able to show

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:31.958
is that these mantis shrimp have to have a spring.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
There needs to be some kind of spring-loaded mechanism

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
in order to generate the amount of force that we observe,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
and the speed that we observe, and the output of the system.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
So we thought, OK, this must be a spring --

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
the saddle could very well be a spring.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And we went back to those high-speed videos again,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and we could actually visualize the saddle compressing and extending.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
And I'll just do that one more time.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
And then if you take a look at the video --

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
it's a little bit hard to see -- it's outlined in yellow.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
The saddle is outlined in yellow. You can actually see it

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
extending over the course of the strike, and actually hyperextending.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
So, we've had very solid evidence showing

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.958
that that saddle-shaped structure actually compresses and extends,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
and does, in fact, function as a spring.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:18.958
The saddle-shaped structure is also known as a "hyperbolic paraboloid surface,"

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
or an "anticlastic surface."

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
And this is very well known to engineers and architects,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
because it's a very strong surface in compression.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
It has curves in two directions,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
one curve upward and opposite transverse curve down the other,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
so any kind of perturbation spreads the forces

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
over the surface of this type of shape.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.958
So it's very well known to engineers, not as well known to biologists.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
It's also known to quite a few people who make jewelry,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
because it requires very little material

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
to build this type of surface, and it's very strong.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
So if you're going to build a thin gold structure,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
it's very nice to have it in a shape that's strong.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:59.958
Now, it's also known to architects. One of the most famous architects

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
is Eduardo Catalano, who popularized this structure.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
And what's shown here is a saddle-shaped roof that he built

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
that's 87 and a half feet spanwise.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
It's two and a half inches thick, and supported at two points.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
And one of the reasons why he designed roofs this way is because it's --

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:21.958
he found it fascinating that you could build such a strong structure

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:25.958
that's made of so few materials and can be supported by so few points.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
And all of these are the same principles that apply

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
to the saddle-shaped spring in stomatopods.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
In biological systems it's important not to have a whole lot

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
of extra material requirements for building it.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
So, very interesting parallels between the biological

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and the engineering worlds. And interestingly, this turns out --

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
the stomatopod saddle turns out to be the first

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
described biological hyperbolic paraboloid spring.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
That's a bit long, but it is sort of interesting.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
So the next and final question was, well, how much force

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:59.958
does a mantis shrimp produce if they're able to break open snails?

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
And so I wired up what's called a load cell.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
A load cell measures forces, and this is actually

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
a piezoelectronic load cell that has a little crystal in it.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
And when this crystal is squeezed, the electrical properties change

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
and it -- which -- in proportion to the forces that go in.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
So these animals are wonderfully aggressive,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
and are really hungry all the time. And so all I had to do

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
was actually put a little shrimp paste on the front of the load cell,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
and they'd smash away at it.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
And so this is just a regular video of the animal

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
just smashing the heck out of this load cell.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And we were able to get some force measurements out.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And again, we were in for a surprise.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
I purchased a 100-pound load cell, thinking,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:41.958
no animal could produce more than 100 pounds at this size of an animal.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
And what do you know? They immediately overloaded the load cell.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
So these are actually some old data

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
where I had to find the smallest animals in the lab,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
and we were able to measure forces of well over 100 pounds

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
generated by an animal about this big.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
And actually, just last week I got a 300-pound load cell

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
up and running, and I've clocked these animals generating

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
well over 200 pounds of force.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
And again, I think this will be a world record.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
I have to do a little bit more background reading,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
but I think this will be the largest amount of force produced

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:13.958
by an animal of a given -- per body mass. So, really incredible forces.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
And again, that brings us back to the importance of that spring

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
in storing up and releasing so much energy in this system.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
But that was not the end of the story.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
Now, things -- I'm making this sound very easy, this is actually a lot of work.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
And I got all these force measurements,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:31.958
and then I went and looked at the force output of the system.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And this is just very simple -- time is on the X-axis

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
and the force is on the Y-axis. And you can see two peaks.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:41.958
And that was what really got me puzzled.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
The first peak, obviously, is the limb hitting the load cell.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:50.958
But there's a really large second peak half a millisecond later,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and I didn't know what that was.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
So now, you'd expect a second peak for other reasons,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
but not half a millisecond later.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
Again, going back to those high-speed videos,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
there's a pretty good hint of what might be going on.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
Here's that same orientation that we saw earlier.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
There's that raptorial appendage -- there's the heel,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
and it's going to swing around and hit the load cell.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
And what I'd like you to do in this shot is keep your eye on this,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:19.958
on the surface of the load cell, as the limb comes flying through.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:24.958
And I hope what you are able to see is actually a flash of light.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
Audience: Wow.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
Sheila Patek: And so if we just take that one frame, what you can actually see there

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
at the end of that yellow arrow is a vapor bubble.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
And what that is, is cavitation.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
And cavitation is an extremely potent fluid dynamic phenomenon

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
which occurs when you have areas of water

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
moving at extremely different speeds.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:48.958
And when this happens, it can cause areas of very low pressure,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
which results in the water literally vaporizing.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
And when that vapor bubble collapses, it emits sound, light and heat,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
and it's a very destructive process.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:02.958
And so here it is in the stomatopod. And again, this is a situation

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
where engineers are very familiar with this phenomenon,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
because it destroys boat propellers.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
People have been struggling for years to try and design

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
a very fast rotating boat propeller that doesn't cavitate

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
and literally wear away the metal and put holes in it,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
just like these pictures show.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:27.958
So this is a potent force in fluid systems, and just to sort of take it one step further,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
I'm going to show you the mantis shrimp approaching the snail.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:34.958
This is taken at 20,000 frames per second, and I have to give

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
full credit to the BBC cameraman, Tim Green, for setting this shot up,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
because I could never have done this in a million years --

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
one of the benefits of working with professional cameramen.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
You can see it coming in, and an incredible flash of light,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
and all this cavitation spreading over the surface of the snail.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
So really, just an amazing image,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:59.958
slowed down extremely, to extremely slow speeds.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
And again, we can see it in slightly different form there,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:06.958
with the bubble forming and collapsing between those two surfaces.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:11.958
In fact, you might have even seen some cavitation going up the edge of the limb.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
So to solve this quandary of the two force peaks:

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
what I think was going on is: that first impact is actually

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
the limb hitting the load cell, and the second impact is actually

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
the collapse of the cavitation bubble.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
And these animals may very well be making use of

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
not only the force and the energy stored with that specialized spring,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
but the extremes of the fluid dynamics. And they might actually be

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
making use of fluid dynamics as a second force for breaking the snail.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:42.958
So, really fascinating double whammy, so to speak, from these animals.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
So, one question I often get after this talk --

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
so I figured I'd answer it now -- is, well, what happens to the animal?

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Because obviously, if it's breaking snails,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
the poor limb must be disintegrating. And indeed it does.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
That's the smashing part of the heel on both these images,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
and it gets worn away. In fact, I've seen them wear away

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
their heel all the way to the flesh.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
But one of the convenient things about being an arthropod

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
is that you have to molt. And every three months or so

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:11.958
these animals molt, and they build a new limb and it's no problem.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:15.958
Very, very convenient solution to that particular problem.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:20.958
So, I'd like to end on sort of a wacky note.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
(Laughter)

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:27.958
Maybe this is all wacky to folks like you, I don't know.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:28.958
(Laughter)

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
So, the saddles -- that saddle-shaped spring --

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:35.958
has actually been well known to biologists for a long time,

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:39.958
not as a spring but as a visual signal.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
And there's actually a spectacular colored dot

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:47.958
in the center of the saddles of many species of stomatopods.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
And this is quite interesting, to find evolutionary origins

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:56.958
of visual signals on what's really, in all species, their spring.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
And I think one explanation for this could be

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
going back to the molting phenomenon.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
So these animals go into a molting period where they're

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
unable to strike -- their bodies become very soft.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
And they're literally unable to strike or they will self-destruct.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:16.958
This is for real. And what they do is, up until that time period

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
when they can't strike, they become really obnoxious and awful,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and they strike everything in sight; it doesn't matter who or what.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:27.958
And the second they get into that time point when they can't strike any more,

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
they just signal. They wave their legs around.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:34.958
And it's one of the classic examples in animal behavior of bluffing.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
It's a well-established fact of these animals

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:40.958
that they actually bluff. They can't actually strike, but they pretend to.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
And so I'm very curious about whether those colored dots

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:46.958
in the center of the saddles are conveying some kind of information

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
about their ability to strike, or their strike force,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
and something about the time period in the molting cycle.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:57.958
So sort of an interesting strange fact to find a visual structure

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
right in the middle of their spring.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:05.958
So to conclude, I mostly want to acknowledge my two collaborators,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
Wyatt Korff and Roy Caldwell, who worked closely with me on this.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
And also the Miller Institute for Basic Research in Science,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:15.958
which gave me three years of funding to just do science all the time,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
and for that I'm very grateful. Thank you very much.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:19.958
(Applause)
