title: The illusion of consciousness
transcript: So I'm going to speak about a problem that I have and that's that I'm a philosopher.(Laughter)When I go to a party and people ask me what do I do and I say, "I'm a professor," their eyes glaze over. When I go to an academic cocktail party and there are all the professors around, they ask me what field I'm in and I say, "philosophy" — their eyes glaze over.(Laughter)When I go to a philosopher's party(Laughter)and they ask me what I work on and I say, "consciousness," their eyes don't glaze over — their lips curl into a snarl.(Laughter)And I get hoots of derision and cackles and growls because they think, "That's impossible! You can't explain consciousness." The very chutzpah of somebody thinking that you could explain consciousness is just out of the question.My late, lamented friend Bob Nozick, a fine philosopher, in one of his books, "Philosophical Explanations," is commenting on the ethos of philosophy — the way philosophers go about their business. And he says, you know, "Philosophers love rational argument." And he says, "It seems as if the ideal argument for most philosophers is you give your audience the premises and then you give them the inferences and the conclusion, and if they don't accept the conclusion, they die. Their heads explode." The idea is to have an argument that is so powerful that it knocks out your opponents. But in fact that doesn't change people's minds at all.It's very hard to change people's minds about something like consciousness, and I finally figured out the reason for that. The reason for that is that everybody's an expert on consciousness. We heard the other day that everybody's got a strong opinion about video games. They all have an idea for a video game, even if they're not experts. But they don't consider themselves experts on video games; they've just got strong opinions. I'm sure that people here who work on, say, climate change and global warming, or on the future of the Internet, encounter people who have very strong opinions about what's going to happen next. But they probably don't think of these opinions as expertise. They're just strongly held opinions. But with regard to consciousness, people seem to think, each of us seems to think, "I am an expert. Simply by being conscious, I know all about this." And so, you tell them your theory and they say, "No, no, that's not the way consciousness is! No, you've got it all wrong." And they say this with an amazing confidence.And so what I'm going to try to do today is to shake your confidence. Because I know the feeling — I can feel it myself. I want to shake your confidence that you know your own innermost minds — that you are, yourselves, authoritative about your own consciousness. That's the order of the day here.Now, this nice picture shows a thought-balloon, a thought-bubble. I think everybody understands what that means. That's supposed to exhibit the stream of consciousness. This is my favorite picture of consciousness that's ever been done. It's a Saul Steinberg of course — it was a New Yorker cover. And this fellow here is looking at the painting by Braque. That reminds him of the word baroque, barrack, bark, poodle, Suzanne R. — he's off to the races. There's a wonderful stream of consciousness here and if you follow it along, you learn a lot about this man. What I particularly like about this picture, too, is that Steinberg has rendered the guy in this sort of pointillist style.Which reminds us, as Rod Brooks was saying yesterday: what we are, what each of us is — what you are, what I am — is approximately 100 trillion little cellular robots. That's what we're made of. No other ingredients at all. We're just made of cells, about 100 trillion of them. Not a single one of those cells is conscious; not a single one of those cells knows who you are, or cares. Somehow, we have to explain how when you put together teams, armies, battalions of hundreds of millions of little robotic unconscious cells — not so different really from a bacterium, each one of them — the result is this. I mean, just look at it. The content — there's color, there's ideas, there's memories, there's history. And somehow all that content of consciousness is accomplished by the busy activity of those hoards of neurons. How is that possible? Many people just think it isn't possible at all. They think, "No, there can't be any sort of naturalistic explanation of consciousness."This is a lovely book by a friend of mine named Lee Siegel, who's a professor of religion, actually, at the University of Hawaii, and he's an expert magician, and an expert on the street magic of India, which is what this book is about, "Net of Magic." And there's a passage in it which I would love to share with you. It speaks so eloquently to the problem. "'I'm writing a book on magic,' I explain, and I'm asked, 'Real magic?' By 'real magic,' people mean miracles, thaumaturgical acts, and supernatural powers. 'No,' I answer. 'Conjuring tricks, not real magic.' 'Real magic,' in other words, refers to the magic that is not real; while the magic that is real, that can actually be done, is not real magic."(Laughter)Now, that's the way a lot of people feel about consciousness.(Laughter)Real consciousness is not a bag of tricks. If you're going to explain this as a bag of tricks, then it's not real consciousness, whatever it is. And, as Marvin said, and as other people have said, "Consciousness is a bag of tricks." This means that a lot of people are just left completely dissatisfied and incredulous when I attempt to explain consciousness. So this is the problem. So I have to do a little bit of the sort of work that a lot of you won't like, for the same reason that you don't like to see a magic trick explained to you. How many of you here, if somebody — some smart aleck — starts telling you how a particular magic trick is done, you sort of want to block your ears and say, "No, no, I don't want to know! Don't take the thrill of it away. I'd rather be mystified. Don't tell me the answer." A lot of people feel that way about consciousness, I've discovered. And I'm sorry if I impose some clarity, some understanding on you. You'd better leave now if you don't want to know some of these tricks.But I'm not going to explain it all to you. I'm going to do what philosophers do. Here's how a philosopher explains the sawing-the-lady-in-half trick. You know the sawing-the-lady-in-half trick? The philosopher says, "I'm going to explain to you how that's done. You see, the magician doesn't really saw the lady in half."(Laughter)"He merely makes you think that he does." And you say, "Yes, and how does he do that?" He says, "Oh, that's not my department, I'm sorry."(Laughter)So now I'm going to illustrate how philosophers explain consciousness. But I'm going to try to also show you that consciousness isn't quite as marvelous — your own consciousness isn't quite as wonderful — as you may have thought it is. This is something, by the way, that Lee Siegel talks about in his book. He marvels at how he'll do a magic show, and afterwards people will swear they saw him do X, Y, and Z. He never did those things. He didn't even try to do those things. People's memories inflate what they think they saw. And the same is true of consciousness.Now, let's see if this will work. All right. Let's just watch this. Watch it carefully. I'm working with a young computer-animator documentarian named Nick Deamer, and this is a little demo that he's done for me, part of a larger project some of you may be interested in. We're looking for a backer. It's a feature-length documentary on consciousness. OK, now, you all saw what changed, right? How many of you noticed that every one of those squares changed color? Every one. I'll just show you by running it again. Even when you know that they're all going to change color, it's very hard to notice. You have to really concentrate to pick up any of the changes at all.Now, this is an example — one of many — of a phenomenon that's now being studied quite a bit. It's one that I predicted in the last page or two of my 1991 book, "Consciousness Explained," where I said if you did experiments of this sort, you'd find that people were unable to pick up really large changes. If there's time at the end, I'll show you the much more dramatic case. Now, how can it be that there are all those changes going on, and that we're not aware of them? Well, earlier today, Jeff Hawkins mentioned the way your eye saccades, the way your eye moves around three or four times a second. He didn't mention the speed. Your eye is constantly in motion, moving around, looking at eyes, noses, elbows, looking at interesting things in the world. And where your eye isn't looking, you're remarkably impoverished in your vision. That's because the foveal part of your eye, which is the high-resolution part, is only about the size of your thumbnail held at arms length. That's the detail part. It doesn't seem that way, does it? It doesn't seem that way, but that's the way it is. You're getting in a lot less information than you think.Here's a completely different effect. This is a painting by Bellotto. It's in the museum in North Carolina. Bellotto was a student of Canaletto's. And I love paintings like that — the painting is actually about as big as it is right here. And I love Canalettos, because Canaletto has this fantastic detail, and you can get right up and see all the details on the painting. And I started across the hall in North Carolina, because I thought it was probably a Canaletto, and would have all that in detail. And I noticed that on the bridge there, there's a lot of people — you can just barely see them walking across the bridge. And I thought as I got closer I would be able to see all the detail of most people, see their clothes, and so forth. And as I got closer and closer, I actually screamed. I yelled out because when I got closer, I found the detail wasn't there at all. There were just little artfully placed blobs of paint. And as I walked towards the picture, I was expecting detail that wasn't there. The artist had very cleverly suggested people and clothes and wagons and all sorts of things, and my brain had taken the suggestion.You're familiar with a more recent technology, which is — There, you can get a better view of the blobs. See, when you get close they're really just blobs of paint. You will have seen something like this — this is the reverse effect. I'll just give that to you one more time.Now, what does your brain do when it takes the suggestion? When an artful blob of paint or two, by an artist, suggests a person — say, one of Marvin Minsky's little society of mind — do they send little painters out to fill in all the details in your brain somewhere? I don't think so. Not a chance. But then, how on Earth is it done? Well, remember the philosopher's explanation of the lady? It's the same thing. The brain just makes you think that it's got the detail there. You think the detail's there, but it isn't there. The brain isn't actually putting the detail in your head at all. It's just making you expect the detail.Let's just do this experiment very quickly. Is the shape on the left the same as the shape on the right, rotated? Yes. How many of you did it by rotating the one on the left in your mind's eye, to see if it matched up with the one on the right? How many of you rotated the one on the right? OK. How do you know that's what you did?(Laughter)There's in fact been a very interesting debate raging for over 20 years in cognitive science — various experiments started by Roger Shepherd, who measured the angular velocity of rotation of mental images. Yes, it's possible to do that. But the details of the process are still in significant controversy. And if you read that literature, one of the things that you really have to come to terms with is even when you're the subject in the experiment, you don't know. You don't know how you do it. You just know that you have certain beliefs. And they come in a certain order, at a certain time. And what explains the fact that that's what you think? Well, that's where you have to go backstage and ask the magician.This is a figure that I love: Bradley, Petrie, and Dumais. You may think that I've cheated, that I've put a little whiter-than-white boundary there. How many of you see that sort of boundary, with the Necker cube floating in front of the circles? Can you see it? Well, you know, in effect, the boundary's really there, in a certain sense. Your brain is actually computing that boundary, the boundary that goes right there. But now, notice there are two ways of seeing the cube, right? It's a Necker cube. Everybody can see the two ways of seeing the cube? OK. Can you see the four ways of seeing the cube? Because there's another way of seeing it. If you're seeing it as a cube floating in front of some circles, some black circles, there's another way of seeing it. As a cube, on a black background, as seen through a piece of Swiss cheese.(Laughter)Can you get it? How many of you can't get it? That'll help.(Laughter)Now you can get it. These are two very different phenomena. When you see the cube one way, behind the screen, those boundaries go away. But there's still a sort of filling in, as we can tell if we look at this. We don't have any trouble seeing the cube, but where does the color change? Does your brain have to send little painters in there? The purple-painters and the green-painters fight over who's going to paint that bit behind the curtain? No. Your brain just lets it go. The brain doesn't need to fill that in. When I first started talking about the Bradley, Petrie, Dumais example that you just saw — I'll go back to it, this one — I said that there was no filling-in behind there. And I supposed that that was just a flat truth, always true. But Rob Van Lier has recently shown that it isn't.Now, if you think you see some pale yellow — I'll run this a few more times. Look in the gray areas, and see if you seem to see something sort of shadowy moving in there — yeah, it's amazing. There's nothing there. It's no trick. ["Failure to Detect Changes in Scenes" slide] This is Ron Rensink's work, which was in some degree inspired by that suggestion right at the end of the book. Let me just pause this for a second if I can.This is change-blindness. What you're going to see is two pictures, one of which is slightly different from the other. You see here the red roof and the gray roof, and in between them there will be a mask, which is just a blank screen, for about a quarter of a second. So you'll see the first picture, then a mask, then the second picture, then a mask. And this will just continue, and your job as the subject is to press the button when you see the change. So, show the original picture for 240 milliseconds. Blank. Show the next picture for 240 milliseconds. Blank. And keep going, until the subject presses the button, saying, "I see the change."So now we're going to be subjects in the experiment. We're going to start easy. Some examples. No trouble there. Can everybody see? All right. Indeed, Rensink's subjects took only a little bit more than a second to press the button. Can you see that one? 2.9 seconds. How many don't see it still? What's on the roof of that barn?(Laughter)It's easy. Is it a bridge or a dock? There are a few more really dramatic ones, and then I'll close. I want you to see a few that are particularly striking. This one because it's so large and yet it's pretty hard to see. Can you see it?Audience: Yes.Dan Dennett: See the shadows going back and forth? Pretty big. So 15.5 seconds is the median time for subjects in his experiment there.I love this one. I'll end with this one, just because it's such an obvious and important thing. How many still don't see it? How many still don't see it? How many engines on the wing of that Boeing?(Laughter)Right in the middle of the picture! Thanks very much for your attention. What I wanted to show you is that scientists, using their from-the-outside, third-person methods, can tell you things about your own consciousness that you would never dream of, and that, in fact, you're not the authority on your own consciousness that you think you are. And we're really making a lot of progress on coming up with a theory of mind.Jeff Hawkins, this morning, was describing his attempt to get theory, and a good, big theory, into the neuroscience. And he's right. This is a problem. Harvard Medical School once — I was at a talk — director of the lab said, "In our lab, we have a saying. If you work on one neuron, that's neuroscience. If you work on two neurons, that's psychology."(Laughter)We have to have more theory, and it can come as much from the top down.Thank you very much.(Applause)

WEBVTT

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:15.958
So I'm going to speak about a problem that I have

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958
and that's that I'm a philosopher.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
(Laughter)

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
When I go to a party and people ask me what do I do

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:28.958
and I say, "I'm a professor," their eyes glaze over.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
When I go to an academic cocktail party

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:34.958
and there are all the professors around, they ask me what field I'm in

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
and I say, "philosophy" -- their eyes glaze over.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
(Laughter)

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
When I go to a philosopher's party

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
(Laughter)

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:49.958
and they ask me what I work on and I say, "consciousness,"

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:54.958
their eyes don't glaze over -- their lips curl into a snarl.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:55.958
(Laughter)

00:00:55.958 --> 00:01:01.958
And I get hoots of derision and cackles and growls

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:06.958
because they think, "That's impossible! You can't explain consciousness."

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
The very chutzpah of somebody thinking

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:12.958
that you could explain consciousness is just out of the question.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:16.958
My late, lamented friend Bob Nozick, a fine philosopher,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:20.958
in one of his books, "Philosophical Explanations,"

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:25.958
is commenting on the ethos of philosophy --

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
the way philosophers go about their business.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:31.958
And he says, you know, "Philosophers love rational argument."

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
And he says, "It seems as if the ideal argument

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:39.958
for most philosophers is you give your audience the premises

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and then you give them the inferences and the conclusion,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:48.958
and if they don't accept the conclusion, they die.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
Their heads explode." The idea is to have an argument

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:55.958
that is so powerful that it knocks out your opponents.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
But in fact that doesn't change people's minds at all.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:01:59.958
It's very hard to change people's minds

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
about something like consciousness,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:06.958
and I finally figured out the reason for that.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:10.958
The reason for that is that everybody's an expert on consciousness.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:14.958
We heard the other day that everybody's got a strong opinion about video games.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
They all have an idea for a video game, even if they're not experts.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
But they don't consider themselves experts on video games;

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:21.958
they've just got strong opinions.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:26.958
I'm sure that people here who work on, say, climate change

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:31.958
and global warming, or on the future of the Internet,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
encounter people who have very strong opinions

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.958
about what's going to happen next.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:40.958
But they probably don't think of these opinions as expertise.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
They're just strongly held opinions.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:46.958
But with regard to consciousness, people seem to think,

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
each of us seems to think, "I am an expert.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
Simply by being conscious, I know all about this."

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
And so, you tell them your theory and they say,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:55.958
"No, no, that's not the way consciousness is!

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
No, you've got it all wrong."

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
And they say this with an amazing confidence.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
And so what I'm going to try to do today

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
is to shake your confidence. Because I know the feeling --

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
I can feel it myself.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:14.958
I want to shake your confidence that you know your own innermost minds --

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:19.958
that you are, yourselves, authoritative about your own consciousness.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
That's the order of the day here.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
Now, this nice picture shows a thought-balloon, a thought-bubble.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
I think everybody understands what that means.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
That's supposed to exhibit the stream of consciousness.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
This is my favorite picture of consciousness that's ever been done.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
It's a Saul Steinberg of course -- it was a New Yorker cover.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:40.958
And this fellow here is looking at the painting by Braque.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:44.958
That reminds him of the word baroque, barrack, bark, poodle,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Suzanne R. -- he's off to the races.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:50.958
There's a wonderful stream of consciousness here

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:54.958
and if you follow it along, you learn a lot about this man.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
What I particularly like about this picture, too,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
is that Steinberg has rendered the guy

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
in this sort of pointillist style.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
Which reminds us, as Rod Brooks was saying yesterday:

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:08.958
what we are, what each of us is -- what you are, what I am --

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:14.958
is approximately 100 trillion little cellular robots.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
That's what we're made of.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:20.958
No other ingredients at all. We're just made of cells, about 100 trillion of them.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
Not a single one of those cells is conscious;

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:27.958
not a single one of those cells knows who you are, or cares.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
Somehow, we have to explain

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:33.958
how when you put together teams, armies, battalions

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:37.958
of hundreds of millions of little robotic unconscious cells --

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:41.958
not so different really from a bacterium, each one of them --

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:45.958
the result is this. I mean, just look at it.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:49.958
The content -- there's color, there's ideas, there's memories,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:53.958
there's history. And somehow all that content of consciousness

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:58.958
is accomplished by the busy activity of those hoards of neurons.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.958
How is that possible? Many people just think it isn't possible at all.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
They think, "No, there can't be any

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:08.958
sort of naturalistic explanation of consciousness."

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
This is a lovely book by a friend of mine named Lee Siegel,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
who's a professor of religion, actually, at the University of Hawaii,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
and he's an expert magician, and an expert

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.958
on the street magic of India, which is what this book is about,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
"Net of Magic."

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
And there's a passage in it which I would love to share with you.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:31.958
It speaks so eloquently to the problem.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:36.958
"'I'm writing a book on magic,' I explain, and I'm asked, 'Real magic?'

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
By 'real magic,' people mean miracles,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
thaumaturgical acts, and supernatural powers.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.958
'No,' I answer. 'Conjuring tricks, not real magic.'

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:48.958
'Real magic,' in other words, refers to the magic that is not real;

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:53.958
while the magic that is real, that can actually be done, is not real magic."

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:57.958
(Laughter)

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:01.958
Now, that's the way a lot of people feel about consciousness.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:02.958
(Laughter)

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
Real consciousness is not a bag of tricks.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
If you're going to explain this as a bag of tricks,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
then it's not real consciousness, whatever it is.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And, as Marvin said, and as other people have said,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
"Consciousness is a bag of tricks."

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:23.958
This means that a lot of people are just left completely dissatisfied

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
and incredulous when I attempt to explain consciousness.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
So this is the problem. So I have to

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
do a little bit of the sort of work

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:36.958
that a lot of you won't like,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
for the same reason that you don't like to see

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
a magic trick explained to you.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
How many of you here, if somebody -- some smart aleck --

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
starts telling you how a particular magic trick is done,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
you sort of want to block your ears and say, "No, no, I don't want to know!

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
Don't take the thrill of it away. I'd rather be mystified.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
Don't tell me the answer."

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
A lot of people feel that way about consciousness, I've discovered.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:05.958
And I'm sorry if I impose some clarity, some understanding on you.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:10.958
You'd better leave now if you don't want to know some of these tricks.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
But I'm not going to explain it all to you.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
I'm going to do what philosophers do.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:23.958
Here's how a philosopher explains the sawing-the-lady-in-half trick.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
You know the sawing-the-lady-in-half trick?

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
The philosopher says, "I'm going to explain to you how that's done.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:34.958
You see, the magician doesn't really saw the lady in half."

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
(Laughter)

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.958
"He merely makes you think that he does."

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And you say, "Yes, and how does he do that?"

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
He says, "Oh, that's not my department, I'm sorry."

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:48.958
(Laughter)

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
So now I'm going to illustrate how philosophers explain consciousness.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
But I'm going to try to also show you

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
that consciousness isn't quite as marvelous --

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
your own consciousness isn't quite as wonderful --

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
as you may have thought it is.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
This is something, by the way, that Lee Siegel talks about in his book.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
He marvels at how he'll do a magic show, and afterwards

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
people will swear they saw him do X, Y, and Z. He never did those things.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
He didn't even try to do those things.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
People's memories inflate what they think they saw.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
And the same is true of consciousness.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:29.958
Now, let's see if this will work. All right. Let's just watch this.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:30.958
Watch it carefully.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
I'm working with a young computer-animator documentarian

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:50.958
named Nick Deamer, and this is a little demo that he's done for me,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
part of a larger project some of you may be interested in.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
We're looking for a backer.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
It's a feature-length documentary on consciousness.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
OK, now, you all saw what changed, right?

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:11.958
How many of you noticed that every one of those squares changed color?

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Every one. I'll just show you by running it again.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:25.958
Even when you know that they're all going to change color,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
it's very hard to notice. You have to really concentrate

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
to pick up any of the changes at all.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:37.958
Now, this is an example -- one of many --

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
of a phenomenon that's now being studied quite a bit.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
It's one that I predicted in the last page or two of my

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
1991 book, "Consciousness Explained,"

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
where I said if you did experiments of this sort,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
you'd find that people were unable to pick up really large changes.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
If there's time at the end,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
I'll show you the much more dramatic case.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Now, how can it be that there are all those changes going on,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
and that we're not aware of them?

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:09.958
Well, earlier today, Jeff Hawkins mentioned the way your eye saccades,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
the way your eye moves around three or four times a second.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
He didn't mention the speed. Your eye is constantly in motion,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
moving around, looking at eyes, noses, elbows,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
looking at interesting things in the world.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And where your eye isn't looking,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
you're remarkably impoverished in your vision.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
That's because the foveal part of your eye,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
which is the high-resolution part,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
is only about the size of your thumbnail held at arms length.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
That's the detail part.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
It doesn't seem that way, does it?

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
It doesn't seem that way, but that's the way it is.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:44.958
You're getting in a lot less information than you think.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:50.958
Here's a completely different effect. This is a painting by Bellotto.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
It's in the museum in North Carolina.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Bellotto was a student of Canaletto's.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:56.958
And I love paintings like that --

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
the painting is actually about as big as it is right here.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And I love Canalettos, because Canaletto has this fantastic detail,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and you can get right up

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
and see all the details on the painting.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:14.958
And I started across the hall in North Carolina,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
because I thought it was probably a Canaletto,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and would have all that in detail.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And I noticed that on the bridge there, there's a lot of people --

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
you can just barely see them walking across the bridge.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:25.958
And I thought as I got closer

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
I would be able to see all the detail of most people,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
see their clothes, and so forth.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
And as I got closer and closer, I actually screamed.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
I yelled out because when I got closer,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
I found the detail wasn't there at all.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:44.958
There were just little artfully placed blobs of paint.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
And as I walked towards the picture,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
I was expecting detail that wasn't there.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:55.958
The artist had very cleverly suggested people and clothes

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and wagons and all sorts of things,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
and my brain had taken the suggestion.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:07.958
You're familiar with a more recent technology, which is -- There,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
you can get a better view of the blobs.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
See, when you get close

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:16.958
they're really just blobs of paint.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:22.958
You will have seen something like this -- this is the reverse effect.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
I'll just give that to you one more time.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:40.958
Now, what does your brain do when it takes the suggestion?

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:45.958
When an artful blob of paint or two, by an artist,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:51.958
suggests a person -- say, one of

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
Marvin Minsky's little society of mind --

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:58.958
do they send little painters out to fill in all the details in your brain somewhere?

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:03.958
I don't think so. Not a chance. But then, how on Earth is it done?

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Well, remember the philosopher's explanation of the lady?

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
It's the same thing.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
The brain just makes you think that it's got the detail there.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
You think the detail's there, but it isn't there.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
The brain isn't actually putting the detail in your head at all.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
It's just making you expect the detail.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Let's just do this experiment very quickly.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Is the shape on the left the same as the shape on the right, rotated?

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
Yes.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
How many of you did it by rotating the one on the left

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
in your mind's eye, to see if it matched up with the one on the right?

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
How many of you rotated the one on the right? OK.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
How do you know that's what you did?

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
(Laughter)

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
There's in fact been a very interesting debate

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
raging for over 20 years in cognitive science --

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
various experiments started by Roger Shepherd,

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:59.958
who measured the angular velocity of rotation of mental images.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
Yes, it's possible to do that.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:08.958
But the details of the process are still in significant controversy.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
And if you read that literature, one of the things

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
that you really have to come to terms with is

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
even when you're the subject in the experiment, you don't know.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
You don't know how you do it.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
You just know that you have certain beliefs.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
And they come in a certain order, at a certain time.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
And what explains the fact that that's what you think?

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:30.958
Well, that's where you have to go backstage and ask the magician.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
This is a figure that I love: Bradley, Petrie, and Dumais.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
You may think that I've cheated,

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:41.958
that I've put a little whiter-than-white boundary there.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
How many of you see that sort of boundary,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
with the Necker cube floating in front of the circles?

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
Can you see it?

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:53.958
Well, you know, in effect, the boundary's really there, in a certain sense.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Your brain is actually computing that boundary,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:01.958
the boundary that goes right there.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
But now, notice there are two ways of seeing the cube, right?

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
It's a Necker cube.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:09.958
Everybody can see the two ways of seeing the cube? OK.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
Can you see the four ways of seeing the cube?

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
Because there's another way of seeing it.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
If you're seeing it as a cube floating in front of some circles,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
some black circles, there's another way of seeing it.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
As a cube, on a black background,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
as seen through a piece of Swiss cheese.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
(Laughter)

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:34.958
Can you get it? How many of you can't get it? That'll help.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
(Laughter)

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Now you can get it. These are two very different phenomena.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:47.958
When you see the cube one way, behind the screen,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
those boundaries go away.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:54.958
But there's still a sort of filling in, as we can tell if we look at this.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:58.958
We don't have any trouble seeing the cube, but where does the color change?

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
Does your brain have to send little painters in there?

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
The purple-painters and the green-painters

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
fight over who's going to paint that bit behind the curtain? No.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
Your brain just lets it go. The brain doesn't need to fill that in.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
When I first started talking about

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.958
the Bradley, Petrie, Dumais example that you just saw --

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
I'll go back to it, this one --

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:33.958
I said that there was no filling-in behind there.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
And I supposed that that was just a flat truth, always true.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:41.958
But Rob Van Lier has recently shown that it isn't.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:46.958
Now, if you think you see some pale yellow --

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
I'll run this a few more times.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:52.958
Look in the gray areas,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:57.958
and see if you seem to see something sort of shadowy moving in there --

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:04.958
yeah, it's amazing. There's nothing there. It's no trick.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:10.958
["Failure to Detect Changes in Scenes" slide]

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
This is Ron Rensink's work, which was in some degree

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:16.958
inspired by that suggestion right at the end of the book.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
Let me just pause this for a second if I can.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
This is change-blindness.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
What you're going to see is two pictures,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
one of which is slightly different from the other.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
You see here the red roof and the gray roof,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
and in between them there will be a mask,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:33.958
which is just a blank screen, for about a quarter of a second.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
So you'll see the first picture, then a mask,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
then the second picture, then a mask.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:41.958
And this will just continue, and your job as the subject

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
is to press the button when you see the change.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:52.958
So, show the original picture for 240 milliseconds. Blank.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:58.958
Show the next picture for 240 milliseconds. Blank.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:02.958
And keep going, until the subject presses the button, saying,

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
"I see the change."

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.958
So now we're going to be subjects in the experiment.

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:16.958
We're going to start easy. Some examples.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
No trouble there.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
Can everybody see? All right.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:25.958
Indeed, Rensink's subjects took only a little bit more

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
than a second to press the button.

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:33.958
Can you see that one?

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
2.9 seconds.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
How many don't see it still?

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:55.958
What's on the roof of that barn?

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:58.958
(Laughter)

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
It's easy.

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:34.958
Is it a bridge or a dock?

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:42.958
There are a few more really dramatic ones, and then I'll close.

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:46.958
I want you to see a few that are particularly striking.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:53.958
This one because it's so large and yet it's pretty hard to see.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:56.958
Can you see it?

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:58.958
Audience: Yes.

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:01.958
Dan Dennett: See the shadows going back and forth? Pretty big.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:13.958
So 15.5 seconds is the median time

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:15.958
for subjects in his experiment there.

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:18.958
I love this one. I'll end with this one,

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:21.958
just because it's such an obvious and important thing.

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:29.958
How many still don't see it? How many still don't see it?

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:32.958
How many engines on the wing of that Boeing?

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:33.958
(Laughter)

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:39.958
Right in the middle of the picture!

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:40.958
Thanks very much for your attention.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:45.958
What I wanted to show you is that scientists,

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:49.958
using their from-the-outside, third-person methods,

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:51.958
can tell you things about your own consciousness

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:53.958
that you would never dream of,

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:55.958
and that, in fact, you're not the authority

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:57.958
on your own consciousness that you think you are.

00:20:57.958 --> 00:20:59.958
And we're really making a lot of progress

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:02.958
on coming up with a theory of mind.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:08.958
Jeff Hawkins, this morning, was describing his attempt

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:12.958
to get theory, and a good, big theory, into the neuroscience.

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:17.958
And he's right. This is a problem.

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:19.958
Harvard Medical School once -- I was at a talk --

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:23.958
director of the lab said, "In our lab, we have a saying.

00:21:23.958 --> 00:21:26.958
If you work on one neuron, that's neuroscience.

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:29.958
If you work on two neurons, that's psychology."

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:33.958
(Laughter)

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
We have to have more theory, and it can come as much from the top down.

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:38.958
Thank you very much.

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:42.958
(Applause)

title: How to truly listen
transcript: I'm not quite sure whether I really want to see a snare drum at nine o'clock or so in the morning.(Laughter)But anyway, it's just great to see such a full theater, and really, I must thank Herbie Hancock and his colleagues for such a great presentation.(Applause)One of the interesting things, of course, is the combination of that raw hand on the instrument and technology, and what he said about listening to our young people.Of course, my job is all about listening. And my aim, really, is to teach the world to listen. That's my only real aim in life. And it sounds quite simple, but actually, it's quite a big, big job. Because you know, when you look at a piece of music, for example, if I just open my little motorbike bag — we have here, hopefully, a piece of music that is full of little black dots on the page. And, you know, we open it up ... And I read the music. So technically, I can actually read this. I will follow the instructions, the tempo markings, the dynamics. I will do exactly as I'm told. And so therefore, because time is short, if I just played you, literally, the first, maybe, two lines or so — It's very straightforward; there's nothing too difficult about the piece. But here, I'm being told that the piece of music is very quick. I'm being told where to play on the drum. I'm being told which part of the stick to use. And I'm being told the dynamic. And I'm also being told that the drum is without snares. Snares on, snares off. So therefore, if I translate this piece of music, we have this idea.(Drum sounds)(Drum sounds end)And so on. My career would probably last about five years.(Laughter)However, what I have to do as a musician is do everything that is not on the music; everything that there isn't time to learn from a teacher, or to talk about, even, from a teacher. But it's the things you notice when you're not actually with your instrument that, in fact, become so interesting, and that you want to explore through this tiny, tiny surface of a drum. So there, we experience the translation. Now we'll experience the interpretation.(Drum sounds)(Drum sounds end)(Applause)Now my career may last a little longer.(Laughter)But in a way, you know, it's the same if I look at you and I see a nice, bright young lady with a pink top on. I see that you're clutching a teddy bear, etc., etc. So I get a basic idea as to what you might be about, what you might like, what you might do as a profession, etc., etc. However, that's just the initial idea I may have that we all get when we actually look and we try to interpret. But actually it's so unbelievably shallow. In the same way, I look at the music; I get a basic idea; I wonder what technically might be hard, or, you know, what I want to do. Just the basic feeling.However, that is simply not enough. And I think what Herbie said: please listen, listen. We have to listen to ourselves, first of all. If I play, for example, holding the stick — where literally I do not let go of the stick —(Drum sound)you'll experience quite a lot of shock coming up through the arm. And you feel really quite — believe it or not — detached from the instrument and from the stick, even though I'm actually holding the stick quite tightly.(Drum sound)By holding it tightly, I feel strangely more detached. If I just simply let go and allow my hand, my arm, to be more of a support system, suddenly —(Drum sound)I have more dynamic with less effort. Much more —(Drum sound)and I just feel, at last, one with the stick and one with the drum. And I'm doing far, far less.So in the same way that I need time with this instrument, I need time with people in order to interpret them. Not just translate them, but interpret them. If, for example, I play just a few bars of a piece of music for which I think of myself as a technician — that is, someone who is basically a percussion player —(Marimba sounds)(Marimba sounds end)And so on, if I think of myself as a musician —(Marimba sounds)(Marimba sounds end)And so on. There is a little bit of a difference there that is worth just —(Applause)thinking about.And I remember when I was 12 years old, and I started playing timpani and percussion, and my teacher said, "Well, how are we going to do this? You know, music is about listening." And I said, "Yes, I agree with that, so what's the problem?" And he said, "Well, how are you going to hear this? How are you going to hear that?" And I said, "Well, how do you hear it?" He said, "Well, I think I hear it through here." And I said, "Well, I think I do too, but I also hear it through my hands, through my arms, cheekbones, my scalp, my tummy, my chest, my legs and so on."And so we began our lessons every single time tuning drums, in particular, the kettle drums, or timpani to such a narrow pitch interval, so something like —(Marimba sounds)that of a difference. Then gradually:(Marimba sounds)And gradually:(Marimba sounds)And it's amazing that when you do open your body up, and open your hand up to allow the vibration to come through, that in fact the tiny, tiny difference —(Marimba sounds)can be felt with just the tiniest part of your finger, there.And so what we would do is that I would put my hands on the wall of the music room, and together, we would "listen" to the sounds of the instruments, and really try to connect with those sounds far, far more broadly than simply depending on the ear. Because of course, the ear is subject to all sorts of things. The room we happen to be in, the amplification, the quality of the instrument, the type of sticks —(Marimba sounds)(Marimba sounds end)Etc., etc., they're all different.(Marimba sounds)(Marimba sounds end)Same amount of weight, but different sound colors. And that's basically what we are; we're just human beings, but we all have our own little sound colors, as it were, that make up these extraordinary personalities and characters and interests and things.And as I grew older, I then auditioned for the Royal Academy of Music in London, and they said, "Well, no, we won't accept you, because we haven't a clue, you know, of the future of a so-called 'deaf musician.'" And I just couldn't quite accept that. And so therefore, I said to them, "Well, look, if you refuse — if you refuse me through those reasons, as opposed to the ability to perform and to understand and love the art of creating sound — then we have to think very, very hard about the people you do actually accept." And as a result, once we got over a little hurdle, and having to audition twice, they accepted me. And not only that, what had happened was that it changed the whole role of the music institutions throughout the United Kingdom.Under no circumstances were they to refuse any application whatsoever on the basis of whether someone had no arms, no legs — they could still perhaps play a wind instrument if it was supported on a stand. No circumstances at all were used to refuse any entry. And every single entry had to be listened to, experienced, and then, based on the musical ability, then that person could either enter or not. And so therefore, this in turn meant that there was an extremely interesting bunch of students who arrived in these various music institutions, and I have to say, many of them now in the professional orchestras throughout the world. The interesting thing about this as well, though —(Applause)is quite simply that not only were people connected with sound — which is basically all of us — we well know that music really is our daily medicine.I say "music," but actually I mean "sound." Because some of the extraordinary things I've experienced as a musician — when you may have a 15-year-old lad who has got the most incredible challenges, who may not be able to control his movements, who may be deaf, who may be blind, etc., etc. — suddenly, if that young lad sits close to this instrument, and perhaps even lies underneath the marimba, and you play something that's so incredibly organ-like, almost — I don't really have the right sticks, perhaps — but something like this — let me change —(Soft marimba sounds)(Soft marimba sounds end)Something that's so unbelievably simple — but he would be experiencing something that I wouldn't be, because I'm on top of the sound. I have the sound coming this way. He would have the sound coming through the resonators. If there were no resonators on here, we would have:(Marimba sounds)So he would have a fullness of sound that those of you in the front few rows wouldn't experience, those of you in the back few rows wouldn't experience, either. Every single one of us, depending on where we're sitting, will experience this sound quite, quite differently. And of course, being the participator of the sound, and that is, starting from the idea of what type of sound I want to produce, for example, this sound:(No sound)Can you hear anything? Exactly — because I'm not even touching it.(Laughter)But yet, we get the sensation of something happening. In the same way that when I see a tree moves, then I imagine that tree making a rustling sound. Do you see what I mean? Whatever the eye sees, then there's always sound happening. So there's always, always that huge — I mean, just this kaleidoscope of things to draw from.So all of my performances are based on entirely what I experience, and not by learning a piece of music, putting on someone else's interpretation of it, buying all the CDs possible of that particular piece of music, and so on and so forth, because that isn't giving me enough of something that is so raw and so basic, and something that I can fully experience the journey of. So it may be that, in certain halls, this dynamic may well work.(Soft marimba sounds)(Soft marimba sounds end)It may be that in other halls, they're simply not going to experience that at all, and so therefore, my level of soft, gentle playing may have to be —(Marimba sounds)(Marimba sounds end)Do you see what I mean? So, because of this explosion in access to sound, especially through the Deaf community, this has not only affected how music institutions, how schools for the deaf treat sound, and not just as a means of therapy — although, of course, being a participator of music, that definitely is the case as well — but it's meant that acousticians have had to really think about the types of halls they put together. There are so few halls in this world that actually have very good acoustics, dare I say. But by that I mean, where you can absolutely do anything you imagine. The tiniest, softest, softest sound to something that is so broad, so huge, so incredible. There's always something: it may sound good up there, may not be so good there; it may be great there, but terrible up there; maybe terrible over there, but not too bad there, etc., etc.So to find an actual hall is incredible — for which you can play exactly what you imagine, without it being cosmetically enhanced. So therefore, acousticians are actually in conversation with people who are hearing impaired, and who are participators of sound. And this is quite interesting. I cannot give you any detail as far as what is actually happening with those halls, but it's just the fact that they are going to a group of people for whom so many years, we've been saying, "Well, how on earth can they experience music? They're deaf." We go like that, and we imagine that's what deafness is about. Or we go like that, and we imagine that's what blindness is about. If we see someone in a wheelchair, we assume they cannot walk. It may be that they can walk three, four, five steps. That, to them, means they can walk. In a year's time, it could be two extra steps. In another year's time, three extra steps.Those are hugely important aspects to think about. So when we do listen to each other, it's unbelievably important for us to really test our listening skills, to really use our bodies as a resonating chamber, to stop the judgment. For me, as a musician who deals with 99 percent of new music, it's very easy for me to say, "Oh yes, I like that piece. No, I don't like that piece," and so on. And I just find that I have to give those pieces of music real time. It may be that the chemistry isn't quite right between myself and that particular piece of music, but that doesn't mean I have the right to say it's a bad piece of music. And you know, one of the great things about being a musician is that it is so unbelievably fluid. So there are no rules, no right, no wrong, this way, that way.If I asked you to clap — maybe I can do this. If I can just say, "Please clap and create the sound of thunder." I'm assuming we've all experienced thunder. Now, I don't mean just the sound; I mean really listen to that thunder within yourselves. And please try to create that through your clapping. Try, just — please try.(Loud clapping sounds)(Clapping ends)Snow.(Laughter)Snow.(Soft clapping sounds)Have you ever heard snow?Audience: No.Evelyn Glennie: Well, then, stop clapping.(Laughter)Try again. Try again: snow.(No sound)See, you're awake.Rain.(Light clapping sounds)EG: (Laughs)Not bad. Not bad. The interesting thing here, though, is that I asked a group of kids not so long ago exactly the same question. Now — great imagination, thank you very much. However, not one of you got out of your seats to think, "Right! How can I clap? OK, maybe:(Clapping sounds)Maybe I can use my jewelry to create extra sounds. Maybe I can use the other parts of my body to create extra sounds." Not a single one of you thought about clapping in a slightly different way other than sitting in your seats there and using two hands. In the same way, when we listen to music, we assume that it's all being fed through here. This is how we experience music. Of course, it's not.We experience thunder, thunder, thunder. Think, think, think. Listen, listen, listen. Now, what can we do with thunder? I remember my teacher, when I first started, my very first lesson, I was all prepared with sticks, ready to go. And instead of him saying, "OK, Evelyn, please, feet slightly apart, arms at a more or less 90-degree angle, sticks in a more or less V shape, keep this amount of space here, etc. Please keep your back straight, etc., etc., etc." — where I was just probably going to end up absolutely rigid, frozen, and I would not be able to strike the drum because I was thinking of so many other things, he said, "Evelyn, take this drum away for seven days, and I'll see you next week."So — heavens! What was I to do? I no longer required the sticks. I wasn't allowed to have these sticks. I had to basically look at this particular drum, see how it was made, what these little lugs did, what the snares did. Turned it upside down, experimented with the shell.(Drum sounds)Experimented with the head.(Drum sounds)Experimented with my body.(Drum sounds)Experimented with jewelry. Experimented with all sorts of things.(Drum sounds)(Drum sounds end)And of course, I returned with all sorts of bruises.(Laughter)But nevertheless, it was such an unbelievable experience, because where on earth are you going to experience that in a piece of music? Where on earth are you going to experience that in a study book? So we never, ever dealt with actual study books. So for example, one of the things that we learn when we are dealing with being a percussion player as opposed to a musician, is basically, straightforward single-stroke rolls.(Drum sounds)Like that, and then we get a little faster —(Drum sounds)and a little faster —(Drum sounds)and a little faster, and so on and so forth. What does this piece require? Single-stroke rolls.(Drum sound)So why can't I then do that whilst learning a piece of music? And that's exactly what he did. And interestingly, the older I became, and when I became a full-time student at a so-called "music institution," all of that went out of the window. We had to study from study books. And constantly, the question, "Well, why? Why? What is this relating to? I need to play a piece of music." "Well, this will help your control." "Well, how? Why do I need to learn that? I need to relate it to a piece of music. You know, I need to say something.Why am I practicing paradiddles?(Drum sounds)Is it just literally for control, for hand-stick control? Why am I doing that? I need to have the reason, and the reason has to be by saying something through the music." And by saying something through music, which basically is sound, we then can reach all sorts of things to all sorts of people. But I don't want to take responsibility of your emotional baggage. That's up to you, when you walk through a hall, because that then determines what and how we listen to certain things. I may feel sorrowful, or happy, or exhilarated, or angry when I play certain pieces of music, but I'm not necessarily wanting you to feel exactly the same thing. So please, the next time you go to a concert, just allow your body to open up, allow your body to be this resonating chamber. Be aware that you're not going to experience the same thing as the performer is.The performer is in the worst possible position for the actual sound, because they're hearing the contact of the stick —(Drum sound)on the drum, or the mallet on the bit of wood, or the bow on the string, etc., or the breath that's creating the sound from wind and brass. They're experiencing that rawness there. But yet they're experiencing something so unbelievably pure, which is before the sound is actually happening. Please take note of the life of the sound after the actual initial strike, or breath, is being pulled. Just experience the whole journey of that sound in the same way that I wished I'd experienced the whole journey of this particular conference, rather than just arriving last night. But I hope maybe we can share one or two things as the day progresses. But thank you very much for having me!(Applause)(Applause ends)(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.021 --> 00:00:16.658
I'm not quite sure whether
I really want to see a snare drum

00:00:16.682 --> 00:00:18.754
at nine o'clock or so in the morning.

00:00:18.778 --> 00:00:20.176
(Laughter)

00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:24.270
But anyway, it's just great
to see such a full theater,

00:00:24.294 --> 00:00:27.579
and really, I must thank
Herbie Hancock and his colleagues

00:00:27.603 --> 00:00:30.107
for such a great presentation.

00:00:30.131 --> 00:00:33.202
(Applause)

00:00:33.226 --> 00:00:35.412
One of the interesting things, of course,

00:00:35.436 --> 00:00:42.389
is the combination of that raw hand
on the instrument and technology,

00:00:42.869 --> 00:00:47.509
and what he said about listening
to our young people.

00:00:47.533 --> 00:00:51.231
Of course, my job is all about listening.

00:00:52.052 --> 00:00:57.997
And my aim, really,
is to teach the world to listen.

00:00:58.021 --> 00:01:01.606
That's my only real aim in life.

00:01:02.352 --> 00:01:08.489
And it sounds quite simple,
but actually, it's quite a big, big job.

00:01:08.513 --> 00:01:13.783
Because you know, when you look
at a piece of music, for example,

00:01:13.807 --> 00:01:17.266
if I just open my little motorbike bag --

00:01:18.605 --> 00:01:21.613
we have here, hopefully,

00:01:21.637 --> 00:01:27.262
a piece of music that is full
of little black dots on the page.

00:01:28.452 --> 00:01:32.218
And, you know, we open it up ...

00:01:34.690 --> 00:01:35.964
And I read the music.

00:01:36.512 --> 00:01:40.226
So technically, I can actually read this.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:44.934
I will follow the instructions,
the tempo markings, the dynamics.

00:01:45.544 --> 00:01:48.729
I will do exactly as I'm told.

00:01:49.675 --> 00:01:53.067
And so therefore, because time is short,

00:01:53.091 --> 00:01:59.990
if I just played you, literally,
the first, maybe, two lines or so --

00:02:00.696 --> 00:02:04.192
It's very straightforward; there's nothing
too difficult about the piece.

00:02:04.216 --> 00:02:07.524
But here, I'm being told
that the piece of music is very quick.

00:02:08.508 --> 00:02:11.514
I'm being told where to play on the drum.

00:02:11.538 --> 00:02:14.454
I'm being told which part
of the stick to use.

00:02:15.805 --> 00:02:18.403
And I'm being told the dynamic.

00:02:18.427 --> 00:02:23.028
And I'm also being told
that the drum is without snares.

00:02:23.052 --> 00:02:26.064
Snares on, snares off.

00:02:26.088 --> 00:02:31.940
So therefore, if I translate
this piece of music,

00:02:31.964 --> 00:02:33.964
we have this idea.

00:02:35.032 --> 00:02:37.236
(Drum sounds)

00:03:02.781 --> 00:03:05.200
(Drum sounds end)

00:03:05.224 --> 00:03:06.491
And so on.

00:03:06.515 --> 00:03:09.997
My career would probably last
about five years.

00:03:10.021 --> 00:03:11.025
(Laughter)

00:03:11.049 --> 00:03:15.572
However, what I have to do as a musician

00:03:15.596 --> 00:03:19.704
is do everything that is not on the music;

00:03:19.728 --> 00:03:24.732
everything that there isn't time
to learn from a teacher,

00:03:24.756 --> 00:03:28.316
or to talk about, even, from a teacher.

00:03:28.340 --> 00:03:33.193
But it's the things you notice when
you're not actually with your instrument

00:03:33.217 --> 00:03:38.464
that, in fact, become so interesting,
and that you want to explore

00:03:38.488 --> 00:03:41.956
through this tiny, tiny surface of a drum.

00:03:41.980 --> 00:03:44.681
So there, we experience the translation.

00:03:44.705 --> 00:03:48.175
Now we'll experience the interpretation.

00:03:49.040 --> 00:03:50.810
(Drum sounds)

00:04:30.934 --> 00:04:32.934
(Drum sounds end)

00:04:34.471 --> 00:04:41.471
(Applause)

00:04:42.016 --> 00:04:44.727
Now my career may last a little longer.

00:04:44.751 --> 00:04:46.078
(Laughter)

00:04:46.102 --> 00:04:49.387
But in a way, you know,
it's the same if I look at you

00:04:49.411 --> 00:04:53.751
and I see a nice, bright young lady
with a pink top on.

00:04:53.775 --> 00:04:57.193
I see that you're clutching
a teddy bear, etc., etc.

00:04:57.217 --> 00:05:01.775
So I get a basic idea
as to what you might be about,

00:05:01.799 --> 00:05:06.167
what you might like, what you might do
as a profession, etc., etc.

00:05:06.600 --> 00:05:12.961
However, that's just the initial idea
I may have that we all get

00:05:12.985 --> 00:05:16.567
when we actually look
and we try to interpret.

00:05:16.591 --> 00:05:18.891
But actually it's so unbelievably shallow.

00:05:18.915 --> 00:05:21.820
In the same way, I look
at the music; I get a basic idea;

00:05:21.844 --> 00:05:26.138
I wonder what technically might be hard,
or, you know, what I want to do.

00:05:26.162 --> 00:05:27.652
Just the basic feeling.

00:05:27.676 --> 00:05:30.339
However, that is simply not enough.

00:05:30.363 --> 00:05:34.677
And I think what Herbie said:
please listen, listen.

00:05:34.701 --> 00:05:38.337
We have to listen
to ourselves, first of all.

00:05:38.361 --> 00:05:42.106
If I play, for example,
holding the stick --

00:05:42.130 --> 00:05:45.183
where literally I do not let go
of the stick --

00:05:45.207 --> 00:05:47.772
(Drum sound)

00:05:47.796 --> 00:05:51.613
you'll experience quite a lot
of shock coming up through the arm.

00:05:51.637 --> 00:05:53.962
And you feel really quite --
believe it or not --

00:05:53.986 --> 00:05:57.229
detached from the instrument
and from the stick,

00:05:57.253 --> 00:06:01.375
even though I'm actually holding
the stick quite tightly.

00:06:01.399 --> 00:06:02.824
(Drum sound)

00:06:02.848 --> 00:06:06.805
By holding it tightly,
I feel strangely more detached.

00:06:06.829 --> 00:06:08.546
If I just simply let go

00:06:08.570 --> 00:06:13.765
and allow my hand, my arm,
to be more of a support system,

00:06:13.789 --> 00:06:14.987
suddenly --

00:06:15.011 --> 00:06:17.025
(Drum sound)

00:06:17.049 --> 00:06:20.506
I have more dynamic with less effort.

00:06:20.530 --> 00:06:21.705
Much more --

00:06:21.729 --> 00:06:23.480
(Drum sound)

00:06:23.504 --> 00:06:26.437
and I just feel, at last,
one with the stick

00:06:26.461 --> 00:06:28.120
and one with the drum.

00:06:28.144 --> 00:06:30.257
And I'm doing far, far less.

00:06:30.281 --> 00:06:33.693
So in the same way that I need
time with this instrument,

00:06:33.717 --> 00:06:39.044
I need time with people
in order to interpret them.

00:06:39.068 --> 00:06:41.756
Not just translate them,
but interpret them.

00:06:41.780 --> 00:06:47.967
If, for example, I play just
a few bars of a piece of music

00:06:49.247 --> 00:06:54.637
for which I think of myself
as a technician --

00:06:54.661 --> 00:06:58.917
that is, someone who is basically
a percussion player --

00:06:58.941 --> 00:07:01.187
(Marimba sounds)

00:07:09.931 --> 00:07:11.828
(Marimba sounds end)

00:07:11.852 --> 00:07:15.040
And so on, if I think of myself
as a musician --

00:07:15.064 --> 00:07:17.132
(Marimba sounds)

00:07:34.825 --> 00:07:36.868
(Marimba sounds end)

00:07:36.892 --> 00:07:38.066
And so on.

00:07:38.090 --> 00:07:41.952
There is a little bit of a difference
there that is worth just --

00:07:41.976 --> 00:07:44.527
(Applause)

00:07:44.551 --> 00:07:45.934
thinking about.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.867
And I remember when I was 12 years old,

00:07:49.891 --> 00:07:53.009
and I started playing timpani
and percussion,

00:07:53.033 --> 00:07:55.463
and my teacher said,

00:07:55.487 --> 00:08:01.140
"Well, how are we going to do this?
You know, music is about listening."

00:08:01.164 --> 00:08:05.835
And I said, "Yes, I agree with that,
so what's the problem?"

00:08:05.859 --> 00:08:08.278
And he said, "Well,
how are you going to hear this?

00:08:08.302 --> 00:08:09.860
How are you going to hear that?"

00:08:09.884 --> 00:08:11.966
And I said, "Well, how do you hear it?"

00:08:12.465 --> 00:08:15.934
He said, "Well, I think
I hear it through here."

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:21.332
And I said, "Well, I think I do too,
but I also hear it through my hands,

00:08:21.356 --> 00:08:24.895
through my arms, cheekbones, my scalp,

00:08:24.919 --> 00:08:27.936
my tummy, my chest, my legs and so on."

00:08:27.960 --> 00:08:32.792
And so we began our lessons
every single time

00:08:32.816 --> 00:08:36.758
tuning drums, in particular,
the kettle drums, or timpani

00:08:36.782 --> 00:08:41.795
to such a narrow pitch interval,
so something like --

00:08:42.564 --> 00:08:45.176
(Marimba sounds)

00:08:46.998 --> 00:08:48.171
that of a difference.

00:08:48.195 --> 00:08:49.397
Then gradually:

00:08:49.421 --> 00:08:50.578
(Marimba sounds)

00:08:50.602 --> 00:08:51.782
And gradually:

00:08:51.806 --> 00:08:53.597
(Marimba sounds)

00:08:53.621 --> 00:08:57.680
And it's amazing that when you do
open your body up,

00:08:57.704 --> 00:09:01.679
and open your hand up to allow
the vibration to come through,

00:09:01.703 --> 00:09:04.026
that in fact the tiny, tiny difference --

00:09:04.050 --> 00:09:06.109
(Marimba sounds)

00:09:06.133 --> 00:09:12.215
can be felt with just the tiniest
part of your finger, there.

00:09:12.239 --> 00:09:15.105
And so what we would do
is that I would put my hands

00:09:15.129 --> 00:09:17.444
on the wall of the music room,

00:09:17.468 --> 00:09:22.662
and together, we would "listen"
to the sounds of the instruments,

00:09:22.686 --> 00:09:26.522
and really try to connect
with those sounds

00:09:26.546 --> 00:09:30.939
far, far more broadly
than simply depending on the ear.

00:09:30.963 --> 00:09:35.606
Because of course, the ear
is subject to all sorts of things.

00:09:35.630 --> 00:09:38.599
The room we happen to be in,
the amplification,

00:09:38.623 --> 00:09:41.358
the quality of the instrument,
the type of sticks --

00:09:41.382 --> 00:09:43.463
(Marimba sounds)

00:09:47.802 --> 00:09:49.749
(Marimba sounds end)

00:09:49.773 --> 00:09:51.592
Etc., etc., they're all different.

00:09:51.616 --> 00:09:53.616
(Marimba sounds)

00:09:56.075 --> 00:09:58.172
(Marimba sounds end)

00:09:58.196 --> 00:10:02.781
Same amount of weight,
but different sound colors.

00:10:02.805 --> 00:10:05.709
And that's basically what we are;
we're just human beings,

00:10:05.733 --> 00:10:08.898
but we all have our own
little sound colors, as it were,

00:10:08.922 --> 00:10:12.571
that make up these extraordinary
personalities and characters

00:10:12.595 --> 00:10:14.468
and interests and things.

00:10:14.492 --> 00:10:17.492
And as I grew older, I then auditioned

00:10:17.516 --> 00:10:19.934
for the Royal Academy of Music in London,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:24.232
and they said, "Well, no, we won't
accept you, because we haven't a clue,

00:10:24.256 --> 00:10:28.909
you know, of the future
of a so-called 'deaf musician.'"

00:10:28.933 --> 00:10:33.460
And I just couldn't quite accept that.

00:10:33.484 --> 00:10:40.052
And so therefore, I said to them,
"Well, look, if you refuse --

00:10:40.076 --> 00:10:43.401
if you refuse me through those reasons,

00:10:43.425 --> 00:10:48.193
as opposed to the ability to perform

00:10:48.217 --> 00:10:54.934
and to understand and love
the art of creating sound --

00:10:54.958 --> 00:11:01.197
then we have to think very, very hard
about the people you do actually accept."

00:11:01.221 --> 00:11:05.479
And as a result,
once we got over a little hurdle,

00:11:05.503 --> 00:11:07.512
and having to audition twice,

00:11:07.536 --> 00:11:09.751
they accepted me.

00:11:09.775 --> 00:11:11.141
And not only that,

00:11:11.165 --> 00:11:16.808
what had happened was that it changed
the whole role of the music institutions

00:11:16.832 --> 00:11:18.784
throughout the United Kingdom.

00:11:18.808 --> 00:11:22.756
Under no circumstances were they to refuse

00:11:22.780 --> 00:11:26.695
any application whatsoever

00:11:26.719 --> 00:11:30.227
on the basis of whether someone
had no arms, no legs --

00:11:30.251 --> 00:11:34.779
they could still perhaps play a wind
instrument if it was supported on a stand.

00:11:35.326 --> 00:11:41.581
No circumstances at all
were used to refuse any entry.

00:11:41.605 --> 00:11:46.443
And every single entry
had to be listened to, experienced,

00:11:46.467 --> 00:11:49.024
and then, based on the musical ability,

00:11:49.048 --> 00:11:54.300
then that person
could either enter or not.

00:11:54.324 --> 00:11:57.478
And so therefore, this in turn meant

00:11:57.502 --> 00:12:01.139
that there was an extremely
interesting bunch of students

00:12:01.163 --> 00:12:04.513
who arrived in these various
music institutions,

00:12:04.537 --> 00:12:09.026
and I have to say, many of them now
in the professional orchestras

00:12:09.050 --> 00:12:11.029
throughout the world.

00:12:11.053 --> 00:12:13.739
The interesting thing
about this as well, though --

00:12:13.763 --> 00:12:17.934
(Applause)

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:24.748
is quite simply that not only were people
connected with sound --

00:12:24.772 --> 00:12:26.283
which is basically all of us --

00:12:26.307 --> 00:12:31.229
we well know that music
really is our daily medicine.

00:12:31.253 --> 00:12:33.934
I say "music," but actually
I mean "sound."

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:38.583
Because some of the extraordinary
things I've experienced as a musician --

00:12:38.607 --> 00:12:42.746
when you may have a 15-year-old lad

00:12:42.770 --> 00:12:47.499
who has got the most
incredible challenges,

00:12:47.523 --> 00:12:50.260
who may not be able
to control his movements,

00:12:50.284 --> 00:12:53.297
who may be deaf,
who may be blind, etc., etc. --

00:12:53.321 --> 00:12:59.351
suddenly, if that young lad
sits close to this instrument,

00:12:59.375 --> 00:13:02.186
and perhaps even lies
underneath the marimba,

00:13:02.210 --> 00:13:07.934
and you play something
that's so incredibly organ-like, almost --

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.818
I don't really have
the right sticks, perhaps --

00:13:10.842 --> 00:13:14.665
but something like this --
let me change --

00:13:16.893 --> 00:13:19.431
(Soft marimba sounds)

00:14:02.125 --> 00:14:04.760
(Soft marimba sounds end)

00:14:04.784 --> 00:14:07.666
Something that's so unbelievably simple --

00:14:07.690 --> 00:14:12.010
but he would be experiencing
something that I wouldn't be,

00:14:12.034 --> 00:14:14.452
because I'm on top of the sound.

00:14:14.476 --> 00:14:16.742
I have the sound coming this way.

00:14:16.766 --> 00:14:20.324
He would have the sound
coming through the resonators.

00:14:20.348 --> 00:14:23.483
If there were no resonators
on here, we would have:

00:14:23.852 --> 00:14:28.925
(Marimba sounds)

00:14:30.064 --> 00:14:32.383
So he would have a fullness of sound

00:14:32.407 --> 00:14:35.405
that those of you in the front few rows
wouldn't experience,

00:14:35.429 --> 00:14:38.574
those of you in the back few rows
wouldn't experience, either.

00:14:38.598 --> 00:14:41.691
Every single one of us,
depending on where we're sitting,

00:14:41.715 --> 00:14:45.492
will experience this sound
quite, quite differently.

00:14:45.516 --> 00:14:48.386
And of course, being
the participator of the sound,

00:14:48.410 --> 00:14:53.236
and that is, starting from the idea
of what type of sound

00:14:53.260 --> 00:14:56.545
I want to produce,
for example, this sound:

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
(No sound)

00:15:03.129 --> 00:15:04.293
Can you hear anything?

00:15:06.066 --> 00:15:08.812
Exactly -- because
I'm not even touching it.

00:15:08.836 --> 00:15:10.361
(Laughter)

00:15:10.385 --> 00:15:15.012
But yet, we get the sensation
of something happening.

00:15:15.036 --> 00:15:17.595
In the same way
that when I see a tree moves,

00:15:17.619 --> 00:15:21.837
then I imagine that tree
making a rustling sound.

00:15:21.861 --> 00:15:23.087
Do you see what I mean?

00:15:23.111 --> 00:15:27.228
Whatever the eye sees,
then there's always sound happening.

00:15:27.252 --> 00:15:31.447
So there's always, always that huge --

00:15:31.471 --> 00:15:35.757
I mean, just this kaleidoscope
of things to draw from.

00:15:35.781 --> 00:15:41.750
So all of my performances
are based on entirely what I experience,

00:15:41.774 --> 00:15:44.270
and not by learning a piece of music,

00:15:44.294 --> 00:15:46.496
putting on someone else's
interpretation of it,

00:15:46.520 --> 00:15:49.699
buying all the CDs possible
of that particular piece of music,

00:15:49.723 --> 00:15:51.089
and so on and so forth,

00:15:51.113 --> 00:15:57.465
because that isn't giving me enough
of something that is so raw and so basic,

00:15:57.489 --> 00:16:02.616
and something that I can fully
experience the journey of.

00:16:02.640 --> 00:16:06.867
So it may be that, in certain halls,

00:16:06.891 --> 00:16:11.659
this dynamic may well work.

00:16:12.127 --> 00:16:14.419
(Soft marimba sounds)

00:16:19.328 --> 00:16:21.330
(Soft marimba sounds end)

00:16:21.354 --> 00:16:22.886
It may be that in other halls,

00:16:22.910 --> 00:16:26.145
they're simply not going
to experience that at all,

00:16:26.169 --> 00:16:30.377
and so therefore, my level of soft,
gentle playing may have to be --

00:16:30.401 --> 00:16:33.560
(Marimba sounds)
