00:16:52.428 --> 00:16:54.429
(Marimba sounds end)

00:16:54.453 --> 00:16:55.795
Do you see what I mean?

00:16:55.819 --> 00:17:02.077
So, because of this explosion
in access to sound,

00:17:02.101 --> 00:17:04.612
especially through the Deaf community,

00:17:04.636 --> 00:17:09.063
this has not only affected
how music institutions,

00:17:09.087 --> 00:17:15.856
how schools for the deaf treat sound,
and not just as a means of therapy --

00:17:15.880 --> 00:17:18.493
although, of course,
being a participator of music,

00:17:18.517 --> 00:17:21.115
that definitely is the case as well --

00:17:21.139 --> 00:17:26.238
but it's meant that acousticians
have had to really think

00:17:26.262 --> 00:17:30.284
about the types of halls
they put together.

00:17:30.308 --> 00:17:32.772
There are so few halls in this world

00:17:32.796 --> 00:17:38.113
that actually have
very good acoustics, dare I say.

00:17:38.137 --> 00:17:43.722
But by that I mean, where you can
absolutely do anything you imagine.

00:17:43.746 --> 00:17:48.564
The tiniest, softest, softest sound
to something that is so broad,

00:17:48.588 --> 00:17:51.310
so huge, so incredible.

00:17:51.334 --> 00:17:52.728
There's always something:

00:17:52.752 --> 00:17:55.256
it may sound good up there,
may not be so good there;

00:17:55.280 --> 00:17:57.423
it may be great there,
but terrible up there;

00:17:57.447 --> 00:18:01.631
maybe terrible over there,
but not too bad there, etc., etc.

00:18:01.655 --> 00:18:06.077
So to find an actual hall is incredible --

00:18:06.101 --> 00:18:10.177
for which you can play
exactly what you imagine,

00:18:10.201 --> 00:18:13.308
without it being cosmetically enhanced.

00:18:13.332 --> 00:18:18.389
So therefore, acousticians
are actually in conversation

00:18:18.413 --> 00:18:21.708
with people who are hearing impaired,

00:18:21.732 --> 00:18:26.583
and who are participators of sound.

00:18:26.607 --> 00:18:28.434
And this is quite interesting.

00:18:28.458 --> 00:18:32.445
I cannot give you any detail

00:18:32.469 --> 00:18:36.206
as far as what is actually happening
with those halls,

00:18:36.230 --> 00:18:40.338
but it's just the fact
that they are going to a group of people

00:18:40.362 --> 00:18:44.308
for whom so many years, we've been saying,

00:18:44.332 --> 00:18:47.673
"Well, how on earth can they experience
music? They're deaf."

00:18:47.697 --> 00:18:51.012
We go like that, and we imagine
that's what deafness is about.

00:18:51.036 --> 00:18:54.172
Or we go like that, and we imagine
that's what blindness is about.

00:18:54.196 --> 00:18:58.018
If we see someone in a wheelchair,
we assume they cannot walk.

00:18:58.042 --> 00:19:01.566
It may be that they can walk
three, four, five steps.

00:19:01.590 --> 00:19:04.441
That, to them, means they can walk.

00:19:05.552 --> 00:19:08.591
In a year's time,
it could be two extra steps.

00:19:09.257 --> 00:19:12.010
In another year's time, three extra steps.

00:19:12.034 --> 00:19:16.737
Those are hugely important
aspects to think about.

00:19:16.761 --> 00:19:20.934
So when we do listen to each other,

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:24.647
it's unbelievably important for us

00:19:24.671 --> 00:19:29.289
to really test our listening skills,

00:19:29.313 --> 00:19:32.785
to really use our bodies
as a resonating chamber,

00:19:32.809 --> 00:19:34.458
to stop the judgment.

00:19:34.482 --> 00:19:38.353
For me, as a musician who deals
with 99 percent of new music,

00:19:38.377 --> 00:19:40.301
it's very easy for me to say,

00:19:40.325 --> 00:19:43.926
"Oh yes, I like that piece.
No, I don't like that piece," and so on.

00:19:43.950 --> 00:19:49.079
And I just find that I have to give
those pieces of music real time.

00:19:49.103 --> 00:19:52.376
It may be that the chemistry
isn't quite right between myself

00:19:52.400 --> 00:19:54.177
and that particular piece of music,

00:19:54.201 --> 00:19:58.683
but that doesn't mean I have the right
to say it's a bad piece of music.

00:19:59.035 --> 00:20:04.135
And you know, one of the great things
about being a musician

00:20:04.159 --> 00:20:07.715
is that it is so unbelievably fluid.

00:20:07.739 --> 00:20:12.143
So there are no rules, no right,
no wrong, this way, that way.

00:20:12.167 --> 00:20:16.995
If I asked you to clap --
maybe I can do this.

00:20:17.019 --> 00:20:23.393
If I can just say, "Please clap
and create the sound of thunder."

00:20:23.417 --> 00:20:26.716
I'm assuming we've all
experienced thunder.

00:20:26.740 --> 00:20:28.322
Now, I don't mean just the sound;

00:20:28.346 --> 00:20:33.263
I mean really listen
to that thunder within yourselves.

00:20:33.287 --> 00:20:35.745
And please try to create that
through your clapping.

00:20:35.769 --> 00:20:37.718
Try, just -- please try.

00:20:37.742 --> 00:20:41.011
(Loud clapping sounds)

00:20:45.519 --> 00:20:46.669
(Clapping ends)

00:20:47.061 --> 00:20:48.419
Snow.

00:20:48.443 --> 00:20:50.579
(Laughter)

00:20:50.603 --> 00:20:51.771
Snow.

00:20:51.795 --> 00:20:54.031
(Soft clapping sounds)

00:20:54.055 --> 00:20:55.600
Have you ever heard snow?

00:20:55.624 --> 00:20:56.775
Audience: No.

00:20:56.799 --> 00:20:58.957
Evelyn Glennie: Well, then, stop clapping.

00:20:58.981 --> 00:21:00.380
(Laughter)

00:21:00.404 --> 00:21:03.609
Try again. Try again: snow.

00:21:03.974 --> 00:21:07.018
(No sound)

00:21:07.780 --> 00:21:09.384
See, you're awake.

00:21:10.053 --> 00:21:11.300
Rain.

00:21:11.672 --> 00:21:13.361
(Light clapping sounds)

00:21:13.845 --> 00:21:15.298
EG: (Laughs)

00:21:16.312 --> 00:21:19.042
Not bad. Not bad.

00:21:19.066 --> 00:21:23.822
The interesting thing here, though,
is that I asked a group of kids

00:21:23.846 --> 00:21:25.549
not so long ago

00:21:25.573 --> 00:21:27.738
exactly the same question.

00:21:27.762 --> 00:21:31.141
Now -- great imagination,
thank you very much.

00:21:31.165 --> 00:21:33.987
However, not one of you got out
of your seats to think,

00:21:34.011 --> 00:21:35.678
"Right! How can I clap?

00:21:35.702 --> 00:21:36.924
OK, maybe:

00:21:36.948 --> 00:21:39.457
(Clapping sounds)

00:21:39.481 --> 00:21:42.313
Maybe I can use my jewelry
to create extra sounds.

00:21:42.337 --> 00:21:46.373
Maybe I can use the other parts
of my body to create extra sounds."

00:21:46.397 --> 00:21:51.790
Not a single one of you thought
about clapping in a slightly different way

00:21:51.814 --> 00:21:54.932
other than sitting in your seats
there and using two hands.

00:21:54.956 --> 00:21:57.101
In the same way, when we listen to music,

00:21:57.125 --> 00:22:01.066
we assume that it's all being
fed through here.

00:22:01.090 --> 00:22:03.634
This is how we experience music.

00:22:03.658 --> 00:22:05.329
Of course, it's not.

00:22:05.353 --> 00:22:08.176
We experience thunder, thunder, thunder.

00:22:08.200 --> 00:22:09.397
Think, think, think.

00:22:09.421 --> 00:22:11.311
Listen, listen, listen.

00:22:11.810 --> 00:22:15.557
Now, what can we do with thunder?

00:22:16.224 --> 00:22:21.618
I remember my teacher, when I first
started, my very first lesson,

00:22:21.642 --> 00:22:25.027
I was all prepared
with sticks, ready to go.

00:22:25.051 --> 00:22:29.847
And instead of him saying,
"OK, Evelyn, please, feet slightly apart,

00:22:29.871 --> 00:22:35.711
arms at a more or less 90-degree angle,
sticks in a more or less V shape,

00:22:35.735 --> 00:22:38.779
keep this amount of space here, etc.

00:22:38.803 --> 00:22:41.357
Please keep your back straight,
etc., etc., etc." --

00:22:41.381 --> 00:22:45.545
where I was just probably going to end up
absolutely rigid, frozen,

00:22:45.569 --> 00:22:47.578
and I would not be able to strike the drum

00:22:47.602 --> 00:22:49.822
because I was thinking
of so many other things,

00:22:49.846 --> 00:22:52.409
he said, "Evelyn, take this drum
away for seven days,

00:22:52.433 --> 00:22:54.218
and I'll see you next week."

00:22:54.242 --> 00:22:56.647
So -- heavens! What was I to do?

00:22:56.671 --> 00:22:59.149
I no longer required the sticks.

00:22:59.173 --> 00:23:01.321
I wasn't allowed to have these sticks.

00:23:01.345 --> 00:23:04.982
I had to basically look
at this particular drum,

00:23:05.006 --> 00:23:06.679
see how it was made,

00:23:06.703 --> 00:23:09.719
what these little lugs did,
what the snares did.

00:23:09.743 --> 00:23:12.695
Turned it upside down,
experimented with the shell.

00:23:12.719 --> 00:23:14.432
(Drum sounds)

00:23:14.456 --> 00:23:15.802
Experimented with the head.

00:23:15.826 --> 00:23:17.288
(Drum sounds)

00:23:17.312 --> 00:23:19.092
Experimented with my body.

00:23:19.116 --> 00:23:20.910
(Drum sounds)

00:23:20.934 --> 00:23:22.758
Experimented with jewelry.

00:23:22.782 --> 00:23:24.870
Experimented with all sorts of things.

00:23:24.894 --> 00:23:28.273
(Drum sounds)

00:23:31.314 --> 00:23:33.790
(Drum sounds end)

00:23:35.140 --> 00:23:38.340
And of course, I returned
with all sorts of bruises.

00:23:38.364 --> 00:23:39.615
(Laughter)

00:23:39.639 --> 00:23:42.999
But nevertheless, it was such
an unbelievable experience,

00:23:43.023 --> 00:23:47.725
because where on earth are you going
to experience that in a piece of music?

00:23:47.749 --> 00:23:51.735
Where on earth are you going
to experience that in a study book?

00:23:51.759 --> 00:23:55.464
So we never, ever dealt
with actual study books.

00:23:55.488 --> 00:23:58.144
So for example,
one of the things that we learn

00:23:58.168 --> 00:24:02.852
when we are dealing
with being a percussion player

00:24:02.876 --> 00:24:04.235
as opposed to a musician,

00:24:04.259 --> 00:24:07.864
is basically, straightforward
single-stroke rolls.

00:24:07.888 --> 00:24:11.512
(Drum sounds)

00:24:11.536 --> 00:24:13.646
Like that, and then
we get a little faster --

00:24:13.670 --> 00:24:14.838
(Drum sounds)

00:24:14.862 --> 00:24:16.058
and a little faster --

00:24:16.082 --> 00:24:17.260
(Drum sounds)

00:24:17.284 --> 00:24:19.766
and a little faster,
and so on and so forth.

00:24:19.790 --> 00:24:21.229
What does this piece require?

00:24:21.253 --> 00:24:22.628
Single-stroke rolls.

00:24:22.652 --> 00:24:25.851
(Drum sound)

00:24:25.875 --> 00:24:29.337
So why can't I then do that
whilst learning a piece of music?

00:24:29.361 --> 00:24:32.179
And that's exactly what he did.

00:24:32.203 --> 00:24:37.553
And interestingly, the older I became,
and when I became a full-time student

00:24:37.577 --> 00:24:42.835
at a so-called "music institution,"
all of that went out of the window.

00:24:42.859 --> 00:24:45.600
We had to study from study books.

00:24:45.624 --> 00:24:49.725
And constantly, the question, "Well, why?
Why? What is this relating to?

00:24:49.749 --> 00:24:51.349
I need to play a piece of music."

00:24:51.373 --> 00:24:53.130
"Well, this will help your control."

00:24:53.154 --> 00:24:55.713
"Well, how? Why do I need to learn that?

00:24:55.737 --> 00:24:58.242
I need to relate it to a piece of music.

00:24:58.266 --> 00:25:00.828
You know, I need to say something.

00:25:00.852 --> 00:25:02.958
Why am I practicing paradiddles?

00:25:02.982 --> 00:25:06.964
(Drum sounds)

00:25:06.988 --> 00:25:10.855
Is it just literally for control,
for hand-stick control?

00:25:10.879 --> 00:25:12.263
Why am I doing that?

00:25:12.287 --> 00:25:14.687
I need to have the reason,

00:25:14.711 --> 00:25:20.292
and the reason has to be by saying
something through the music."

00:25:20.316 --> 00:25:24.809
And by saying something through music,
which basically is sound,

00:25:24.833 --> 00:25:29.205
we then can reach all sorts
of things to all sorts of people.

00:25:29.229 --> 00:25:33.478
But I don't want to take responsibility
of your emotional baggage.

00:25:33.502 --> 00:25:35.726
That's up to you,
when you walk through a hall,

00:25:35.750 --> 00:25:41.084
because that then determines
what and how we listen to certain things.

00:25:41.108 --> 00:25:46.389
I may feel sorrowful, or happy,
or exhilarated, or angry

00:25:46.413 --> 00:25:48.201
when I play certain pieces of music,

00:25:48.225 --> 00:25:53.102
but I'm not necessarily wanting you
to feel exactly the same thing.

00:25:53.126 --> 00:25:56.230
So please, the next time
you go to a concert,

00:25:56.254 --> 00:25:59.899
just allow your body to open up,

00:25:59.923 --> 00:26:03.005
allow your body to be
this resonating chamber.

00:26:03.029 --> 00:26:06.306
Be aware that you're not going
to experience the same thing

00:26:06.330 --> 00:26:08.036
as the performer is.

00:26:08.060 --> 00:26:11.800
The performer is in the worst possible
position for the actual sound,

00:26:11.824 --> 00:26:15.380
because they're hearing
the contact of the stick --

00:26:15.404 --> 00:26:16.916
(Drum sound)

00:26:16.940 --> 00:26:19.809
on the drum, or the mallet
on the bit of wood,

00:26:19.833 --> 00:26:22.020
or the bow on the string, etc.,

00:26:22.044 --> 00:26:26.182
or the breath that's creating
the sound from wind and brass.

00:26:26.206 --> 00:26:28.727
They're experiencing that rawness there.

00:26:28.751 --> 00:26:32.599
But yet they're experiencing
something so unbelievably pure,

00:26:32.623 --> 00:26:36.453
which is before the sound
is actually happening.

00:26:36.477 --> 00:26:43.033
Please take note of the life of the sound
after the actual initial strike,

00:26:43.057 --> 00:26:45.462
or breath, is being pulled.

00:26:45.486 --> 00:26:49.734
Just experience the whole
journey of that sound

00:26:49.758 --> 00:26:53.356
in the same way that I wished
I'd experienced the whole journey

00:26:53.380 --> 00:26:57.809
of this particular conference,
rather than just arriving last night.

00:26:57.833 --> 00:27:02.490
But I hope maybe we can share
one or two things as the day progresses.

00:27:02.514 --> 00:27:05.253
But thank you very much for having me!

00:27:05.277 --> 00:27:08.511
(Applause)

00:27:11.220 --> 00:27:12.918
(Applause ends)

00:27:24.915 --> 00:27:27.937
(Music)

00:31:49.589 --> 00:31:51.859
(Music ends)

00:31:55.202 --> 00:32:02.202
(Applause)

title: Cradle to cradle design
transcript: In 1962, with Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring," I think for people like me in the world of the making of things, the canary in the mine wasn't singing. And so the question that we might not have birds became kind of fundamental to those of us wandering around looking for the meadowlarks that seemed to have all disappeared. And the question was, were the birds singing? Now, I'm not a scientist, that'll be really clear. But, you know, we've just come from this discussion of what a bird might be. What is a bird? Well, in my world, this is a rubber duck. It comes in California with a warning — "This product contains chemicals known by the State of California to cause cancer and birth defects or other reproductive harm." This is a bird. What kind of culture would produce a product of this kind and then label it and sell it to children? I think we have a design problem.Someone heard the six hours of talk that I gave called "The Monticello Dialogues" on NPR, and sent me this as a thank you note — "We realize that design is a signal of intention, but it also has to occur within a world, and we have to understand that world in order to imbue our designs with inherent intelligence, and so as we look back at the basic state of affairs in which we design, we, in a way, need to go to the primordial condition to understand the operating system and the frame conditions of a planet, and I think the exciting part of that is the good news that's there, because the news is the news of abundance, and not the news of limits, and I think as our culture tortures itself now with tyrannies and concerns over limits and fear, we can add this other dimension of abundance that is coherent, driven by the sun, and start to imagine what that would be like to share." That was a nice thing to get. That was one sentence. Henry James would be proud. This is — I put it down at the bottom, but that was extemporaneous, obviously.The fundamental issue is that, for me, design is the first signal of human intentions. So what are our intentions, and what would our intentions be — if we wake up in the morning, we have designs on the world — well, what would our intention be as a species now that we're the dominant species? And it's not just stewardship and dominion debate, because really, dominion is implicit in stewardship — because how could you dominate something you had killed? And stewardship's implicit in dominion, because you can't be steward of something if you can't dominate it.So the question is, what is the first question for designers? Now, as guardians — let's say the state, for example, which reserves the right to kill, the right to be duplicitous and so on — the question we're asking the guardian at this point is are we meant, how are we meant, to secure local societies, create world peace and save the environment? But I don't know that that's the common debate.Commerce, on the other hand, is relatively quick, essentially creative, highly effective and efficient, and fundamentally honest, because we can't exchange value for very long if we don't trust each other. So we use the tools of commerce primarily for our work, but the question we bring to it is, how do we love all the children of all species for all time? And so we start our designs with that question. Because what we realize today is that modern culture appears to have adopted a strategy of tragedy. If we come here and say, "Well, I didn't intend to cause global warming on the way here," and we say, "That's not part of my plan," then we realize it's part of our de facto plan. Because it's the thing that's happening because we have no other plan.And I was at the White House for President Bush, meeting with every federal department and agency, and I pointed out that they appear to have no plan. If the end game is global warming, they're doing great. If the end game is mercury toxification of our children downwind of coal fire plants as they scuttled the Clean Air Act, then I see that our education programs should be explicitly defined as, "Brain death for all children. No child left behind."(Applause)So, the question is, how many federal officials are ready to move to Ohio and Pennsylvania with their families? So if you don't have an endgame of something delightful, then you're just moving chess pieces around, if you don't know you're taking the king. So perhaps we could develop a strategy of change, which requires humility. And in my business as an architect, it's unfortunate the word "humility" and the word "architect" have not appeared in the same paragraph since "The Fountainhead." So if anybody here has trouble with the concept of design humility, reflect on this — it took us 5,000 years to put wheels on our luggage. So, as Kevin Kelly pointed out, there is no endgame. There is an infinite game, and we're playing in that infinite game. And so we call it "cradle to cradle," and our goal is very simple.This is what I presented to the White House. Our goal is a delightfully diverse, safe, healthy and just world, with clean air, clean water, soil and power — economically, equitably, ecologically and elegantly enjoyed, period.(Applause)What don't you like about this? Which part of this don't you like? So we realized we want full diversity, even though it can be difficult to remember what De Gaulle said when asked what it was like to be President of France. He said, "What do you think it's like trying to run a country with 400 kinds of cheese?" But at the same time, we realize that our products are not safe and healthy.So we've designed products and we analyzed chemicals down to the parts per million. This is a baby blanket by Pendleton that will give your child nutrition instead of Alzheimer's later in life. We can ask ourselves, what is justice, and is justice blind, or is justice blindness? And at what point did that uniform turn from white to black? Water has been declared a human right by the United Nations. Air quality is an obvious thing to anyone who breathes. Is there anybody here who doesn't breathe? Clean soil is a critical problem — the nitrification, the dead zones in the Gulf of Mexico. A fundamental issue that's not being addressed. We've seen the first form of solar energy that's beat the hegemony of fossil fuels in the form of wind here in the Great Plains, and so that hegemony is leaving. And if we remember Sheikh Yamani when he formed OPEC, they asked him, "When will we see the end of the age of oil?" I don't know if you remember his answer, but it was, "The Stone Age didn't end because we ran out of stones." We see that companies acting ethically in this world are outperforming those that don't. We see the flows of materials in a rather terrifying prospect. This is a hospital monitor from Los Angeles, sent to China. This woman will expose herself to toxic phosphorous, release four pounds of toxic lead into her childrens' environment, which is from copper.On the other hand, we see great signs of hope. Here's Dr. Venkataswamy in India, who's figured out how to do mass-produced health. He has given eyesight to two million people for free. We see in our material flows that car steels don't become car steel again because of the contaminants of the coatings — bismuth, antimony, copper and so on. They become building steel. On the other hand, we're working with Berkshire Hathaway, Warren Buffett and Shaw Carpet, the largest carpet company in the world. We've developed a carpet that is continuously recyclable, down to the parts per million. The upper is Nylon 6 that can go back to caprolactam, the bottom, a polyolephine — infinitely recyclable thermoplastic. Now if I was a bird, the building on my left is a liability. The building on my right, which is our corporate campus for The Gap with an ancient meadow, is an asset — its nesting grounds.Here's where I come from. I grew up in Hong Kong, with six million people in 40 square miles. During the dry season, we had four hours of water every fourth day. And the relationship to landscape was that of farmers who have been farming the same piece of ground for 40 centuries. You can't farm the same piece of ground for 40 centuries without understanding nutrient flow. My childhood summers were in the Puget Sound of Washington, among the first growth and big growth. My grandfather had been a lumberjack in the Olympics, so I have a lot of tree karma I am working off. I went to Yale for graduate school, studied in a building of this style by Le Corbusier, affectionately known in our business as Brutalism. If we look at the world of architecture, we see with Mies' 1928 tower for Berlin, the question might be, "Well, where's the sun?" And this might have worked in Berlin, but we built it in Houston, and the windows are all closed. And with most products appearing not to have been designed for indoor use, this is actually a vertical gas chamber.When I went to Yale, we had the first energy crisis, and I was designing the first solar-heated house in Ireland as a student, which I then built — which would give you a sense of my ambition. And Richard Meier, who was one of my teachers, kept coming over to my desk to give me criticism, and he would say, "Bill, you've got to understand- — solar energy has nothing to do with architecture." I guess he didn't read Vitruvius. In 1984, we did the first so-called "green office" in America for Environmental Defense. We started asking manufacturers what were in their materials. They said, "They're proprietary, they're legal, go away." The only indoor quality work done in this country at that time was sponsored by R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, and it was to prove there was no danger from secondhand smoke in the workplace.So, all of a sudden, here I am, graduating from high school in 1969, and this happens, and we realize that "away" went away. Remember we used to throw things away, and we'd point to away? And yet, NOAA has now shown us, for example — you see that little blue thing above Hawaii? That's the Pacific Gyre. It was recently dragged for plankton by scientists, and they found six times as much plastic as plankton. When asked, they said, "It's kind of like a giant toilet that doesn't flush." Perhaps that's away. So we're looking for the design rules of this — this is the highest biodiversity of trees in the world, Irian Jaya, 259 species of tree, and we described this in the book, "Cradle to Cradle." The book itself is a polymer. It is not a tree. That's the name of the first chapter — "This Book is Not a Tree." Because in poetics, as Margaret Atwood pointed out, "we write our history on the skin of fish with the blood of bears." And with so much polymer, what we really need is technical nutrition, and to use something as elegant as a tree — imagine this design assignment: Design something that makes oxygen, sequesters carbon, fixes nitrogen, distills water, accrues solar energy as fuel, makes complex sugars and food, creates microclimates, changes colors with the seasons and self-replicates. Well, why don't we knock that down and write on it?(Laughter)So, we're looking at the same criteria as most people — you know, can I afford it? Does it work? Do I like it? We're adding the Jeffersonian agenda, and I come from Charlottesville, where I've had the privilege of living in a house designed by Thomas Jefferson. We're adding life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. Now if we look at the word "competition," I'm sure most of you've used it. You know, most people don't realize it comes from the Latin competere, which means strive together. It means the way Olympic athletes train with each other. They get fit together, and then they compete. The Williams sisters compete — one wins Wimbledon. So we've been looking at the idea of competition as a way of cooperating in order to get fit together. And the Chinese government has now — I work with the Chinese government now — has taken this up. We're also looking at survival of the fittest, not in just competition terms in our modern context of destroy the other or beat them to the ground, but really to fit together and build niches and have growth that is good.Now most environmentalists don't say growth is good, because, in our lexicon, asphalt is two words: assigning blame. But if we look at asphalt as our growth, then we realize that all we're doing is destroying the planetary's fundamental underlying operating system. So when we see E equals mc squared come along, from a poet's perspective, we see energy as physics, chemistry as mass, and all of a sudden, you get this biology. And we have plenty of energy, so we'll solve that problem, but the biology problem's tricky, because as we put through all these toxic materials that we disgorge, we will never be able to recover that. And as Francis Crick pointed out, nine years after discovering DNA with Mr. Watson, that life itself has to have growth as a precondition — it has to have free energy, sunlight and it needs to be an open system of chemicals. So we're asking for human artifice to become a living thing, and we want growth, we want free energy from sunlight and we want an open metabolism for chemicals. Then, the question becomes not growth or no growth, but what do you want to grow? So instead of just growing destruction, we want to grow the things that we might enjoy, and someday the FDA will allow us to make French cheese.So therefore, we have these two metabolisms, and I worked with a German chemist, Michael Braungart, and we've identified the two fundamental metabolisms. The biological one I'm sure you understand, but also the technical one, where we take materials and put them into closed cycles. We call them biological nutrition and technical nutrition. Technical nutrition will be in an order of magnitude of biological nutrition. Biological nutrition can supply about 500 million humans, which means that if we all wore Birkenstocks and cotton, the world would run out of cork and dry up. So we need materials in closed cycles, but we need to analyze them down to the parts per million for cancer, birth defects, mutagenic effects, disruption of our immune systems, biodegradation, persistence, heavy metal content, knowledge of how we're making them and their production and so on.Our first product was a textile where we analyzed 8,000 chemicals in the textile industry. Using those intellectual filters, we eliminated [7,962.] We were left with 38 chemicals. We have since databased the 4000 most commonly used chemicals in human manufacturing, and we're releasing this database into the public in six weeks. So designers all over the world can analyze their products down to the parts per million for human and ecological health.(Applause)We've developed a protocol so that companies can send these same messages all the way through their supply chains, because when we asked most companies we work with — about a trillion dollars — and say, "Where does your stuff come from?" They say, "Suppliers." "And where does it go?" "Customers." So we need some help there.So the biological nutrients, the first fabrics — the water coming out was clean enough to drink. Technical nutrients — this is for Shaw Carpet, infinitely reusable carpet. Here's nylon going back to caprolactam back to carpet. Biotechnical nutrients — the Model U for Ford Motor, a cradle to cradle car — concept car. Shoes for Nike, where the uppers are polyesters, infinitely recyclable, the bottoms are biodegradable soles. Wear your old shoes in, your new shoes out. There is no finish line. The idea here of the car is that some of the materials go back to the industry forever, some of the materials go back to soil — it's all solar-powered.Here's a building at Oberlin College we designed that makes more energy than it needs to operate and purifies its own water. Here's a building for The Gap, where the ancient grasses of San Bruno, California, are on the roof.And this is our project for Ford Motor Company. It's the revitalization of the River Rouge in Dearborn. This is obviously a color photograph. These are our tools. These are how we sold it to Ford. We saved Ford 35 million dollars doing it this way, day one, which is the equivalent of the Ford Taurus at a four percent margin of an order for 900 million dollars worth of cars. Here it is. It's the world's largest green roof, 10 and a half acres. This is the roof, saving money, and this is the first species to arrive here. These are killdeer. They showed up in five days. And we now have 350-pound auto workers learning bird songs on the Internet. We're developing now protocols for cities — that's the home of technical nutrients. The country — the home of biological. And putting them together.And so I will finish by showing you a new city we're designing for the Chinese government. We're doing 12 cities for China right now, based on cradle to cradle as templates. Our assignment is to develop protocols for the housing for 400 million people in 12 years. We did a mass energy balance — if they use brick, they will lose all their soil and burn all their coal. They'll have cities with no energy and no food. We signed a Memorandum of Understanding — here's Madam Deng Nan, Deng Xiaoping's daughter — for China to adopt cradle to cradle. Because if they toxify themselves, being the lowest-cost producer, send it to the lowest-cost distribution — Wal-Mart — and then we send them all our money, what we'll discover is that we have what, effectively, when I was a student, was called mutually assured destruction.Now we do it by molecule. These are our cities. We're building a new city next to this city; look at that landscape. This is the site. We don't normally do green fields, but this one is about to be built, so they brought us in to intercede. This is their plan. It's a rubber stamp grid that they laid right on that landscape. And they brought us in and said, "What would you do?" This is what they would end up with, which is another color photograph. So this is the existing site, so this is what it looks like now, and here's our proposal.(Applause)So the way we approached this is we studied the hydrology very carefully. We studied the biota, the ancient biota, the current farming and the protocols. We studied the winds and the sun to make sure everybody in the city will have fresh air, fresh water and direct sunlight in every single apartment at some point during the day. We then take the parks and lay them out as ecological infrastructure. We lay out the building areas. We start to integrate commercial and mixed use so the people all have centers and places to be. The transportation is all very simple, everybody's within a five-minute walk of mobility. We have a 24-hour street, so that there's always a place that's alive. The waste systems all connect. If you flush a toilet, your feces will go to the sewage treatment plants, which are sold as assets, not liabilities. Because who wants the fertilizer factory that makes natural gas? The waters are all taken in to construct the wetlands for habitat restorations. And then it makes natural gas, which then goes back into the city to power the fuel for the cooking for the city. So this is — these are fertilizer gas plants. And then the compost is all taken back to the roofs of the city, where we've got farming, because what we've done is lifted up the city, the landscape, into the air to — to restore the native landscape on the roofs of the buildings. The solar power of all the factory centers and all the industrial zones with their light roofs powers the city.And this is the concept for the top of the city. We've lifted the earth up onto the roofs. The farmers have little bridges to get from one roof to the next. We inhabit the city with work/live space on all the ground floors. And so this is the existing city, and this is the new city.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:16.958
In 1962, with Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring,"

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:21.958
I think for people like me in the world of the making of things,

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:25.958
the canary in the mine wasn't singing.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
And so the question that we might not have birds

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:31.958
became kind of fundamental to those of us wandering around

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
looking for the meadowlarks that seemed to have all disappeared.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
And the question was, were the birds singing?

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:41.958
Now, I'm not a scientist, that'll be really clear.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
But, you know, we've just come from this discussion of what a bird might be.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:46.958
What is a bird?

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:50.958
Well, in my world, this is a rubber duck.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
It comes in California with a warning --

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
"This product contains chemicals known by the State of California

00:00:55.958 --> 00:01:02.958
to cause cancer and birth defects or other reproductive harm."

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
This is a bird.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
What kind of culture would produce a product of this kind

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:13.958
and then label it and sell it to children?

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
I think we have a design problem.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:21.958
Someone heard the six hours of talk that I gave

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:27.958
called "The Monticello Dialogues" on NPR, and sent me this as a thank you note --

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
"We realize that design is a signal of intention,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
but it also has to occur within a world,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:36.958
and we have to understand that world in order to

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
imbue our designs with inherent intelligence,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and so as we look back at the basic state of affairs

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:49.958
in which we design, we, in a way, need to go to the primordial condition

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:54.958
to understand the operating system and the frame conditions of a planet,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:59.958
and I think the exciting part of that is the good news that's there,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:02.958
because the news is the news of abundance,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
and not the news of limits,

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:09.958
and I think as our culture tortures itself now

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:14.958
with tyrannies and concerns over limits and fear,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:19.958
we can add this other dimension of abundance that is coherent,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
driven by the sun, and start to imagine

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:28.958
what that would be like to share."

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
That was a nice thing to get.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
That was one sentence.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
Henry James would be proud.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
This is -- I put it down at the bottom,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
but that was extemporaneous, obviously.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
The fundamental issue is that, for me,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
design is the first signal of human intentions.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:50.958
So what are our intentions, and what would our intentions be --

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
if we wake up in the morning, we have designs on the world --

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
well, what would our intention be as a species

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
now that we're the dominant species?

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
And it's not just stewardship and dominion debate,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:06.958
because really, dominion is implicit in stewardship --

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
because how could you dominate something you had killed?

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
And stewardship's implicit in dominion,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
because you can't be steward of something if you can't dominate it.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:18.958
So the question is, what is the first question for designers?

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
Now, as guardians -- let's say the state, for example,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:26.958
which reserves the right to kill, the right to be duplicitous and so on --

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
the question we're asking the guardian at this point is

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
are we meant, how are we meant,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
to secure local societies, create world peace

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
and save the environment?

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
But I don't know that that's the common debate.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:42.958
Commerce, on the other hand, is relatively quick,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
essentially creative, highly effective and efficient,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
and fundamentally honest, because we can't exchange

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
value for very long if we don't trust each other.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
So we use the tools of commerce primarily for our work,

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
but the question we bring to it is,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:59.958
how do we love all the children of all species for all time?

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
And so we start our designs with that question.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
Because what we realize today is that modern culture

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
appears to have adopted a strategy of tragedy.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
If we come here and say, "Well, I didn't intend

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:10.958
to cause global warming on the way here,"

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
and we say, "That's not part of my plan,"

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
then we realize it's part of our de facto plan.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
Because it's the thing that's happening because we have no other plan.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
And I was at the White House for President Bush,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
meeting with every federal department and agency,

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:26.958
and I pointed out that they appear to have no plan.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
If the end game is global warming, they're doing great.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
If the end game is mercury toxification of our children

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
downwind of coal fire plants as they scuttled the Clean Air Act,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
then I see that our education programs should be explicitly defined as,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
"Brain death for all children. No child left behind."

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
(Applause)

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:48.958
So, the question is, how many federal officials

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
are ready to move to Ohio and Pennsylvania with their families?

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:55.958
So if you don't have an endgame of something delightful,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
then you're just moving chess pieces around,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:58.958
if you don't know you're taking the king.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
So perhaps we could develop a strategy of change,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
which requires humility. And in my business as an architect,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:08.958
it's unfortunate the word "humility" and the word "architect"

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
have not appeared in the same paragraph since "The Fountainhead."

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:16.958
So if anybody here has trouble with the concept of design humility,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
reflect on this -- it took us 5,000 years

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:23.958
to put wheels on our luggage.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:28.958
So, as Kevin Kelly pointed out, there is no endgame.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
There is an infinite game, and we're playing in that infinite game.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
And so we call it "cradle to cradle,"

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:35.958
and our goal is very simple.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
This is what I presented to the White House.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
Our goal is a delightfully diverse, safe, healthy and just world,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:43.958
with clean air, clean water, soil and power --

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:47.958
economically, equitably, ecologically and elegantly enjoyed, period.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
(Applause)

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
What don't you like about this?

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
Which part of this don't you like?

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
So we realized we want full diversity,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
even though it can be difficult to remember what De Gaulle said

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
when asked what it was like to be President of France.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
He said, "What do you think it's like trying to run a country with 400 kinds of cheese?"

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
But at the same time, we realize that our products are not safe and healthy.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
So we've designed products

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
and we analyzed chemicals down to the parts per million.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
This is a baby blanket by Pendleton that will give your child nutrition

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
instead of Alzheimer's later in life.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
We can ask ourselves, what is justice,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:24.958
and is justice blind, or is justice blindness?

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:29.958
And at what point did that uniform turn from white to black?

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Water has been declared a human right by the United Nations.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Air quality is an obvious thing to anyone who breathes.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
Is there anybody here who doesn't breathe?

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
Clean soil is a critical problem -- the nitrification, the dead zones

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
in the Gulf of Mexico.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
A fundamental issue that's not being addressed.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
We've seen the first form of solar energy

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
that's beat the hegemony of fossil fuels in the form of wind

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
here in the Great Plains, and so that hegemony is leaving.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
And if we remember Sheikh Yamani when he formed OPEC,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
they asked him, "When will we see the end of the age of oil?"

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
I don't know if you remember his answer, but it was,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
"The Stone Age didn't end because we ran out of stones."

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:09.958
We see that companies acting ethically in this world

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:10.958
are outperforming those that don't.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:15.958
We see the flows of materials in a rather terrifying prospect.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
This is a hospital monitor from Los Angeles, sent to China.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
This woman will expose herself to toxic phosphorous,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
release four pounds of toxic lead into her childrens' environment,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
which is from copper.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
On the other hand, we see great signs of hope.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
Here's Dr. Venkataswamy in India, who's figured out

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
how to do mass-produced health.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
He has given eyesight to two million people for free.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
We see in our material flows that car steels don't become car steel again

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
because of the contaminants of the coatings --

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
bismuth, antimony, copper and so on.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:45.958
They become building steel.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
On the other hand, we're working with Berkshire Hathaway,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
Warren Buffett and Shaw Carpet,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:51.958
the largest carpet company in the world.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
We've developed a carpet that is continuously recyclable,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
down to the parts per million.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
The upper is Nylon 6 that can go back to caprolactam,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
the bottom, a polyolephine -- infinitely recyclable thermoplastic.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:07.958
Now if I was a bird, the building on my left is a liability.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
The building on my right, which is our corporate campus for The Gap

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:15.958
with an ancient meadow, is an asset -- its nesting grounds.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Here's where I come from. I grew up in Hong Kong,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
with six million people in 40 square miles.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
During the dry season, we had four hours of water every fourth day.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
And the relationship to landscape was that of farmers who have been

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
farming the same piece of ground for 40 centuries.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
You can't farm the same piece of ground for 40 centuries

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
without understanding nutrient flow.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
My childhood summers were in the Puget Sound of Washington,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
among the first growth and big growth.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
My grandfather had been a lumberjack in the Olympics,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:47.958
so I have a lot of tree karma I am working off.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
I went to Yale for graduate school,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
studied in a building of this style by Le Corbusier,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:55.958
affectionately known in our business as Brutalism.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
If we look at the world of architecture,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
we see with Mies' 1928 tower for Berlin,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
the question might be, "Well, where's the sun?"

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
And this might have worked in Berlin, but we built it in Houston,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
and the windows are all closed. And with most products

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
appearing not to have been designed for indoor use,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
this is actually a vertical gas chamber.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
When I went to Yale, we had the first energy crisis,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
and I was designing the first solar-heated house in Ireland

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
as a student, which I then built --

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
which would give you a sense of my ambition.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And Richard Meier, who was one of my teachers,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
kept coming over to my desk to give me criticism,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and he would say, "Bill, you've got to understand- --

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:37.958
solar energy has nothing to do with architecture."

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
I guess he didn't read Vitruvius.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
In 1984, we did the first so-called "green office" in America

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:44.958
for Environmental Defense.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
We started asking manufacturers what were in their materials.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
They said, "They're proprietary, they're legal, go away."

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
The only indoor quality work done in this country at that time

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
was sponsored by R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:55.958
and it was to prove there was no danger

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
from secondhand smoke in the workplace.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
So, all of a sudden, here I am, graduating from high school in 1969,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
and this happens, and we realize that "away" went away.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
Remember we used to throw things away, and we'd point to away?

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
And yet, NOAA has now shown us, for example --

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
you see that little blue thing above Hawaii?

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:14.958
That's the Pacific Gyre.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
It was recently dragged for plankton by scientists,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and they found six times as much plastic as plankton.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:25.958
When asked, they said, "It's kind of like a giant toilet that doesn't flush."

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Perhaps that's away.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
So we're looking for the design rules of this --

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
this is the highest biodiversity of trees in the world, Irian Jaya,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:34.958
259 species of tree, and we described this

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:35.958
in the book, "Cradle to Cradle."

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:39.958
The book itself is a polymer. It is not a tree.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
That's the name of the first chapter -- "This Book is Not a Tree."

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
Because in poetics, as Margaret Atwood pointed out,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
"we write our history on the skin of fish

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
with the blood of bears."

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:51.958
And with so much polymer, what we really need

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
is technical nutrition, and to use something

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
as elegant as a tree -- imagine this design assignment:

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
Design something that makes oxygen, sequesters carbon,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
fixes nitrogen, distills water, accrues solar energy as fuel,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:07.958
makes complex sugars and food, creates microclimates,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:13.958
changes colors with the seasons and self-replicates.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
Well, why don't we knock that down and write on it?

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:21.958
(Laughter)

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
So, we're looking at the same criteria

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
as most people -- you know, can I afford it?

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
Does it work? Do I like it?

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
We're adding the Jeffersonian agenda, and I come from Charlottesville,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:33.958
where I've had the privilege of living in a house designed by Thomas Jefferson.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:39.958
We're adding life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:40.958
Now if we look at the word "competition,"

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
I'm sure most of you've used it.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:43.958
You know, most people don't realize it comes from

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
the Latin competere, which means strive together.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
It means the way Olympic athletes train with each other.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
They get fit together, and then they compete.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
The Williams sisters compete -- one wins Wimbledon.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
So we've been looking at the idea of competition

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:01.958
as a way of cooperating in order to get fit together.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:02.958
And the Chinese government has now --

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
I work with the Chinese government now --

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
has taken this up.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
We're also looking at survival of the fittest,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
not in just competition terms in our modern context

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
of destroy the other or beat them to the ground,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
but really to fit together and build niches

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
and have growth that is good.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
Now most environmentalists don't say growth is good,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:24.958
because, in our lexicon, asphalt is two words: assigning blame.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
But if we look at asphalt as our growth,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
then we realize that all we're doing is destroying

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:33.958
the planetary's fundamental underlying operating system.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:38.958
So when we see E equals mc squared come along, from a poet's perspective,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
we see energy as physics, chemistry as mass,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
and all of a sudden, you get this biology.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
And we have plenty of energy, so we'll solve that problem,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
but the biology problem's tricky, because as we put through

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
all these toxic materials that we disgorge,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
we will never be able to recover that.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And as Francis Crick pointed out, nine years

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
after discovering DNA with Mr. Watson,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
that life itself has to have growth as a precondition --

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
it has to have free energy, sunlight

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
and it needs to be an open system of chemicals.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
So we're asking for human artifice to become a living thing,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
and we want growth, we want free energy from sunlight

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
and we want an open metabolism for chemicals.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
Then, the question becomes not growth or no growth,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
but what do you want to grow?

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
So instead of just growing destruction,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
we want to grow the things that we might enjoy,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
and someday the FDA will allow us to make French cheese.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:31.958
So therefore, we have these two metabolisms,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
and I worked with a German chemist, Michael Braungart,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
and we've identified the two fundamental metabolisms.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
The biological one I'm sure you understand,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
but also the technical one, where we take materials

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
and put them into closed cycles.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
We call them biological nutrition and technical nutrition.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
Technical nutrition will be in an order of magnitude of biological nutrition.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
Biological nutrition can supply about 500 million humans,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
which means that if we all wore Birkenstocks and cotton,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
the world would run out of cork and dry up.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
So we need materials in closed cycles,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
but we need to analyze them down to the parts per million

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
for cancer, birth defects, mutagenic effects,

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
disruption of our immune systems, biodegradation, persistence,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
heavy metal content, knowledge of how we're making them

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
and their production and so on.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:15.958
Our first product was a textile where we analyzed 8,000 chemicals

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:16.958
in the textile industry.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:21.958
Using those intellectual filters, we eliminated [7,962.]

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
We were left with 38 chemicals.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
We have since databased the 4000 most commonly used chemicals

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:31.958
in human manufacturing, and we're releasing this database into the public in six weeks.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
So designers all over the world can analyze their products

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:38.958
down to the parts per million for human and ecological health.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:43.958
(Applause)

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
We've developed a protocol so that companies can send

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
these same messages all the way through their supply chains,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
because when we asked most companies we work with -- about a trillion dollars

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
-- and say, "Where does your stuff come from?" They say, "Suppliers."

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
"And where does it go?"

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:57.958
"Customers."

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:58.958
So we need some help there.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
So the biological nutrients, the first fabrics --

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
the water coming out was clean enough to drink.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:06.958
Technical nutrients -- this is for Shaw Carpet, infinitely reusable carpet.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
Here's nylon going back to caprolactam back to carpet.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
Biotechnical nutrients -- the Model U for Ford Motor,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
a cradle to cradle car -- concept car.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
Shoes for Nike, where the uppers are polyesters, infinitely recyclable,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
the bottoms are biodegradable soles.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
Wear your old shoes in, your new shoes out.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
There is no finish line.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
The idea here of the car is that some of the materials

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
go back to the industry forever, some of the materials go back to soil --

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
it's all solar-powered.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
Here's a building at Oberlin College we designed

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.958
that makes more energy than it needs to operate and purifies its own water.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
Here's a building for The Gap, where the ancient grasses

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:44.958
of San Bruno, California, are on the roof.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
And this is our project for Ford Motor Company.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
It's the revitalization of the River Rouge in Dearborn.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.958
This is obviously a color photograph.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.958
These are our tools. These are how we sold it to Ford.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
We saved Ford 35 million dollars doing it this way, day one,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
which is the equivalent of the Ford Taurus

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:05.958
at a four percent margin of an order for 900 million dollars worth of cars.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
Here it is. It's the world's largest green roof, 10 and a half acres.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
This is the roof, saving money,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:15.958
and this is the first species to arrive here. These are killdeer.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
They showed up in five days.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
And we now have 350-pound auto workers

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:24.958
learning bird songs on the Internet.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
We're developing now protocols for cities --

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
that's the home of technical nutrients.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
The country -- the home of biological. And putting them together.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
And so I will finish by showing you a new city

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
we're designing for the Chinese government.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
We're doing 12 cities for China right now,

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
based on cradle to cradle as templates.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
Our assignment is to develop protocols for the housing

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
for 400 million people in 12 years.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
We did a mass energy balance -- if they use brick,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
they will lose all their soil and burn all their coal.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
They'll have cities with no energy and no food.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
We signed a Memorandum of Understanding --

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
here's Madam Deng Nan, Deng Xiaoping's daughter --

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
for China to adopt cradle to cradle.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:02.958
Because if they toxify themselves, being the lowest-cost producer,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
send it to the lowest-cost distribution -- Wal-Mart --

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
and then we send them all our money, what we'll discover is that

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
we have what, effectively, when I was a student,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:13.958
was called mutually assured destruction.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
Now we do it by molecule. These are our cities.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
We're building a new city next to this city; look at that landscape.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
This is the site.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:25.958
We don't normally do green fields, but this one is about to be built,

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
so they brought us in to intercede.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
This is their plan.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
It's a rubber stamp grid that they laid right on that landscape.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
And they brought us in and said, "What would you do?"

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:39.958
This is what they would end up with, which is another color photograph.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
So this is the existing site, so this is what it looks like now,

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:44.958
and here's our proposal.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:48.958
(Applause)

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:50.958
So the way we approached this

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
is we studied the hydrology very carefully.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
We studied the biota, the ancient biota,

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
the current farming and the protocols.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
We studied the winds and the sun to make sure everybody in the city

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:04.958
will have fresh air, fresh water and direct sunlight

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.958
in every single apartment at some point during the day.

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:11.958
We then take the parks and lay them out as ecological infrastructure.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
We lay out the building areas.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:15.958
We start to integrate commercial and mixed use

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:18.958
so the people all have centers and places to be.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
The transportation is all very simple,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:23.958
everybody's within a five-minute walk of mobility.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:28.958
We have a 24-hour street, so that there's always a place that's alive.

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
The waste systems all connect.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:35.958
If you flush a toilet, your feces will go to the sewage treatment plants,

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:37.958
which are sold as assets, not liabilities.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:41.958
Because who wants the fertilizer factory that makes natural gas?

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:46.958
The waters are all taken in to construct the wetlands for habitat restorations.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:50.958
And then it makes natural gas, which then goes back into the city

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
to power the fuel for the cooking for the city.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:56.958
So this is -- these are fertilizer gas plants.

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:59.958
And then the compost is all taken back

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
to the roofs of the city, where we've got farming,

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.958
because what we've done is lifted up the city,

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:12.958
the landscape, into the air to -- to restore the native landscape

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:14.958
on the roofs of the buildings.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:17.958
The solar power of all the factory centers

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:20.958
and all the industrial zones with their light roofs powers the city.

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:22.958
And this is the concept for the top of the city.

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:26.958
We've lifted the earth up onto the roofs.

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:30.958
The farmers have little bridges to get from one roof to the next.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:34.958
We inhabit the city with work/live space on all the ground floors.

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:39.958
And so this is the existing city, and this is the new city.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:53.958
(Applause)

title: The electricity metaphor for the web's future
transcript: When you think about resilience and technology it's actually much easier. You're going to see some other speakers today, I already know, who are going to talk about breaking-bones stuff, and, of course, with technology it never is. So it's very easy, comparatively speaking, to be resilient. I think that, if we look at what happened on the Internet, with such an incredible last half a dozen years, that it's hard to even get the right analogy for it. A lot of how we decide, how we're supposed to react to things and what we're supposed to expect about the future depends on how we bucket things and how we categorize them.And so I think the tempting analogy for the boom-bust that we just went through with the Internet is a gold rush. It's easy to think of this analogy as very different from some of the other things you might pick. For one thing, both were very real. In 1849, in that Gold Rush, they took over $700 million worth of gold out of California. It was very real. The Internet was also very real. This is a real way for humans to communicate with each other. It's a big deal. Huge boom. Huge boom. Huge bust. Huge bust. You keep going, and both things are lots of hype. I don't have to remind you of all the hype that was involved with the Internet — like GetRich.com.But you had the same thing with the Gold Rush. "Gold. Gold. Gold." Sixty-eight rich men on the Steamer Portland. Stacks of yellow metal. Some have 5,000. Many have more. A few bring out 100,000 dollars each. People would get very excited about this when they read these articles. "The Eldorado of the United States of America: the discovery of inexhaustible gold mines in California." And the parallels between the Gold Rush and the Internet Rush continue very strongly. So many people left what they were doing. And what would happen is — and the Gold Rush went on for years.People on the East Coast in 1849, when they first started to get the news, they thought, "Ah, this isn't real." But they keep hearing about people getting rich, and then in 1850 they still hear that. And they think it's not real. By about 1852, they're thinking, "Am I the stupidest person on Earth by not rushing to California?" And they start to decide they are. These are community affairs, by the way. Local communities on the East Coast would get together and whole teams of 10, 20 people would caravan across the United States, and they would form companies. These were typically not solitary efforts. But no matter what, if you were a lawyer or a banker, people dropped what they were doing, no matter what skill set they had, to go pan for gold.This guy on the left, Dr. Richard Beverley Cole, he lived in Philadelphia and he took the Panama route. They would take a ship down to Panama, across the isthmus, and then take another ship north. This guy, Dr. Toland, went by covered wagon to California. This has its parallels, too.
