precisely because it is atheistic.

00:05:40.295 --> 00:05:44.048
Now, the difficult problem
for any theory of biological design

00:05:44.072 --> 00:05:49.334
is to explain the massive statistical
improbability of living things.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:54.730
Statistical improbability
in the direction of good design --

00:05:54.754 --> 00:05:56.642
"complexity" is another word for this.

00:05:57.227 --> 00:05:58.974
The standard creationist argument --

00:05:58.998 --> 00:06:01.934
there is only one;
they're all reduced to this one --

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.338
takes off from
a statistical improbability.

00:06:04.362 --> 00:06:07.648
Living creatures are too complex
to have come about by chance;

00:06:07.672 --> 00:06:09.934
therefore, they must have had a designer.

00:06:10.552 --> 00:06:12.996
This argument of course,
shoots itself in the foot.

00:06:13.020 --> 00:06:16.335
Any designer capable of designing
something really complex

00:06:16.359 --> 00:06:18.940
has to be even more complex himself,

00:06:18.964 --> 00:06:22.934
and that's before we even start
on the other things he's expected to do,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.872
like forgive sins, bless
marriages, listen to prayers --

00:06:26.896 --> 00:06:28.934
favor our side in a war --

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.344
(Laughter)

00:06:31.368 --> 00:06:33.934
disapprove of our sex lives, and so on.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.934
(Laughter)

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:40.934
Complexity is the problem
that any theory of biology has to solve,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:45.665
and you can't solve it by postulating
an agent that is even more complex,

00:06:45.689 --> 00:06:48.299
thereby simply compounding the problem.

00:06:48.886 --> 00:06:53.283
Darwinian natural selection
is so stunningly elegant

00:06:53.307 --> 00:06:57.132
because it solves the problem
of explaining complexity

00:06:57.156 --> 00:07:00.211
in terms of nothing but simplicity.

00:07:01.052 --> 00:07:04.321
Essentially, it does it
by providing a smooth ramp

00:07:04.345 --> 00:07:07.660
of gradual, step-by-step increment.

00:07:08.715 --> 00:07:10.588
But here, I only want to make the point

00:07:10.612 --> 00:07:14.302
that the elegance of Darwinism
is corrosive to religion,

00:07:14.326 --> 00:07:18.934
precisely because it is so elegant,
so parsimonious, so powerful,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.672
so economically powerful.

00:07:23.243 --> 00:07:29.140
It has the sinewy economy
of a beautiful suspension bridge.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.549
The God theory is not just a bad theory.

00:07:32.573 --> 00:07:34.343
It turns out to be -- in principle --

00:07:34.367 --> 00:07:37.934
incapable of doing the job required of it.

00:07:38.422 --> 00:07:41.533
So, returning to tactics
and the evolution lobby,

00:07:41.557 --> 00:07:44.679
I want to argue that rocking the boat

00:07:44.703 --> 00:07:49.410
may be just the right thing to do.

00:07:50.410 --> 00:07:53.006
My approach to attacking creationism is --

00:07:53.030 --> 00:07:55.513
unlike the evolution lobby --

00:07:55.537 --> 00:08:00.267
my approach to attacking creationism
is to attack religion as a whole.

00:08:01.314 --> 00:08:05.576
And at this point I need
to acknowledge the remarkable taboo

00:08:05.600 --> 00:08:08.086
against speaking ill of religion,

00:08:08.110 --> 00:08:11.459
and I'm going to do so in the words
of the late Douglas Adams,

00:08:11.483 --> 00:08:13.722
a dear friend who,
if he never came to TED,

00:08:13.746 --> 00:08:15.728
certainly should have been invited.

00:08:15.752 --> 00:08:17.219
(Richard Saul Wurman: He was.)

00:08:17.243 --> 00:08:20.266
Richard Dawkins: He was. Good.
I thought he must have been.

00:08:20.290 --> 00:08:23.134
He begins this speech,
which was tape recorded in Cambridge

00:08:23.158 --> 00:08:24.934
shortly before he died --

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:29.531
he begins by explaining how science
works through the testing of hypotheses

00:08:29.555 --> 00:08:33.158
that are framed to be vulnerable
to disproof, and then he goes on.

00:08:33.182 --> 00:08:36.934
I quote, "Religion doesn't
seem to work like that.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.934
It has certain ideas at the heart of it,
which we call 'sacred' or 'holy.'

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.934
What it means is:
here is an idea or a notion

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:47.613
that you're not allowed
to say anything bad about.

00:08:47.637 --> 00:08:51.934
You're just not. Why not?
Because you're not."

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:55.862
(Laughter)

00:08:55.886 --> 00:08:58.307
"Why should it be
that it's perfectly legitimate

00:08:58.331 --> 00:09:00.320
to support the Republicans or Democrats,

00:09:00.344 --> 00:09:02.704
this model of economics versus that,

00:09:02.728 --> 00:09:04.693
Macintosh instead of Windows,

00:09:04.717 --> 00:09:07.678
but to have an opinion
about how the universe began,

00:09:07.702 --> 00:09:09.338
about who created the universe --

00:09:09.362 --> 00:09:11.011
no, that's holy.

00:09:11.742 --> 00:09:15.108
So, we're used to not
challenging religious ideas,

00:09:15.132 --> 00:09:18.322
and it's very interesting how much
of a furor Richard creates

00:09:18.346 --> 00:09:19.505
when he does it." --

00:09:19.529 --> 00:09:21.329
He meant me, not that one.

00:09:22.536 --> 00:09:24.934
"Everybody gets absolutely
frantic about it,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.546
because you're not allowed
to say these things.

00:09:27.570 --> 00:09:29.267
Yet when you look at it rationally,

00:09:29.291 --> 00:09:31.387
there's no reason why those ideas

00:09:31.411 --> 00:09:34.086
shouldn't be as open
to debate as any other,

00:09:34.110 --> 00:09:37.179
except that we've agreed
somehow between us

00:09:37.203 --> 00:09:38.577
that they shouldn't be."

00:09:38.941 --> 00:09:41.258
And that's the end
of the quote from Douglas.

00:09:43.822 --> 00:09:47.934
In my view, not only is science
corrosive to religion;

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.109
religion is corrosive to science.

00:09:51.656 --> 00:09:55.529
It teaches people
to be satisfied with trivial,

00:09:55.553 --> 00:09:58.576
supernatural non-explanations,

00:09:58.600 --> 00:10:02.331
and blinds them to the wonderful,
real explanations

00:10:02.355 --> 00:10:03.934
that we have within our grasp.

00:10:04.553 --> 00:10:10.594
It teaches them to accept
authority, revelation and faith,

00:10:10.618 --> 00:10:14.087
instead of always insisting on evidence.

00:10:16.039 --> 00:10:20.578
There's Douglas Adams, magnificent picture
from his book, "Last Chance to See."

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.618
Now, there's a typical scientific journal,

00:10:24.642 --> 00:10:26.275
The Quarterly Review of Biology.

00:10:26.299 --> 00:10:29.155
And I'm going to put
together, as guest editor,

00:10:29.179 --> 00:10:34.424
a special issue on the question,
"Did an asteroid kill the dinosaurs?"

00:10:34.448 --> 00:10:38.545
And the first paper
is a standard scientific paper,

00:10:38.569 --> 00:10:40.444
presenting evidence,

00:10:40.468 --> 00:10:42.203
"Iridium layer at the K-T boundary,

00:10:42.227 --> 00:10:44.648
and potassium argon dated
crater in Yucatan,

00:10:44.672 --> 00:10:47.283
indicate that an asteroid
killed the dinosaurs."

00:10:47.307 --> 00:10:49.934
Perfectly ordinary scientific paper.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.491
Now, the next one.

00:10:51.515 --> 00:10:54.180
"The President of the Royal Society

00:10:54.204 --> 00:10:58.692
has been vouchsafed
a strong inner conviction

00:10:58.716 --> 00:11:01.219
that an asteroid killed the dinosaurs."

00:11:01.243 --> 00:11:03.196
(Laughter)

00:11:05.488 --> 00:11:11.290
"It has been privately
revealed to Professor Huxtane

00:11:11.314 --> 00:11:13.235
that an asteroid killed the dinosaurs."

00:11:13.259 --> 00:11:14.647
(Laughter)

00:11:16.918 --> 00:11:19.219
"Professor Hordley was brought up

00:11:19.243 --> 00:11:21.934
to have total and unquestioning faith" --

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:22.990
(Laughter) --

00:11:23.014 --> 00:11:27.810
"that an asteroid killed the dinosaurs."

00:11:30.417 --> 00:11:34.934
"Professor Hawkins has
promulgated an official dogma

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:38.402
binding on all loyal Hawkinsians

00:11:38.426 --> 00:11:41.295
that an asteroid killed the dinosaurs."

00:11:41.319 --> 00:11:43.259
(Laughter)

00:11:44.481 --> 00:11:47.782
That's inconceivable, of course.

00:11:48.806 --> 00:11:50.036
But suppose --

00:11:50.060 --> 00:11:53.106
[Supporters of the Asteroid Theory
cannot be patriotic citizens]

00:11:53.130 --> 00:11:54.845
(Laughter)

00:11:54.869 --> 00:11:57.488
(Applause)

00:11:59.732 --> 00:12:02.934
In 1987, a reporter asked George Bush, Sr.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:06.776
whether he recognized
the equal citizenship and patriotism

00:12:06.800 --> 00:12:08.934
of Americans who are atheists.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.934
Mr. Bush's reply has become infamous.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.934
"No, I don't know that atheists
should be considered citizens,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.934
nor should they be considered patriots.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.592
This is one nation under God."

00:12:21.529 --> 00:12:24.148
Bush's bigotry
was not an isolated mistake,

00:12:24.172 --> 00:12:27.457
blurted out in the heat
of the moment and later retracted.

00:12:27.481 --> 00:12:32.328
He stood by it in the face of repeated
calls for clarification or withdrawal.

00:12:32.352 --> 00:12:33.582
He really meant it.

00:12:33.606 --> 00:12:38.161
More to the point, he knew
it posed no threat to his election --

00:12:38.185 --> 00:12:39.367
quite the contrary.

00:12:39.391 --> 00:12:43.121
Democrats as well as Republicans
parade their religiousness

00:12:43.145 --> 00:12:44.869
if they want to get elected.

00:12:44.893 --> 00:12:49.053
Both parties invoke
"one nation under God."

00:12:49.077 --> 00:12:51.389
What would Thomas Jefferson have said?

00:12:51.413 --> 00:12:55.039
[In every country and in every age,
the priest has been hostile to liberty]

00:12:55.063 --> 00:12:58.934
Incidentally, I'm not usually
very proud of being British,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.934
but you can't help making the comparison.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:09.927
(Applause)

00:13:11.443 --> 00:13:13.934
In practice, what is an atheist?

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:18.266
An atheist is just somebody
who feels about Yahweh

00:13:18.290 --> 00:13:24.553
the way any decent Christian feels
about Thor or Baal or the golden calf.

00:13:24.577 --> 00:13:28.934
As has been said before, we are
all atheists about most of the gods

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.263
that humanity has ever believed in.

00:13:31.287 --> 00:13:33.934
Some of us just go one god further.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.934
(Laughter)

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:43.934
(Applause)

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.292
And however we define atheism,
it's surely the kind of academic belief

00:13:47.316 --> 00:13:50.934
that a person is entitled
to hold without being vilified

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:55.114
as an unpatriotic,
unelectable non-citizen.

00:13:56.003 --> 00:13:59.387
Nevertheless, it's an undeniable fact
that to own up to being an atheist

00:13:59.411 --> 00:14:03.951
is tantamount to introducing yourself
as Mr. Hitler or Miss Beelzebub.

00:14:04.541 --> 00:14:08.243
And that all stems
from the perception of atheists

00:14:08.267 --> 00:14:12.172
as some kind of weird, way-out minority.

00:14:12.847 --> 00:14:15.934
Natalie Angier wrote a rather
sad piece in the New Yorker,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.021
saying how lonely she felt as an atheist.

00:14:18.378 --> 00:14:20.816
She clearly feels
in a beleaguered minority.

00:14:20.840 --> 00:14:26.095
But actually, how do American atheists
stack up numerically?

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.857
The latest survey makes
surprisingly encouraging reading.

00:14:30.254 --> 00:14:33.684
Christianity, of course, takes a massive
lion's share of the population,

00:14:33.708 --> 00:14:35.302
with nearly 160 million.

00:14:36.214 --> 00:14:39.691
But what would you think
was the second largest group,

00:14:39.715 --> 00:14:45.151
convincingly outnumbering Jews
with 2.8 million, Muslims at 1.1 million,

00:14:45.175 --> 00:14:48.825
Hindus, Buddhists and all other
religions put together?

00:14:48.849 --> 00:14:51.492
The second largest group,
with nearly 30 million,

00:14:51.516 --> 00:14:54.706
is the one described
as non-religious or secular.

00:14:55.659 --> 00:14:58.934
You can't help wondering
why vote-seeking politicians

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:04.140
are so proverbially overawed by the power
of, for example, the Jewish lobby --

00:15:04.164 --> 00:15:08.481
the state of Israel seems to owe its very
existence to the American Jewish vote --

00:15:08.505 --> 00:15:09.934
while at the same time,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:14.048
consigning the non-religious
to political oblivion.

00:15:15.302 --> 00:15:18.934
This secular non-religious vote,
if properly mobilized,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.871
is nine times as numerous
as the Jewish vote.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.934
Why does this far more
substantial minority

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.165
not make a move to exercise
its political muscle?

00:15:30.243 --> 00:15:33.013
Well, so much for quantity.
How about quality?

00:15:33.497 --> 00:15:36.600
Is there any correlation,
positive or negative,

00:15:36.624 --> 00:15:40.635
between intelligence
and tendency to be religious?

00:15:40.659 --> 00:15:42.896
[Them folks misunderestimated me]

00:15:42.920 --> 00:15:47.008
(Laughter)

00:15:47.540 --> 00:15:50.934
The survey that I quoted,
which is the ARIS survey,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:54.006
didn't break down its data
by socio-economic class or education,

00:15:54.030 --> 00:15:55.752
IQ or anything else.

00:15:55.776 --> 00:15:59.934
But a recent article by Paul G. Bell
in the Mensa magazine

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.934
provides some straws in the wind.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.435
Mensa, as you know,
is an international organization

00:16:04.459 --> 00:16:07.769
for people with very high IQ.

00:16:07.793 --> 00:16:12.728
And from a meta-analysis
of the literature,

00:16:12.752 --> 00:16:17.934
Bell concludes that, I quote --
"Of 43 studies carried out since 1927

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.253
on the relationship
between religious belief,

00:16:20.277 --> 00:16:22.743
and one's intelligence
or educational level,

00:16:22.767 --> 00:16:26.934
all but four found an inverse connection.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:30.575
That is, the higher one's intelligence
or educational level,

00:16:30.599 --> 00:16:32.934
the less one is likely to be religious."

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.133
Well, I haven't seen
the original 42 studies,

00:16:35.157 --> 00:16:38.165
and I can't comment on that meta-analysis,

00:16:38.189 --> 00:16:41.902
but I would like to see more
studies done along those lines.

00:16:41.926 --> 00:16:44.989
And I know that there are --
if I could put a little plug here --

00:16:45.013 --> 00:16:46.609
there are people in this audience

00:16:46.633 --> 00:16:51.934
easily capable of financing a massive
research survey to settle the question,

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.543
and I put the suggestion up,
for what it's worth.

00:16:54.567 --> 00:16:56.217
But let me know show you some data

00:16:56.241 --> 00:16:58.470
that have been properly
published and analyzed,

00:16:58.494 --> 00:17:02.486
on one special group --
namely, top scientists.

00:17:03.402 --> 00:17:08.934
In 1998, Larson and Witham
polled the cream of American scientists,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.649
those who'd been honored by election
to the National Academy of Sciences,

00:17:12.673 --> 00:17:15.304
and among this select group,

00:17:15.328 --> 00:17:20.775
belief in a personal God dropped
to a shattering seven percent.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:26.705
About 20 percent are agnostic;
the rest could fairly be called atheists.

00:17:26.729 --> 00:17:29.934
Similar figures obtained
for belief in personal immortality.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.934
Among biological scientists,
the figure is even lower:

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.713
5.5 percent, only, believe in God.

00:17:36.737 --> 00:17:39.934
Physical scientists, it's 7.5 percent.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.934
I've not seen corresponding
figures for elite scholars

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.934
in other fields,
such as history or philosophy,

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.132
but I'd be surprised
if they were different.

00:17:49.449 --> 00:17:52.672
So, we've reached a truly
remarkable situation,

00:17:52.696 --> 00:17:57.711
a grotesque mismatch
between the American intelligentsia

00:17:57.735 --> 00:17:59.504
and the American electorate.

00:18:00.322 --> 00:18:03.934
A philosophical opinion
about the nature of the universe,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:07.934
which is held by the vast majority
of top American scientists

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:11.814
and probably the majority
of the intelligentsia generally,

00:18:11.838 --> 00:18:14.638
is so abhorrent to the American electorate

00:18:14.662 --> 00:18:19.566
that no candidate for popular election
dare affirm it in public.

00:18:20.035 --> 00:18:22.934
If I'm right, this means that high office

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:25.604
in the greatest country in the world

00:18:25.628 --> 00:18:29.715
is barred to the very people
best qualified to hold it --

00:18:29.739 --> 00:18:30.934
the intelligentsia --

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.934
unless they are prepared
to lie about their beliefs.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:37.452
To put it bluntly:
American political opportunities

00:18:37.476 --> 00:18:39.934
are heavily loaded against those

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.743
who are simultaneously
intelligent and honest.

00:18:42.767 --> 00:18:43.973
(Laughter)

00:18:43.997 --> 00:18:50.308
(Applause)

00:18:50.332 --> 00:18:53.934
I'm not a citizen of this country,
so I hope it won't be thought unbecoming

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.934
if I suggest that something
needs to be done.

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:59.458
(Laughter)

00:18:59.482 --> 00:19:01.934
And I've already hinted
what that something is.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.715
From what I've seen of TED, I think this
may be the ideal place to launch it.

00:19:06.437 --> 00:19:08.588
Again, I fear it will cost money.

00:19:08.612 --> 00:19:11.159
We need a consciousness-raising,

00:19:11.183 --> 00:19:14.934
coming-out campaign for American atheists.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:16.934
(Laughter)

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:20.678
This could be similar to the campaign
organized by homosexuals

00:19:20.702 --> 00:19:21.934
a few years ago,

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:25.291
although heaven forbid
that we should stoop to public outing

00:19:25.315 --> 00:19:26.934
of people against their will.

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:29.934
In most cases, people who out themselves

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:33.934
will help to destroy the myth that
there is something wrong with atheists.

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:35.111
On the contrary,

00:19:35.135 --> 00:19:38.205
they'll demonstrate that atheists
are often the kinds of people

00:19:38.229 --> 00:19:40.934
who could serve as decent
role models for your children,

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:45.725
the kinds of people an advertising agent
could use to recommend a product,

00:19:45.749 --> 00:19:48.581
the kinds of people
who are sitting in this room.

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:52.934
There should be a snowball effect,
a positive feedback,

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:55.934
such that the more names
we have, the more we get.

00:19:56.548 --> 00:19:59.317
There could be non-linearities,
threshold effects.

00:19:59.341 --> 00:20:01.420
When a critical mass has been obtained,

00:20:01.444 --> 00:20:04.349
there's an abrupt
acceleration in recruitment.

00:20:04.373 --> 00:20:06.087
And again, it will need money.

00:20:07.452 --> 00:20:10.934
I suspect that the word "atheist" itself

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:14.425
contains or remains a stumbling block

00:20:14.449 --> 00:20:17.125
far out of proportion
to what it actually means,

00:20:17.149 --> 00:20:18.722
and a stumbling block to people

00:20:18.746 --> 00:20:21.803
who otherwise might be
happy to out themselves.

00:20:21.827 --> 00:20:24.552
So, what other words might
be used to smooth the path,

00:20:24.576 --> 00:20:27.124
oil the wheels, sugar the pill?

00:20:28.340 --> 00:20:31.338
Darwin himself preferred "agnostic" --

00:20:31.362 --> 00:20:34.466
and not only out of loyalty
to his friend Huxley,

00:20:34.490 --> 00:20:36.017
who coined the term.

00:20:36.691 --> 00:20:39.524
Darwin said, "I have never been an atheist

00:20:39.548 --> 00:20:42.246
in the same sense of denying
the existence of a God.

00:20:42.754 --> 00:20:44.934
I think that generally an 'agnostic'

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:48.066
would be the most correct
description of my state of mind."

00:20:48.804 --> 00:20:53.622
He even became uncharacteristically
tetchy with Edward Aveling.

00:20:54.217 --> 00:20:55.934
Aveling was a militant atheist

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:57.934
who failed to persuade Darwin

00:20:57.958 --> 00:21:00.934
to accept the dedication
of his book on atheism --

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:03.648
incidentally, giving rise
to a fascinating myth

00:21:03.672 --> 00:21:07.069
that Karl Marx tried to dedicate
"Das Kapital" to Darwin,

00:21:07.093 --> 00:21:09.461
which he didn't, it was
actually Edward Aveling.

00:21:09.485 --> 00:21:13.934
What happened was that Aveling's
mistress was Marx's daughter,

00:21:13.958 --> 00:21:17.239
and when both Darwin and Marx were dead,

00:21:17.263 --> 00:21:21.477
Marx's papers became muddled
up with Aveling's papers,

00:21:21.501 --> 00:21:25.808
and a letter from Darwin saying,
"My dear sir, thank you very much

00:21:25.832 --> 00:21:28.195
but I don't want you
to dedicate your book to me,"

00:21:28.219 --> 00:21:31.472
was mistakenly supposed
to be addressed to Marx,

00:21:31.496 --> 00:21:34.813
and that gave rise to this whole
myth, which you've probably heard.

00:21:34.837 --> 00:21:39.376
It's a sort of urban myth, that Marx
tried to dedicate "Kapital" to Darwin.

00:21:39.400 --> 00:21:45.767
Anyway, it was Aveling, and when
they met, Darwin challenged Aveling.

00:21:46.640 --> 00:21:50.479
"Why do you call yourselves atheists?"

00:21:54.106 --> 00:21:58.393
"'Agnostic, '" retorted Aveling, "was
simply 'atheist' writ respectable,

00:21:58.417 --> 00:22:02.226
and 'atheist' was simply
'agnostic' writ aggressive."

00:22:02.250 --> 00:22:05.472
Darwin complained, "But why
should you be so aggressive?"

00:22:06.099 --> 00:22:09.695
Darwin thought that atheism might be
well and good for the intelligentsia,

00:22:09.719 --> 00:22:12.957
but that ordinary people were
not, quote, "ripe for it."

00:22:13.815 --> 00:22:17.219
Which is, of course, our old friend,
the "don't rock the boat" argument.

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:22.934
It's not recorded whether Aveling told
Darwin to come down off his high horse.

00:22:22.958 --> 00:22:24.785
(Laughter)

00:22:24.809 --> 00:22:27.159
But in any case,
that was more than 100 years ago.

00:22:27.183 --> 00:22:29.571
You'd think we might have
grown up since then.

00:22:30.087 --> 00:22:35.351
Now, a friend, an intelligent lapsed Jew,

00:22:35.375 --> 00:22:39.500
who, incidentally, observes the Sabbath
for reasons of cultural solidarity,

00:22:39.524 --> 00:22:43.116
describes himself
as a "tooth-fairy agnostic."

00:22:44.024 --> 00:22:45.587
He won't call himself an atheist

00:22:45.611 --> 00:22:48.934
because it's, in principle,
impossible to prove a negative,

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:51.934
but "agnostic" on its own might
suggest that God's existence

00:22:51.958 --> 00:22:57.100
was therefore on equal terms
of likelihood as his non-existence.

00:22:57.124 --> 00:23:01.441
So, my friend is strictly
agnostic about the tooth fairy,

00:23:01.465 --> 00:23:04.458
but it isn't very likely, is it?

00:23:04.482 --> 00:23:05.934
Like God.

00:23:05.958 --> 00:23:07.965
Hence the phrase, "tooth-fairy agnostic."

00:23:08.287 --> 00:23:10.049
Bertrand Russell made the same point

00:23:10.073 --> 00:23:13.636
using a hypothetical teapot
in orbit about Mars.

00:23:14.096 --> 00:23:15.934
You would strictly have to be agnostic

00:23:15.958 --> 00:23:18.387
about whether there is a teapot
in orbit about Mars,

00:23:18.411 --> 00:23:21.411
but that doesn't mean you treat
the likelihood of its existence

00:23:21.435 --> 00:23:24.239
as on all fours with its non-existence.

00:23:24.263 --> 00:23:27.568
The list of things which we strictly
have to be agnostic about

00:23:27.592 --> 00:23:30.934
doesn't stop at tooth fairies
and teapots; it's infinite.

00:23:30.958 --> 00:23:33.435
If you want to believe
one particular one of them --

00:23:33.459 --> 00:23:37.539
unicorns or tooth fairies
or teapots or Yahweh --

00:23:37.563 --> 00:23:39.934
the onus is on you to say why.

00:23:39.958 --> 00:23:43.316
The onus is not on the rest
of us to say why not.

00:23:43.958 --> 00:23:45.340
We, who are atheists,

00:23:45.364 --> 00:23:48.755
are also a-fairyists and a-teapotists.

00:23:48.779 --> 00:23:51.420
(Laughter)

00:23:51.444 --> 00:23:53.032
But we don't bother to say so.

00:23:53.801 --> 00:23:57.627
And this is why my friend
uses "tooth-fairy agnostic"

00:23:57.651 --> 00:24:00.226
as a label for what most people
would call atheist.

00:24:00.637 --> 00:24:06.056
Nonetheless, if we want to attract
deep-down atheists to come out publicly,

00:24:06.080 --> 00:24:09.169
we're going to have find
something better to stick on our banner

00:24:09.193 --> 00:24:11.691
than "tooth-fairy" or "teapot agnostic."

00:24:12.601 --> 00:24:14.133
So, how about "humanist"?

00:24:16.538 --> 00:24:20.934
This has the advantage of a worldwide
network of well-organized associations

00:24:20.958 --> 00:24:22.934
and journals and things already in place.

00:24:22.958 --> 00:24:25.906
My problem with it is only
its apparent anthropocentrism.

00:24:25.930 --> 00:24:27.936
One of the things
we've learned from Darwin

00:24:27.960 --> 00:24:30.436
is that the human species is only one

00:24:30.460 --> 00:24:34.264
among millions of cousins,
some close, some distant.

00:24:34.288 --> 00:24:36.821
And there are other possibilities,
like "naturalist,"

00:24:36.845 --> 00:24:39.280
but that also has problems of confusion,

00:24:39.304 --> 00:24:41.510
because Darwin would have
thought naturalist --

00:24:41.534 --> 00:24:44.669
"Naturalist" means, of course,
as opposed to "supernaturalist" --

00:24:44.693 --> 00:24:46.057
and it is used sometimes --

00:24:46.081 --> 00:24:49.475
Darwin would have been confused
by the other sense of "naturalist,"

00:24:49.499 --> 00:24:50.690
which he was, of course,

00:24:50.714 --> 00:24:55.706
and I suppose there might be others
who would confuse it with "nudism".

00:24:55.730 --> 00:24:56.948
(Laughter)

00:24:56.972 --> 00:25:03.870
Such people might be those
belonging to the British lynch mob,

00:25:03.894 --> 00:25:08.934
which last year attacked a pediatrician
in mistake for a pedophile.

00:25:08.958 --> 00:25:12.483
(Laughter)

00:25:14.507 --> 00:25:17.667
I think the best of the available
alternatives for "atheist"

00:25:17.691 --> 00:25:18.934
is simply "non-theist."

00:25:18.958 --> 00:25:21.958
It lacks the strong connotation
that there's definitely no God,

00:25:21.982 --> 00:25:27.841
and it could therefore easily be embraced
by teapot or tooth-fairy agnostics.

00:25:27.865 --> 00:25:33.396
It's completely compatible
with the God of the physicists.

00:25:33.420 --> 00:25:39.934
When atheists like Stephen Hawking
and Albert Einstein use the word "God,"

00:25:39.958 --> 00:25:43.671
they use it of course
as a metaphorical shorthand

00:25:43.695 --> 00:25:48.266
for that deep, mysterious part of physics
which we don't yet understand.

00:25:49.179 --> 00:25:54.195
"Non-theist" will do for all that,
yet unlike "atheist,"

00:25:54.219 --> 00:26:01.068
it doesn't have the same
phobic, hysterical responses.

00:26:01.516 --> 00:26:03.370
But I think, actually, the alternative

00:26:03.394 --> 00:26:06.243
is to grasp the nettle
of the word "atheism" itself,

00:26:06.267 --> 00:26:08.934
precisely because it is a taboo word,

00:26:08.958 --> 00:26:12.236
carrying frissons of hysterical phobia.

00:26:13.172 --> 00:26:16.604
Critical mass may be harder
to achieve with the word "atheist"

00:26:16.628 --> 00:26:18.183
than with the word "non-theist,"

00:26:18.207 --> 00:26:20.167
or some other non-confrontational word.

00:26:20.643 --> 00:26:24.405
But if we did achieve it
with that dread word "atheist" itself,

00:26:24.429 --> 00:26:27.222
the political impact
would be even greater.

00:26:28.301 --> 00:26:31.706
Now, I said that if I were religious,
I'd be very afraid of evolution --

00:26:31.730 --> 00:26:35.364
I'd go further: I would fear science
in general, if properly understood.

00:26:35.388 --> 00:26:38.601
And this is because
the scientific worldview

00:26:38.625 --> 00:26:41.690
is so much more exciting, more poetic,

00:26:41.714 --> 00:26:44.191
more filled with sheer wonder

00:26:44.215 --> 00:26:49.251
than anything in the poverty-stricken
arsenals of the religious imagination.

00:26:51.195 --> 00:26:55.934
As Carl Sagan, another recently
dead hero, put it,

00:26:55.958 --> 00:27:00.524
"How is it that hardly any major
religion has looked at science

00:27:00.548 --> 00:27:04.843
and concluded, 'This
is better than we thought!

00:27:04.867 --> 00:27:07.339
The universe is much bigger
than our prophet said,

00:27:07.363 --> 00:27:10.570
grander, more subtle, more elegant'?

00:27:10.594 --> 00:27:12.934
Instead they say, 'No, no, no!

00:27:12.958 --> 00:27:16.592
My god is a little god,
and I want him to stay that way.'

00:27:18.137 --> 00:27:20.267
A religion, old or new,

00:27:20.291 --> 00:27:22.934
that stressed the magnificence
of the universe

00:27:22.958 --> 00:27:24.934
as revealed by modern science,

00:27:24.958 --> 00:27:28.622
might be able to draw forth
reserves of reverence and awe

00:27:28.646 --> 00:27:31.583
hardly tapped by the conventional faiths."

00:27:33.178 --> 00:27:36.314
Now, this is an elite audience,

00:27:36.338 --> 00:27:41.092
and I would therefore expect
about 10 percent of you to be religious.

00:27:42.862 --> 00:27:47.341
Many of you probably subscribe
to our polite cultural belief

00:27:47.365 --> 00:27:49.554
that we should respect religion.

00:27:50.261 --> 00:27:53.934
But I also suspect
that a fair number of those

00:27:53.958 --> 00:27:57.315
secretly despise religion as much as I do.

00:27:57.727 --> 00:27:58.986
(Laughter)

00:27:59.010 --> 00:28:01.863
If you're one of them, and of course
many of you may not be,

00:28:01.887 --> 00:28:03.195
but if you are one of them,

00:28:03.219 --> 00:28:05.287
I'm asking you to stop being polite,

00:28:05.311 --> 00:28:07.120
come out, and say so.

00:28:08.071 --> 00:28:10.070
And if you happen to be rich,

00:28:10.094 --> 00:28:13.676
give some thought to ways
in which you might make a difference.

00:28:14.327 --> 00:28:16.697
The religious lobby in this country

00:28:16.721 --> 00:28:22.251
is massively financed by foundations --
to say nothing of all the tax benefits --

00:28:22.275 --> 00:28:26.799
by foundations, such as the Templeton
Foundation and the Discovery Institute.

00:28:27.473 --> 00:28:31.140
We need an anti-Templeton to step forward.

00:28:32.751 --> 00:28:35.934
If my books sold as well
as Stephen Hawking's books,

00:28:35.958 --> 00:28:39.904
instead of only as well as
Richard Dawkins' books, I'd do it myself.

00:28:43.412 --> 00:28:49.710
People are always going on about,
"How did September the 11th change you?"

00:28:50.829 --> 00:28:52.451
Well, here's how it changed me.

00:28:53.427 --> 00:28:57.092
Let's all stop being so damned respectful.

00:28:58.338 --> 00:28:59.934
Thank you very much.

00:28:59.958 --> 00:29:04.958
(Applause)

title: Technology's long tail
transcript: I'd like to speak about technology trends, which is something that many of you follow — but we also follow, for related reasons. Obviously, being a technology magazine, technology trends are something that we write about and need to know about.But also it's part of being any monthly magazine — you live in the future. And we have a long lead-time. We have to plan issues many months in advance; we have to guess at what public appetites are going to be six months, nine months down the road. So we're in the forecasting business.We also, like a lot of companies, create a product that's based on technology trends. In this case, ours is about ideas and information, and, if we're lucky, some entertainment. But the concept's quite the same. And so we have to understand not only why tech's important, where it's going, but also, very importantly, when — the timing is everything.And it's interesting, when you look at the predictions made during the peak of the boom in the 1990s, about e-commerce, or Internet traffic, or broadband adoption, or Internet advertising, they were all right — they were just wrong in time. Almost every one of those has come true just a few years later. But the difference of a few years on stock-market valuations is obviously extreme. And that's why timing is everything.You've probably seen something like this before. This is the classic Gartner Hype Curve, which talks about kind of the trajectory of a technology's lifespan. And just for fun, we put a bunch of technologies on it, to show whether they were kind of rising for the first high peak, or whether they were about to crash into the trough of disillusionment, or rise back in the slope of enlightenment, etc. And this is one way to do technology forecasting: get a sense of where technology is and then anticipate the next upturn.We tend to do any technology that we think is sufficiently important; we'll typically do it twice. Once, we want to do it first. We want to be the first to do it, for the geeks who appreciate that, we'll catch it right there at the technology-trigger. You can see in 1997, we put Linux on the cover. But then it comes back. And sufficiently big technologies are going to hit the mainstream, and they're going to burst out. And then it's time to do it again. Last year. And that's one way that we try to time technology trends.I'd like to talk about a way of thinking about technology trends that I call my "grand unified theory of predicting the future," but it's closer to a petite unified theory of predicting the future. It's based on the presumption, the observation even, that all important technologies go through four stages in their life — at least one of the four stages, sometimes all four of the stages. And at each one of these stages, can be seen as a collision — a collision with something else — for example, a critical price-line that changes both the technology and also changes its effect on the world. It's an inflection point. And these are the inflection points that tell you what the next chapter in that technology's life is going to be, and maybe how you can do something about it.The first is the critical price. The first stage in a technology's advance is that it'll fall below a critical price. After it falls below a critical price, it will tend, if it's successful, to rise above a critical mass, a penetration. Many technologies, at that point, displace another technology, and that's another important point. And then finally, a lot of technologies commoditize. Towards the end of their life, they become nearly free.Each one of those is an opportunity to do something about it; it's an opportunity for the technology to change. And even if you missed, you know, the first boom of Wi-Fi — you know, Wi-Fi did the critical price, it did the critical mass, but hasn't done displacement yet, and hasn't done free yet — there's still more opportunity in that.I'd like to demonstrate what I mean by this by telling the story of the DVD, which is a technology which has done all of these. The DVD, as you know, was introduced in the mid-1990s and it was quite expensive. But you can see that by 1998, it had fallen below 400 dollars, and 400 dollars was a psychological threshold. And it started to take off. And you can see that the units started to trend up, the hidden inflection point — it was taking off.The next thing it hit, a year later, was critical mass. In this case, 20 percent is often a good proxy for critical mass in a household. And what's interesting here is that something else took off along with it: home-theater units. Suddenly you have a DVD in the house; you've got high-quality digital video; you have a reason to have a big-screen television; you have a reason for Dolby 5.1 surround-sound. And maybe you have reasons for starting to connect them, and bring the rest of your entertainment in. What's interesting also is — note that Netflix was founded in 1999. Reed Hastings is here. He clearly saw that that was a moment, that was an inflection point that he could do something with.The next phase it hit was displacement. You can see around 2001 it finally out-sold the VCR. And here too, you can see the implications in the world at large. Netflix was right — the Netflix model could capitalize on the DVD in a way that the video-rental stores couldn't. Among the DVD's many assets is that it's very small; you can stick it in the mailer and post it cheaply. That gave an advantage; that was an implication of the technology's rise that wasn't obvious to everybody.And then finally, DVDs are approaching free. There's a company called Apex, a no-name Chinese firm, who has, several times in the past year, been the number-one DVD seller in America. Their average price, for last year, was 48 dollars. You're aware of the perhaps apocryphal Wal-Mart stampede over the 30-dollar DVD. But they're getting very, very cheap, and look at the interesting implication of it. As they get cheaper, the premium brands, the Sonys and such, are losing market share, and the no-names, the Apexes, are gaining them. They're being commodified, and that's what happens when things go to zero. It's a tough market out there. (Laughter)Now they've introduced these four ways of looking at technology, these four stages of technology's life. I'd like to talk about some other technologies out there, just technologies on our radar — and I'll use this lens, these four, as a way to kind of tell you where each one of those technologies is in its development. They're not necessarily the top-10 technologies out there — they're just examples of technologies that are in each one of these periods. But I think that the implications of them approaching these crossovers, these intersections, are interesting to think about.Start with gene sequencing. As you probably know, gene sequencing — in a large part, because it's built on computers — is falling in price at a kind of a Moore's Law-like level. It is now possible — will be possible, and if Craig Venter indeed comes today, he may tell you something about this — to sequence the human genome for 40 million dollars by the end of this year. That's as opposed to billions just a few years ago. You know, our ability to capture the tools of creation is getting closer and closer.What's interesting is that at the same time, the number of genes that we're discovering is rising very quickly. Each one of these genes has potential diagnostic test. There will come a day when you can have hundreds of thousands of tests done, very cheaply, if you want to know. You can learn about your own mosaic.Here's another technology that's approaching a critical price. This is a fascinating research from WHO that shows the effect of generic drugs on anti-retroviral drug compounds and cocktails. In January 2000, the price was 10,000 dollars, or 27 dollars a day. The generics came in, first in Brazil and elsewhere, and the effect was just dramatic on pricing. Today it's less than 50 cents a day. And what's interesting is if you look at the price elasticity, if you look at the correlation between these two, as the anti-retrovirals come down, the number of people you can treat goes radically up. And the Clinton Foundation and WHO believe that they can treat three million people worldwide by 2005 — two million in sub-Saharan Africa. And the falling price of drugs has a lot to do with that.Linux is another good example. Now we've switched to critical mass. These are now technologies that are hitting critical mass. If you look here, here's Linux in red, and it's hit 20 percent. Interestingly, it's done a crossover before, but not the crossovers that matter. The crossover that's going to matter is the one with the blue. But you can look and see the direction those lines are going, you can see that at the 20 percent, it's now taken seriously. It's not just for the geeks any more. That is, I imagine, what people in Redmond wake up in the middle of the night thinking about. (Laughter)Another technology that we see all around us out here is hybrid cars. I don't know whether anybody has a Prius 2004, but they're fantastic. And if you look at the trends here, by about 2008 — and I don't think this is a crazy forecast — they'll be two percent of auto sales. Two percent isn't 20 percent, but in the car business, which is slow moving, that's huge; that's arrival. At two percent, you start seeing them on the roads everywhere.And what's interesting about the hybrids taking off is you've now introduced electric motors to the automobile industry. It's the first radical change in automobile technology in 100 years. And once you have electric motors, you can do anything: you can change the structure of the car in any way you want. You can have regenerative braking; you can have drive-by-wire; you can have replaceable body shapes — it's a little thing that starts with a hybrid, but it can lead to a whole new era of the car.Voice Over IP is something you may have heard something about. Again, it's kind of coming out of nowhere; it's a little hard to use right now. There's a company created by the Kazaa founders called Skype. Look at these numbers. They launched it in August of last year; they already have nearly four million registered users — that's critical mass. And the same thing's happening on the carrier side. You're looking at IP taking over from some of the traditional telecom standards. This is a tipping point — if Malcolm's here, forgive me — and it's going to change the economics, and the speed, and the players in the industry. It's going to look a little bit like that.And finally, free. Free is really, really interesting. Free is something that comes with digital, because the reproduction costs are essentially free. It comes with IP, because it's such an efficient protocol. It comes with fiber optics, because there's so much bandwidth. Free is really, you know, the gift of Silicon Valley to the world. It's an economic force; it's a technical force. It's a deflationary force, if not handled right. It is abundance, as opposed to scarcity. Free is probably the most interesting thing.And here you have just the number of songs that can be stored on a hard drive. You know, there could be a film's [unclear] there, but it's basically, every song ever made could be stored on 400 dollars worth of storage by 2008. It takes that entire element, the physical element, of songs off the table. And you've seen the numbers. I mean, you know, the music industry is imploding in front of our very eyes, and Hollywood's worried as well. They're facing a force that they haven't faced before. And their response is draconian, and not necessarily the one that's going to get them out of this.And finally, I'll give you one last example of free — perhaps the most powerful of all. I mentioned fiber optics — their abundance tends to make things free. This is the price of a phone call to India per minute. And what's interesting is that it was just 1990 when it was more than two dollars a minute. India had, still has, a regulated phone system and so did we. It was surprisingly non-innovative, moved very slowly, but then there was just so much fiber out there, you couldn't hold back, and look how quickly the price fell. It's seven cents a minute, in many cases.And the consequence of cheap phone calling, free phone calling, to India, is the pissed-off programmer, is the outsourcing. It is probably one of the most dramatic shifts in globalization and one of the most powerful economic tools that we're seeing in our world today. The force of India, and then China, and any other country that can contact our markets and will work with our companies — because the communications are free — is just beginning to be felt. And I think that's probably one of the most important technology trends that we're looking at today. Thank you.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:51.958
to show whether they were kind of rising for the first high peak,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:52.958
or whether they were about to crash

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
into the trough of disillusionment,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:02:00.958
or rise back in the slope of enlightenment, etc.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
And this is one way to do technology forecasting: get a sense

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
of where technology is and then anticipate the next upturn.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
We tend to do any technology that we think is sufficiently important;

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:14.958
we'll typically do it twice. Once, we want to do it first.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
We want to be the first to do it, for the geeks who appreciate that,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
we'll catch it right there at the technology-trigger.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.958
You can see in 1997, we put Linux on the cover.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:27.958
But then it comes back. And sufficiently big technologies

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
are going to hit the mainstream, and they're going to burst out.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:34.958
And then it's time to do it again. Last year.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:38.958
And that's one way that we try to time technology trends.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
I'd like to talk about a way of thinking about technology trends

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:45.958
that I call my "grand unified theory of predicting the future,"

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:51.958
but it's closer to a petite unified theory of predicting the future.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
It's based on the presumption, the observation even,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:59.958
that all important technologies go through four stages in their life --

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:03.958
at least one of the four stages, sometimes all four of the stages.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:08.958
And at each one of these stages, can be seen as a collision --

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
a collision with something else --

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:15.958
for example, a critical price-line that changes both the technology

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
and also changes its effect on the world. It's an inflection point.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
And these are the inflection points that tell you

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:26.958
what the next chapter in that technology's life is going to be,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
and maybe how you can do something about it.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
The first is the critical price.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
The first stage in a technology's advance

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:38.958
is that it'll fall below a critical price.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
After it falls below a critical price, it will tend,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:45.958
if it's successful, to rise above a critical mass, a penetration.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:51.958
Many technologies, at that point, displace another technology,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:55.958
and that's another important point.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
And then finally, a lot of technologies commoditize.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
Towards the end of their life, they become nearly free.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
Each one of those is an opportunity to do something about it;

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
it's an opportunity for the technology to change.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:10.958
And even if you missed, you know, the first boom of Wi-Fi --

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:14.958
you know, Wi-Fi did the critical price, it did the critical mass,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
but hasn't done displacement yet, and hasn't done free yet --

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
there's still more opportunity in that.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
I'd like to demonstrate what I mean by this

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
by telling the story of the DVD,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
which is a technology which has done all of these.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
The DVD, as you know, was introduced in the mid-1990s

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:34.958
and it was quite expensive. But you can see that by 1998,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:39.958
it had fallen below 400 dollars, and 400 dollars was a psychological threshold.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:43.958
And it started to take off. And you can see that the units

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:49.958
started to trend up, the hidden inflection point -- it was taking off.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:54.958
The next thing it hit, a year later, was critical mass. In this case,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:58.958
20 percent is often a good proxy for critical mass in a household.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
And what's interesting here

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:05.958
is that something else took off along with it: home-theater units.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
Suddenly you have a DVD in the house;

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
you've got high-quality digital video;

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
you have a reason to have a big-screen television;

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
you have a reason for Dolby 5.1 surround-sound.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And maybe you have reasons for starting to connect them,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
and bring the rest of your entertainment in.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:23.958
What's interesting also is -- note that Netflix was founded in 1999.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:28.958
Reed Hastings is here. He clearly saw that that was a moment,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
that was an inflection point that he could do something with.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
The next phase it hit was displacement.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
You can see around 2001 it finally out-sold the VCR.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:44.958
And here too, you can see the implications in the world at large.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:48.958
Netflix was right -- the Netflix model could capitalize on the DVD

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
in a way that the video-rental stores couldn't.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
Among the DVD's many assets is that it's very small;

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
you can stick it in the mailer and post it cheaply.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:01.958
That gave an advantage; that was an implication

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.958
of the technology's rise that wasn't obvious to everybody.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
And then finally, DVDs are approaching free.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
There's a company called Apex, a no-name Chinese firm,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
who has, several times in the past year, been the number-one

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:21.958
DVD seller in America. Their average price, for last year, was 48 dollars.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
You're aware of the

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:27.958
perhaps apocryphal Wal-Mart stampede

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:31.958
over the 30-dollar DVD.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
But they're getting very, very cheap,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and look at the interesting implication of it. As they get cheaper,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
the premium brands, the Sonys and such, are losing market share,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
and the no-names, the Apexes, are gaining them.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
They're being commodified, and that's what happens

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:49.958
when things go to zero. It's a tough market out there.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
(Laughter)

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Now they've introduced these four ways of looking at technology,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
these four stages of technology's life.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
I'd like to talk about some other technologies out there,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
just technologies on our radar -- and I'll use this lens,

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
these four, as a way to kind of tell you

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
where each one of those technologies is in its development.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
They're not necessarily the top-10 technologies out there --

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:12.958
they're just examples of technologies

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
that are in each one of these periods.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
But I think that the implications of them approaching

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
these crossovers, these intersections, are interesting to think about.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
Start with gene sequencing.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
As you probably know, gene sequencing -- in a large part,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
because it's built on computers -- is falling in price

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
at a kind of a Moore's Law-like level.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
It is now possible -- will be possible,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
and if Craig Venter indeed comes today,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:38.958
he may tell you something about this --

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:43.958
to sequence the human genome for 40 million dollars by the end of this year.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:48.958
That's as opposed to billions just a few years ago.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:53.958
You know, our ability to capture the tools of creation

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
is getting closer and closer.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
What's interesting is that at the same time, the number of genes

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
that we're discovering is rising very quickly.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
Each one of these genes has potential diagnostic test.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
There will come a day

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
when you can have hundreds of thousands of tests done, very cheaply,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:14.958
if you want to know. You can learn about your own mosaic.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Here's another technology that's approaching a critical price.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:21.958
This is a fascinating research from WHO that shows the effect

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:28.958
of generic drugs on anti-retroviral drug compounds and cocktails.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:34.958
In January 2000, the price was 10,000 dollars, or 27 dollars a day.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
The generics came in, first in Brazil and elsewhere,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
and the effect was just dramatic on pricing.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:46.958
Today it's less than 50 cents a day.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And what's interesting is if you look at the price elasticity,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
if you look at the correlation between these two,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
as the anti-retrovirals come down, the number of people you can treat

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:03.958
goes radically up. And the Clinton Foundation and WHO

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
believe that they can treat three million people worldwide by 2005 --

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
two million in sub-Saharan Africa.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
And the falling price of drugs has a lot to do with that.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Linux is another good example.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
Now we've switched to critical mass.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
These are now technologies that are hitting critical mass.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:24.958
If you look here, here's Linux in red, and it's hit 20 percent.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
Interestingly, it's done a crossover before,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
but not the crossovers that matter.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
The crossover that's going to matter is the one with the blue.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
But you can look and see the direction those lines are going,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
you can see that at the 20 percent, it's now taken seriously.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:40.958
It's not just for the geeks any more.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
That is, I imagine, what people in Redmond

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
wake up in the middle of the night thinking about.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
(Laughter)

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
Another technology that we see all around us out here is hybrid cars.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
I don't know whether anybody has a Prius 2004, but they're fantastic.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And if you look at the trends here, by about 2008 --

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
and I don't think this is a crazy forecast --

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
they'll be two percent of auto sales.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
Two percent isn't 20 percent, but in the car business,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:10.958
which is slow moving, that's huge; that's arrival.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
At two percent, you start seeing them on the roads everywhere.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:17.958
And what's interesting about the hybrids taking off

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:21.958
is you've now introduced electric motors to the automobile industry.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:25.958
It's the first radical change in automobile technology in 100 years.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
And once you have electric motors, you can do anything:

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
you can change the structure of the car in any way you want.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
You can have regenerative braking; you can have drive-by-wire;

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
you can have replaceable body shapes --

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
it's a little thing that starts with a hybrid,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
but it can lead to a whole new era of the car.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
Voice Over IP is something you may have heard something about.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:45.958
Again, it's kind of coming out of nowhere;

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
it's a little hard to use right now.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.958
There's a company created by the Kazaa founders called Skype.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
Look at these numbers. They launched it in August of last year;

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:59.958
they already have nearly four million registered users --

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
that's critical mass.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
And the same thing's happening on the carrier side.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
You're looking at IP taking over from some of the traditional

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:13.958
telecom standards. This is a tipping point --

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:17.958
if Malcolm's here, forgive me -- and it's going to change the economics,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
and the speed, and the players in the industry.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:27.958
It's going to look a little bit like that.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And finally, free. Free is really, really interesting.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:39.958
Free is something that comes with digital, because

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:45.958
the reproduction costs are essentially free. It comes with IP,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
because it's such an efficient protocol. It comes with fiber optics,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:49.958
because there's so much bandwidth.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:54.958
Free is really, you know, the gift of Silicon Valley to the world.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
It's an economic force; it's a technical force.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:01.958
It's a deflationary force, if not handled right.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
It is abundance, as opposed to scarcity.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
Free is probably the most interesting thing.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
And here you have just the number of songs

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
that can be stored on a hard drive.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
You know, there could be a film's [unclear] there,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
but it's basically, every song ever made could be stored

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:25.958
on 400 dollars worth of storage by 2008. It takes that entire element,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:29.958
the physical element, of songs off the table.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:30.958
And you've seen the numbers.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:34.958
I mean, you know, the music industry is imploding

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
in front of our very eyes, and Hollywood's worried as well.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:42.958
They're facing a force that they haven't faced before.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And their response is draconian, and not necessarily

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
the one that's going to get them out of this.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
And finally, I'll give you one last example of free --

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
perhaps the most powerful of all. I mentioned fiber optics --

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
their abundance tends to make things free.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
This is the price of a phone call to India per minute.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And what's interesting is that it was just 1990

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
when it was more than two dollars a minute.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:19.958
India had, still has, a regulated phone system and so did we.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:24.958
It was surprisingly non-innovative, moved very slowly,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
but then there was just so much fiber out there,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:31.958
you couldn't hold back, and look how quickly the price fell.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:35.958
It's seven cents a minute, in many cases.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:40.958
And the consequence of cheap phone calling, free phone calling,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:45.958
to India, is the pissed-off programmer, is the outsourcing.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
It is probably one of the most dramatic shifts in globalization

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
and one of the most powerful economic tools

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:53.958
that we're seeing in our world today.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:58.958
The force of India, and then China, and any other country

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
that can contact our markets

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:05.958
and will work with our companies -- because the communications are free --

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
is just beginning to be felt.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:08.958
And I think that's probably one

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
of the most important technology trends that we're looking at today.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
Thank you.
